AC-2:supplement:<del>Information s</del><ins>S</ins>ystem account types include, for example, individual, shared, group, system, guest<del>/</del><ins>, </ins>anonymous, emergency, developer/manufacturer/vendor, temporary, and service. <del>Some of the account management requirements listed above can be implemented by organizational information systems. </del>The identification of authorized users of the <del>information </del>system and the specification of access privileges reflects the requirements in other <del>se</del>c<del>urity c</del>ontrols in the security plan. Users requiring administrative privileges on <del>information </del>system accounts receive additional scrutiny by appropriate organizational personnel <del>(</del><ins>r</ins>e<del>.</del><ins>sponsible for approvin</ins>g<del>.</del><ins> such accounts and privileged access</ins>, <ins>including, for example, </ins>system owner, mission/business owner, or chief information security officer<del>) responsible for approving such accounts and privileged access</del>. Organizations may choose to define access privileges or other attributes by account, by type of account, or a combination of both. Other attributes required for authorizing access include, for example, restrictions on time-of-day, day-of-week, and point-of-origin. In defining other account attributes, organizations consider system-related requirements <del>(e.g., scheduled m</del>a<del>i</del>n<del>tenance, system upgra</del>d<del>es)</del> <del>and </del>mission/business requirements<del>, (e</del>.<del>g.,</del> <del>time zone differences, customer requirements, remote access to support travel requirements). </del>Failure to consider these factors could affect <del>information </del>system availability. Temporary and emergency accounts are <del>accounts </del>intended for short-term use. Organizations establish temporary accounts as a part of normal account activation procedures when there is a need for short-term accounts without the demand for immediacy in account activation. Organizations establish emergency accounts in response to crisis situations and with the need for rapid account activation. Therefore, emergency account activation may bypass normal account authorization processes. Emergency and temporary accounts are not to be confused with infrequently used accounts <del>(e.</del><ins>includin</ins>g<del>.</del>, <ins>for examp</ins>l<ins>e, l</ins>ocal logon accounts used for special tasks <del>defined by </del>or<del>ganizations</del> <del>or </del>when network resources are unavailable<del>)</del>. Such accounts remain available and are not subject to automatic disabling or removal dates. Conditions for disabling or deactivating accounts include, for example<del>:</del><ins>,</ins> <del>(i) </del>when shared/group, emergency, or temporary accounts are no longer required; or <del>(ii) </del>when individuals are transferred or terminated. Some types of <del>information </del>system accounts may require specialized training. Related <del>c</del><ins>C</ins>ontrols: AC-3, AC-<del>4, AC-</del>5, AC-6, AC-1<del>0</del><ins>7</ins>, AC-1<del>7</del><ins>8</ins>, AC-<del>19</del><ins>20</ins>, AC-2<del>0</del><ins>4</ins>, AU-9, <del>IA</del><ins>CM</ins>-<del>2</del><ins>5</ins>, IA-<del>4</del><ins>2</ins>, IA-<del>5</del><ins>8</ins>, <del>I</del><ins>M</ins>A-<del>8</del><ins>3</ins>, <del>C</del>M<ins>A</ins>-5, <del>CM</del><ins>PE</ins>-<del>6</del><ins>2</ins>, <del>CM</del><ins>PL</ins>-<del>11</del><ins>4</ins>, <del>MA</del><ins>PS</ins>-<del>3</del><ins>2</ins>, <del>MA</del><ins>PS</ins>-4, <del>MA</del><ins>PS</ins>-5, P<del>L</del><ins>S</ins>-<del>4</del><ins>7</ins>, SC-<ins>7, SC-</ins>13<ins>, SC-37</ins>.

AC-2 (2):supplement:This control enhancement requires the removal o<ins>r disabling o</ins>f both temporary and emergency accounts automatically after a predefined <ins>time-</ins>period <del>of time </del>has elapsed, rather than at the convenience of the systems administrator<ins>. Automatic removal or disabling of accounts provides a more consistent implementation. Related Controls: None</ins>.

AC-2 (6):title:ACCOUNT MANAGEMENT | DYNAMIC PRIVILEGE MANAGEMENT
AC-2 (6):text:<del>The infor</del><ins>I</ins>m<del>ation system im</del>plement<del>s</del> the following dynamic privilege management capabilities: [Assignment: organization-defined list of dynamic privilege management capabilities].
AC-2 (6):supplement:In contrast to conventional access control approaches which employ static <del>information </del>system accounts and predefined <del>sets of </del>user privileges, dynamic access control approaches <del>(e.g., se</del>r<del>vic</del>e<del>-oriented architectures) re</del>ly on run time access control decisions facilitated by dynamic privilege management<ins> such as attribute based access control (ABAC)</ins>. While user identities <del>may </del>remain relatively constant over time, user privileges <del>m</del><ins>typic</ins>a<ins>ll</ins>y change more frequently based on ongoing mission<del>/</del><ins> or </ins>business requirements and operational needs of organizations. Dynamic privilege management can include, for example, <del>the </del>immediate revocation of privileges from users, as opposed to requiring that users terminate and restart their sessions to reflect any changes in privileges. Dynamic privilege management can also <del>r</del><ins>includ</ins>e<del>fer</del> t<ins>h</ins>o<ins>se</ins> mechanisms that change <del>th</del><ins>us</ins>e<ins>r</ins> privileges <del>of users </del>based on dynamic rules as opposed to editing specific user profiles. <del>This ty</del><ins>Exam</ins>p<del>e of privi</del>le<del>ge</del><ins>s</ins> <del>management </del>include<del>s,</del> <del>for ex</del>a<del>mple, a</del>utomatic adjustments of <ins>user </ins>privileges if <del>us</del><ins>th</ins>e<del>rs</del><ins>y</ins> are operating out of their normal work times, <del>o</del><ins>thei</ins>r <del>if</del><ins>job</ins> <ins>funct</ins>i<ins>o</ins>n<del>f</del><ins> </ins>or<del>m</del><ins> </ins>a<del>t</del><ins>ss</ins>i<del>o</del><ins>g</ins>n<ins>ment</ins> <ins>change</ins>s<ins>, or if s</ins>ystems are under duress or in emergency <del>maintenance </del>situations. This control enhancement also includes the <del>ancillary </del>effects of privilege changes, for example, the <del>potential </del>changes to encryption keys used for communications. <del>Dynamic privilege management can support requirements for information system resiliency. </del>Related <del>c</del><ins>C</ins>ontrol<ins>s</ins>: AC-16.

AC-2 (7):supplement:Privileged roles are organization-defined roles assigned to individuals that allow those individuals to perform certain security-relevant functions that ordinary users are not authorized to perform. These privileged roles include, for example, key management, account management, network and system administration, database administration, and web administration.<ins> Related Controls: None.</ins>

AC-3 (3):supplement:Mandatory access control <del>as def</del>i<del>ned in thi</del>s <del>control enh</del>a<del>ncement</del> <del>is s</del><ins>t</ins>y<del>n</del><ins>pe </ins>o<del>nymous</del><ins>f</ins> <del>with </del>nondiscretionary access control<del>, and is not constrained only to certain historical uses (e</del>.<del>g.,</del> <del>implementations using the Bell-LaPadula Model). </del>The above class of mandatory access control policies constrains what actions subjects can take with information obtained from data objects for which they have already been granted access<del>,</del><ins>.</ins> <del>t</del><ins>T</ins>h<del>u</del><ins>i</ins>s prevent<del>ing</del><ins>s</ins> the subjects from passing the information to unauthorized subjects and objects. This class of mandatory access control policies also constrains what actions subjects can take with respect to the propagation of access control privileges; that is, a subject with a privilege cannot pass that privilege to other subjects. The policy is uniformly enforced over all subjects and objects to which the <del>information </del>system has control. Otherwise, the access control policy can be circumvented. This enforcement <del>typ</del>i<del>cally i</del>s provided <del>via</del><ins>by</ins> an implementation that meets the reference monitor concept <del>(</del><ins>a</ins>s<ins> d</ins>e<ins>scrib</ins>e<ins>d</ins> <ins>in </ins>AC-25<del>)</del>. The policy is bounded by the <del>information </del>system boundary (i.e., once the information is passed outside of the control of the system, additional means may be required to ensure that the constraints on the information remain in effect). The trusted subjects described above are granted privileges consistent with the concept of least privilege (see AC-6). Trusted subjects are only given the minimum privileges relative to the above policy necessary for satisfying organizational mission/business needs. The control is most applicable when there is <del>some</del><ins>a</ins> policy mandate <del>(e.g., law, Execu</del>t<del>ive Order, directive, or regulation) t</del>hat establishes a policy regarding access to <del>s</del><ins>controll</ins>e<ins>d u</ins>n<ins>cla</ins>s<ins>s</ins>i<del>t</del><ins>f</ins>i<del>v</del>e<del>/</del><ins>d information or </ins>classified information and some users of the <del>information </del>system are not authorized access to all s<del>ensitive/</del><ins>u</ins>c<del>lassified</del><ins>h</ins> information resident in the <del>information </del>system. This control can operate in conjunction with AC-3<del> </del>(4). A subject <del>that is </del>constrained in its operation by policies governed by this control is still able to operate under the less rigorous constraints of AC-3<del> </del>(4), but policies governed by this control take precedence over the less rigorous constraints of AC-3<del> </del>(4). For example, while a mandatory access control policy imposes a constraint preventing a subject from passing information to another subject operating at a different sensitivity label, AC-3<del> </del>(4) permits the subject to pass the information to any subject with the same sensitivity label as the subject. Related <del>c</del><ins>C</ins>ontrols: <del>AC-25, </del>SC-<del>11</del><ins>7</ins>.

AC-3 (4):supplement:When discretionary access control policies are implemented, subjects are not constrained <del>with </del>regard<ins>ing</ins> <del>to </del>what actions they can take with information for which they have already been granted access. Thus, subjects that have been granted access to information are not prevented from passing (i.e., the subjects have the discretion to pass) the information to other subjects or objects. This control enhancement can operate in conjunction with AC-3<del> </del>(3). A subject that is constrained in its operation by policies governed by AC-3<del> </del>(3) is still able to operate under the less rigorous constraints of this control enhancement. Th<del>us</del><ins>erefore</ins>, while AC-3<del> </del>(3) imposes constraints preventing a subject from passing information to another subject operating at a different sensitivity level, AC-3<del> </del>(4) permits the subject to pass the information to any subject at the same sensitivity level. Once the information is passed outside of the control of the <del>information </del>system, additional means may be required to <ins>h</ins>e<ins>lp e</ins>nsure that the constraints remain in effect. While the older, more traditional definitions of discretionary access control require identity-based access control, that limitation is not required for this use of discretionary access control<ins>. Related Controls: None</ins>.
AC-3 (5):title:ACCESS ENFORCEMENT | SECURITY-RELEVANT INFORMATION
AC-3 (5):text:<del>The info</del><ins>P</ins>r<del>mation syst</del>e<del>m pre</del>vent<del>s</del> access to [Assignment: organization-defined security-relevant information] except during secure, non-operable system states.
AC-3 (5):supplement:Security-relevant information is any information within <del>information </del>systems that can potentially impact the operation of security functions or the provision of security services in a manner that could result in failure to enforce system security policies or maintain the isolation of code and data. Security-relevant information includes, for example, filtering rules for routers/firewalls, cryptographic key management information, configuration parameters for security services, and access control lists. Secure, non-operable system states include the times in which <del>information </del>systems are not performing mission/business-related processing<ins>,</ins> <del>(</del><ins>for </ins>e<del>.g.</del><ins>xample</ins>, the system is off-line for maintenance, troubleshooting, boot-up, <ins>or </ins>shut down<del>)</del>. AC-3 (7):title:ACCESS ENFORCEMENT | ROLE-BASED ACCESS CONTROL
AC-3 (7):text:<del>The i</del><ins>E</ins>nfor<del>mation system enfor</del>ce<del>s</del> a role-based access control policy over defined subjects and objects and control<del>s</del> access based upon [Assignment: organization-defined roles and users authorized to assume such roles].
AC-3 (7):supplement:Role-based access control (RBAC) is an access control policy that restricts <del>information </del>system access to authorized users. Organizations can create specific roles based on job functions and the authorizations (i.e., privileges) to perform needed operations on <del>organiza</del>t<del>ional</del><ins>he</ins> <del>information </del>systems associated with the organization-defined roles. When users are assigned to the organizational roles, they inherit the authorizations or privileges defined for those roles. RBAC simplifies privilege administration for organizations because privileges are not assigned directly to every user (which can be a significant number of individuals for mid- to large-size organizations) but are instead acquired through role assignments. RBAC can be implemented either as a mandatory or discretionary form of access control. For organizations implementing RBAC with mandatory access controls, the requirements in AC-3<del> </del>(3) define the scope of the subjects and objects covered by the policy<ins>. Related Controls: PE-2</ins>.
AC-3 (8):title:ACCESS ENFORCEMENT | REVOCATION OF ACCESS AUTHORIZATIONS

AC-3 (8):supplement:Revocation of access rules may differ based on the types of access revoked. For example, if a subject (i.e., user or process) is removed from a group, access may not be revoked until the next time the object <del>(e.g., f</del>i<del>le) i</del>s opened or <del>un</del>t<del>il t</del>he next time the subject attempts a new access to the object. Revocation based on changes to security labels may take effect immediately. Organizations <del>can </del>provide alternative approaches on how to make revocations immediate if <del>information </del>systems cannot provide such capability and immediate revocation is necessary<ins>. Related Controls: None</ins>.
AC-3 (9):title:ACCESS ENFORCEMENT | CONTROLLED RELEASE
AC-3 (9):text:<del>Th</del><ins>R</ins>e<del> information system does not re</del>lease information outside of the established system boundary <del>u</del><ins>o</ins>nl<del>ess</del><ins>y if</ins>:

AC-3 (9):supplement:<del>Information s</del><ins>S</ins>ystems can only protect organizational information within the confines of established system boundaries. Additional security <del>safegua</del><ins>cont</ins>r<del>d</del><ins>ol</ins>s may be needed to ensure that such information is adequately protected once it is passed beyond the established <del>information </del>system boundaries. <del>Examples of i</del><ins>I</ins>n<del>formation</del> <del>leav</del><ins>s</ins>i<del>ng </del>t<del>he system bo</del>u<del>nd</del>a<del>ry include </del>t<del>ransm</del>i<del>tting inf</del>o<del>rmatio</del>n<del> to an external information </del>s<del>ystem</del> <del>or printing the information on one of its printers. In cases </del>where the <del>information </del>system is unable to <del>make a </del>determin<del>ation</del><ins>e</ins> <del>of </del>the adequacy of the protections provided by entities outside its boundary, as a mitigating control, organizations determine procedurally whether the external <del>information </del>systems are providing adequate security. The means used to determine the adequacy of <del>the </del>security provided by external <del>information </del>systems include, for example, conducting inspections or periodic testing<del>,</del> <ins>and ass</ins>es<ins>smen</ins>t<ins>s; est</ins>ablishing agreements between the organization and its counterpart organizations<del>,</del><ins>;</ins> or some other process. The means used by external entities to protect the information received need not be the same as those used by the organization, but the means employed are sufficient to provide consistent adjudication of the security policy to protect the information. This control enhancement requires <del>information </del>systems to employ technical or procedural means to validate the information prior to releasing it to external systems. For example, if the <del>information </del>system passes information to another system controlled by another organization, technical means are employed to validate that the security attributes associated with the exported information are appropriate for the receiving system. Alternatively, if the <del>information </del>system passes information to a printer in organization-controlled space, procedural means can be employed to ensure that only appropriately authorized individuals gain access to the printer. This control enhancement is most applicable when there is some policy mandate <del>(e.g., law, Execu</del>t<del>ive Order, directive, or regulation) t</del>hat establishes policy regarding access to the information, and that policy applies beyond the realm of a particular <del>information </del>system or organization<ins>. Related Controls: SC-16</ins>.

AC-3 (12):title:<ins>ACCESS ENFORCEMENT | ASSERT AND ENFORCE APPLICATION ACCESS</ins>
AC-3 (12) (a):text:<ins>Require applications to assert, as part of the installation process, the access needed to the following system applications and functions: [Assignment: organization-defined system applications and functions]; and</ins>
AC-3 (12) (b):text:<ins>Provide an enforcement mechanism to prevent other-than-asserted access.</ins>
AC-3 (12):supplement:<ins>This control enhancement is intended to address applications that need to access existing system applications and functions including, for example, user contacts; global positioning system; camera; keyboard; microphone; network; or phones or other files. Related Controls: CM-7.</ins>
AC-3 (13):title:<ins>ACCESS ENFORCEMENT | ATTRIBUTE-BASED ACCESS CONTROL</ins>
AC-3 (13):text:<ins>Enforce attribute-based access control policy over defined subjects and objects and control access based upon [Assignment: organization-defined attributes to assume access permissions].</ins>
AC-3 (13):supplement:<ins>Attribute-based access control (ABAC) is an access control policy that restricts system access to authorized users based on their organizational attributes, such as job function; environmental attributes, such as time of day; and resource attributes, such as the classification of a document. Organizations can create specific rules based on attributes and the authorizations (i.e., privileges) to perform needed operations on the systems associated with the organization-defined attributes and rules. When users are assigned to attributes defined in ABAC policies or rules, they can be provisioned to a system with appropriate privileges or dynamically granted access to a protected resource upon access. ABAC can be implemented either as a mandatory or discretionary form of access control. For organizations implementing ABAC with mandatory access controls, the requirements in AC-3(3) define the scope of the subjects and objects covered by the policy. Related Controls: PE-2.</ins>
AC-3:references:N<ins>IST Special Publicati</ins>on<ins>s 800-57-1 , 800-57-2 , 800-57-3 , 800-162 ; NIST Int</ins>e<ins>ragency Report 7874</ins>

AC-4:title:INFORMATION FLOW ENFORCEMENT
AC-4:text:<del>The i</del><ins>E</ins>nfor<del>mation system enfor</del>ce<del>s</del> approved authorizations for controlling the flow of information within the system and between interconnected systems based on [Assignment: organization-defined information flow control policies].
AC-4:supplement:Information flow control regulates where information <del>is </del><ins>c</ins>a<del>llowed</del><ins>n</ins> t<del>o t</del>ravel within a<del>n</del> <del>information </del>system and between <del>information </del>systems (as opposed to who is allowed to access the information) and without explicit regard to subsequent accesses to that information. Flow control restrictions include, for example, keeping export-controlled information from being transmitted in the clear to the Internet, blocking outside traffic that claims to be from within the organization, restricting web requests to the Internet that are not from the internal web proxy server, and limiting information transfers between organizations based on data structures and content. Transferring information between <del>information </del>systems <del>represent</del>in<del>g</del> different security domains with different security policies introduces risk that such transfers violate one or more domain security policies. In such situations, information owners<del>/</del><ins> or </ins>stewards provide guidance at designated policy enforcement points between interconnected systems. Organizations consider mandating specific architectural solutions when required to enforce specific security policies. Enforcement includes, for example<del>:</del><ins>,</ins> <del>(i) </del>prohibiting information transfers between interconnected systems (i.e., allowing access only); <del>(ii) </del>employing hardware mechanisms to enforce one-way information flows; and <del>(</del>i<del>ii) i</del>mplementing trustworthy regrading mechanisms to reassign security attributes and security labels. Organizations commonly employ information flow control policies and enforcement mechanisms to control the flow of information between designated sources and destinations <del>(e.g., net</del>w<del>orks, </del>i<del>ndividuals, and devices) wi</del>thin <del>information </del>systems and between interconnected systems. Flow control is based on the characteristics of the information and/or the information path. Enforcement occurs, for example, in boundary protection devices <del>(e.g., ga</del>t<del>eways, routers, guards, encrypted tunnels, firewalls) t</del>hat employ rule sets or establish configuration settings that restrict <del>information </del>system services, provide a packet-filtering capability based on header information, or message-filtering capability based on message content<del> (e</del>.<del>g.,</del> <del>implementing key word searches or using document characteristics). </del>Organizations also consider the trustworthiness of filtering/inspection mechanisms (i.e., hardware, firmware, and software components) that are critical to information flow enforcement. Control enhancements 3 through 22 primarily address cross-domain solution needs which focus on more advanced filtering techniques, in-depth analysis, and stronger flow enforcement mechanisms implemented in cross-domain products, for example, high-assurance guards. Such capabilities are generally not available in commercial off-the-shelf information technology products. Related <del>c</del><ins>C</ins>ontrols: AC-3, AC-<ins>6, AC-</ins>1<ins>6, AC-1</ins>7, AC-19, AC-21, <ins>AU-10, </ins>C<del>M</del><ins>A</ins>-<del>6</del><ins>9</ins>, CM-7, <del>SA</del><ins>PM</ins>-<del>8</del><ins>25</ins>, SC-<del>2</del><ins>4</ins>, SC-<del>5</del><ins>7</ins>, SC-<del>7</del><ins>16</ins>, SC-<ins>3</ins>1<del>8</del>.
AC-4 (1):title:INFORMATION FLOW ENFORCEMENT | OBJECT SECURITY ATTRIBUTES
AC-4 (1):text:<del>The information </del><ins>U</ins>s<del>yst</del>e<del>m uses</del> [Assignment: organization-defined security attributes] associated with [Assignment: organization-defined information, source, and destination objects] to enforce [Assignment: organization-defined information flow control policies] as a basis for flow control decisions.
AC-4 (1):supplement:Information flow enforcement mechanisms compare security attributes associated with information (data content and data structure) and source/destination objects, and respond appropriately <del>(e.g., block, quarantine, alert administrator) </del>when the mechanisms encounter information flows not explicitly allowed by information flow policies. For example, an information object labeled Secret would be allowed to flow to a destination object labeled Secret, but an information object labeled Top Secret would not be allowed to flow to a destination object labeled Secret. Security attributes can also include, for example, source and destination addresses employed in traffic filter firewalls. Flow enforcement using explicit security attributes can be used, for example, to control the release of certain types of information. Related <del>c</del><ins>C</ins>ontrol<ins>s</ins>: <del>AC-16</del><ins>None</ins>.
AC-4 (2):title:INFORMATION FLOW ENFORCEMENT | PROCESSING DOMAINS
AC-4 (2):text:<del>The information </del><ins>U</ins>s<del>yst</del>e<del>m uses</del> protected processing domains to enforce [Assignment: organization-defined information flow control policies] as a basis for flow control decisions.
AC-4 (2):supplement:Within <del>information </del>systems, protected processing domains are processing spaces that have controlled interactions with other processing spaces, <del>thus </del>enabling control of information flows between these spaces and to/from data/information objects. A protected processing domain can be provided, for example, by implementing domain and type enforcement. In domain and type enforcement, <del>information </del>system processes are assigned to domains; information is identified by types; and information flows are controlled based on allowed information accesses (determined by domain and type), allowed signaling among domains, and allowed process transitions to other domains<ins>. Related Controls: SC-39</ins>.
AC-4 (3):title:INFORMATION FLOW ENFORCEMENT | DYNAMIC INFORMATION FLOW CONTROL
AC-4 (3):text:<del>The i</del><ins>E</ins>nfor<del>mation system enfor</del>ce<del>s</del> dynamic information flow control based on [Assignment: organization-defined policies].
AC-4 (3):supplement:Organizational policies regarding dynamic information flow control include, for example, allowing or disallowing information flows based on changing conditions or mission/operational considerations. Changing conditions include, for example, changes in organizational risk tolerance due to changes in the immediacy of mission/business needs, changes in the threat environment, and detection of potentially harmful or adverse events. Related <del>c</del><ins>C</ins>ontrol<ins>s</ins>: SI-4.
AC-4 (4):title:INFORMATION FLOW ENFORCEMENT <del> </del>| <ins>FLOW </ins>CONT<del>ENT</del><ins>ROL</ins> <del>CHECK</del><ins>OF</ins> ENCRYPTED INFORMATION
AC-4 (4):text:<del>The info</del><ins>P</ins>r<del>mation syst</del>e<del>m pre</del>vent<del>s</del> encrypted information from bypassing <del>co</del><ins>[Assig</ins>n<del>t</del><ins>m</ins>ent<ins>: organization</ins>-<del>ch</del><ins>d</ins>e<del>ck</del><ins>f</ins>in<del>g</del><ins>ed</ins> <ins>flow control </ins>mechanisms<ins>]</ins> by [Selection (one or more): decrypting the information; blocking the flow of the encrypted information; terminating communications sessions attempting to pass encrypted information; [Assignment: organization-defined procedure or method]].
AC-4 (4):supplement:<del>R</del><ins>Cont</ins>e<ins>nt checking, security po</ins>l<ins>icy filters, </ins>a<ins>nd da</ins>t<ins>a typ</ins>e<ins> i</ins>d<ins>entifiers</ins> <ins>are examples of flow </ins>control<ins> mechanisms. Related Controls</ins>: SI-4.
AC-4 (5):title:INFORMATION FLOW ENFORCEMENT | EMBEDDED DATA TYPES
AC-4 (5):text:<del>The i</del><ins>E</ins>nfor<del>mation system enfor</del>ce<del>s</del> [Assignment: organization-defined limitations] on embedding data types within other data types.
AC-4 (5):supplement:Embedding data types within other data types may result in reduced flow control effectiveness. Data type embedding includes, for example, inserting executable files as objects within word processing files, inserting references or descriptive information into a media file, and compressed or archived data types that may include multiple embedded data types. Limitations on data type embedding consider the levels of embedding and prohibit levels of data type embedding that are beyond the capability of the inspection tools.<ins> Related Controls: None.</ins>
AC-4 (6):title:INFORMATION FLOW ENFORCEMENT | METADATA
AC-4 (6):text:<del>The i</del><ins>E</ins>nfor<del>mation system enfor</del>ce<del>s</del> information flow control based on [Assignment: organization-defined metadata].
AC-4 (6):supplement:Metadata is information used to describe the characteristics of data. Metadata can include structural metadata describing data structures <del>(e.g., data f</del>or<del>mat,</del> <del>syntax, an</del>d<del> s</del>e<del>mantic</del>s<del>) or des</del>criptive metadata describing data contents<del> (e</del>.<del>g.,</del> <del>age, location, telephone number). </del>Enforcing allowed information flows based on metadata enables simpler and more effective flow control. Organizations consider the trustworthiness of metadata <del>with </del>regard<ins>ing</ins> <del>to </del>data accuracy (i.e., knowledge that the metadata values are correct with respect to the data), data integrity (i.e., protecting against unauthorized changes to metadata tags), and the binding of metadata to the data payload (i.e., ensuring sufficiently strong binding techniques with appropriate levels of assurance). Related <del>c</del><ins>C</ins>ontrols: AC-16, SI-7.
AC-4 (7):title:INFORMATION FLOW ENFORCEMENT | ONE-WAY FLOW MECHANISMS
AC-4 (7):text:<del>The i</del><ins>E</ins>nfor<del>mation system enfor</del>ce<del>s</del> [Assignment: organization-defined one-way information flows] using hardware mechanisms.
AC-4 (7):supplement:<ins>None. Related Controls: None.</ins>
AC-4 (8):title:INFORMATION FLOW ENFORCEMENT | SECURITY POLICY FILTERS
AC-4 (8):text:<del>The i</del><ins>E</ins>nfor<del>mation system enfor</del>ce<del>s</del> information flow control using [Assignment: organization-defined security policy filters] as a basis for flow control decisions for [Assignment: organization-defined information flows].
AC-4 (8):supplement:Organization-defined security policy filters can address data structures and content. For example, security policy filters for data structures can check for maximum file lengths, maximum field sizes, and data/file types (for structured and unstructured data). Security policy filters for data content can check for specific words <del>(</del>e<del>.g., dirty/clea</del>n<del> word filters), en</del>umerated values or data value ranges, and hidden content. Structured data permits the interpretation of data content by applications. Unstructured data <del>typically </del>refers to digital information without a <del>particular </del>data structure or with a data structure that does not facilitate the development of rule sets to address the <del>particular </del>sensitivity of the information conveyed by the data or the <del>associated </del>flow enforcement decisions. Unstructured data consists of<del>:</del> <del>(i) </del>bitmap objects that are inherently non<del> </del><ins>-</ins>language-based (i.e., image, video, or audio files); and <del>(ii) </del>textual objects that are based on written or printed languages<del> (e</del>.<del>g.,</del> <del>commercial off-the-shelf word processing documents, spreadsheets, or emails). </del>Organizations can implement more than one security policy filter to meet information flow control objectives<del> (e</del>.<del>g.,</del> <ins>R</ins>e<del>mp</del>l<del>oying cle</del>a<del>n wor</del><ins>te</ins>d <del>lists in c</del><ins>C</ins>on<del>junc</del>t<del>ion with di</del>r<del>ty w</del>o<del>rd </del>l<del>i</del>s<del>ts</del><ins>:</ins> <del>may help t</del><ins>N</ins>o<del> r</del><ins>n</ins>e<del>duce false positives)</del>.
AC-4 (9):title:INFORMATION FLOW ENFORCEMENT | HUMAN REVIEWS
AC-4 (9):text:<del>The i</del><ins>E</ins>nfor<del>mation system enfor</del>ce<del>s</del> the use of human reviews for [Assignment: organization-defined information flows] under the following conditions: [Assignment: organization-defined conditions].
AC-4 (9):supplement:Organizations define security policy filters for all situations where automated flow control decisions are possible. When a fully automated flow control decision is not possible, then a human review may be employed in lieu of, or as a complement to, automated security policy filtering. Human reviews may also be employed as deemed necessary by organizations.<ins> Related Controls: None.</ins>
AC-4 (10):title:INFORMATION FLOW ENFORCEMENT | ENABLE <del>/</del><ins>AND</ins> DISABLE SECURITY POLICY FILTERS
AC-4 (10):text:<del>The info</del><ins>P</ins>r<del>mati</del>o<del>n system pro</del>vide<del>s</del> the capability for privileged administrators to enable<del>/</del><ins> and </ins>disable [Assignment: organization-defined security policy filters] under the following conditions: [Assignment: organization-defined conditions].
AC-4 (10):supplement:For example, as allowed by the <del>information </del>system authorization, administrators can enable security policy filters to accommodate approved data types<ins>. Related Controls: None</ins>.
AC-4 (11):title:INFORMATION FLOW ENFORCEMENT | CONFIGURATION OF SECURITY POLICY FILTERS
AC-4 (11):text:<del>The info</del><ins>P</ins>r<del>mati</del>o<del>n system pro</del>vide<del>s</del> the capability for privileged administrators to configure [Assignment: organization-defined security policy filters] to support different security policies.
AC-4 (11):supplement:For example, to reflect changes in security policies, administrators can change the list of <del>"</del><ins>“</ins>dirty words<del>"</del><ins>”</ins> that security policy mechanisms check in accordance with the definitions provided by organizations<ins>. Related Controls: None</ins>.
AC-4 (12):title:INFORMATION FLOW ENFORCEMENT | DATA TYPE IDENTIFIERS
AC-4 (12):text:<del>T</del><ins>W</ins>he<del> i</del>n<del>formation</del> <del>sys</del>t<del>em, when t</del>ransferring information between different security domains, use<del>s</del> [Assignment: organization-defined data type identifiers] to validate data essential for information flow decisions.
AC-4 (12):supplement:Data type identifiers include, for example, filenames, file types, file signatures/tokens, and multiple internal file signatures/tokens. <del>Information s</del><ins>S</ins>ystems may allow transfer of data only if compliant with data type format specifications<ins>. Related Controls: None</ins>.
AC-4 (13):title:INFORMATION FLOW ENFORCEMENT | DECOMPOSITION INTO POLICY-RELEVANT SUBCOMPONENTS
AC-4 (13):text:<del>T</del><ins>W</ins>he<del> i</del>n<del>formation</del> <del>sys</del>t<del>em, when t</del>ransferring information between different security domains, decompose<del>s</del> information into [Assignment: organization-defined policy-relevant subcomponents] for submission to policy enforcement mechanisms.
AC-4 (13):supplement:Policy enforcement mechanisms apply filtering, inspection, and/or sanitization rules to the policy-relevant subcomponents of information to facilitate flow enforcement prior to transferring such information to different security domains. Parsing transfer files facilitates policy decisions on source, destination, certificates, classification, attachments, and other security-related component differentiators.<ins> Related Controls: None.</ins>
AC-4 (14):title:INFORMATION FLOW ENFORCEMENT | SECURITY POLICY FILTER CONSTRAINTS
AC-4 (14):text:<del>T</del><ins>W</ins>he<del> i</del>n<del>formation</del> <del>sys</del>t<del>em, when t</del>ransferring information between different security domains, implement<del>s</del> [Assignment: organization-defined security policy filters] requiring fully enumerated formats that restrict data structure and content.
AC-4 (14):supplement:Data structure and content restrictions reduce the range of potential malicious <del>and/</del>or unsanctioned content in cross-domain transactions. Security policy filters that restrict data structures include, for example, restricting file sizes and field lengths. Data content policy filters include, for example<del>:</del><ins>,</ins> <del>(i) </del>encoding formats for character sets<del> (e.g., Universal Character Set Transformation Formats, American Standard Code for Information Interchange)</del>; <del>(ii) </del>restricting character data fields to only contain alpha-numeric characters; <del>(iii) </del>prohibiting special characters; and <del>(i</del>v<del>) v</del>alidating schema structures<ins>. Related Controls: None</ins>.
AC-4 (15):title:INFORMATION FLOW ENFORCEMENT | DETECTION OF UNSANCTIONED INFORMATION
AC-4 (15):text:<del>T</del><ins>W</ins>he<del> i</del>n<del>formation</del> <del>sys</del>t<del>em, when t</del>ransferring information between different security domains, examine<del>s</del> the information for the presence of [Assignment: organized-defined unsanctioned information] and prohibit<del>s</del> the transfer of such information in accordance with the [Assignment: organization-defined security policy].
AC-4 (15):supplement:Detection of unsanctioned information includes, for example, checking all information to be transferred for malicious code and dirty words. Related <del>c</del><ins>C</ins>ontrol<ins>s</ins>: SI-3.

AC-4 (17):title:INFORMATION FLOW ENFORCEMENT | DOMAIN AUTHENTICATION
AC-4 (17):text:<del>The i</del><ins>U</ins>n<del>format</del>i<del>on system uni</del>quely identif<del>ies</del><ins>y</ins> and authenticate<del>s</del> source and destination points by [Selection (one or more): organization, system, application<ins>, service</ins>, individual] for information transfer.
AC-4 (17):supplement:Attribution is a critical component of a security concept of operations. The ability to identify source and destination points for information flowing in <del>information </del>systems, allows the forensic reconstruction of events when required, and encourages policy compliance by attributing policy violations to specific organizations/individuals. Successful domain authentication requires that <del>information </del>system labels distinguish among systems, organizations, and individuals involved in preparing, sending, receiving, or disseminating information. Related <del>c</del><ins>C</ins>ontrols: IA-2, IA-3, IA-<del>4, IA-5</del><ins>9</ins>.
AC-4 (18):title:INFORMATION FLOW ENFORCEMENT | SECURITY ATTRIBUTE BINDING
AC-4 (18):withdrawn:<ins>Incorporated into AC-16</ins>
AC-4 (18):text:<del>The information system binds security attributes to information using [Assignment: organization-defined binding techniques] to facilitate information flow policy enforcement.</del>
AC-4 (18):supplement:<del>Binding techniques implemented by information systems affect the strength of security attribute binding to information. Binding strength and the assurance associated with binding techniques play an important part in the trust organizations have in the information flow enforcement process. The binding techniques affect the number and degree of additional reviews required by organizations. Related controls: AC-16, SC-16.</del>
AC-4 (19):title:INFORMATION FLOW ENFORCEMENT | VALIDATION OF METADATA
AC-4 (19):text:<del>T</del><ins>W</ins>he<del> i</del>n<del>formation</del> <del>sys</del>t<del>em, when t</del>ransferring information between different security domains, appl<del>ies</del><ins>y</ins> the same security policy filtering to metadata as it applies to data payloads.
AC-4 (19):supplement:This control enhancement requires the validation of metadata and the data to which the metadata applies. Some organizations distinguish between metadata and data payloads (i.e., only the data to which the metadata is bound). Other organizations do not make such distinctions, considering metadata and the data to which the metadata applies as part of the payload. All information (including metadata and the data to which the metadata applies) is subject to filtering and inspection.<ins> Related Controls: None.</ins>
AC-4 (20):title:INFORMATION FLOW ENFORCEMENT | APPROVED SOLUTIONS
AC-4 (20):text:<del>The organization e</del><ins>E</ins>mploy<del>s</del> [Assignment: organization-defined solutions in approved configurations] to control the flow of [Assignment: organization-defined information] across security domains.
AC-4 (20):supplement:Organizations define approved solutions and configurations in cross-domain policies and guidance in accordance with the types of information flows across classification boundaries. The Unified Cross Domain Management Office <del>(UCDMO) </del>provides a baseline listing of approved cross-domain solutions<ins>. Related Controls: None</ins>.
AC-4 (21):title:INFORMATION FLOW ENFORCEMENT | PHYSICAL <del>/</del><ins>AND</ins> LOGICAL SEPARATION OF INFORMATION FLOWS
AC-4 (21):text:<del>Th</del><ins>S</ins>e<del> information system se</del>parate<del>s</del> information flows logically or physically using [Assignment: organization-defined mechanisms and/or techniques] to accomplish [Assignment: organization-defined required separations by types of information].
AC-4 (21):supplement:Enforcing the separation of information flows by type can enhance protection by ensuring that information is not commingled while in transit and by enabling flow control by transmission paths perhaps not otherwise achievable. Types of separable information include, for example, inbound and outbound communications traffic, service requests and responses, and information of differing security categories.<ins> Related Controls: SC-32.</ins>
AC-4 (22):title:INFORMATION FLOW ENFORCEMENT | ACCESS ONLY
AC-4 (22):text:<del>The info</del><ins>P</ins>r<del>mati</del>o<del>n system pro</del>vide<del>s</del> access from a single device to computing platforms, applications, or data residing on multiple different security domains, while preventing any information flow between the different security domains.
AC-4 (22):supplement:The <del>information </del>system, for example, provides a desktop for users to access each connected security domain without providing any mechanisms to allow transfer of information between the different security domains<ins>. Related Controls: None</ins>.

AC-5:title:SEPARATION OF DUTIES
AC-5:text:<del>The organization:</del>
AC-5 a:text:<del>The organization: </del>Separate<del>s</del> [Assignment: organization-defined duties of individuals];

AC-5 c:text:<del>The organization: </del>Define<del>s information</del> system access authorizations to support separation of duties.
AC-5:supplement:Separation of duties addresses the potential for abuse of authorized privileges and helps to reduce the risk of malevolent activity without collusion. Separation of duties includes, for example<del>:</del><ins>,</ins> <del>(i) </del>dividing mission functions and <del>information </del>system support functions among different individuals and/or roles; <del>(ii) </del>conducting <del>information </del>system support functions with different individuals<ins>;</ins> <del>(</del><ins>and </ins>e<del>.</del><ins>nsurin</ins>g<del>.,</del> s<ins>ecurit</ins>y<ins> per</ins>s<del>t</del><ins>onn</ins>e<del>m</del><ins>l</ins> <del>m</del>a<del>nage</del><ins>d</ins>m<del>e</del><ins>i</ins>n<ins>is</ins>t<del>, p</del><ins>e</ins>r<del>ogramm</del>ing<del>,</del> <ins>a</ins>c<ins>cess c</ins>on<ins>trol </ins>f<del>ig</del>u<del>ra</del><ins>nc</ins>tion<ins>s</ins> <del>ma</del><ins>do </ins>n<ins>ot </ins>a<del>ge</del><ins>lso ad</ins>m<del>e</del><ins>i</ins>n<ins>is</ins>t<del>,</del><ins>er</ins> <del>qu</del>a<del>l</del><ins>ud</ins>it<del>y</del> <del>ass</del><ins>f</ins>u<del>ra</del>nc<ins>tions. B</ins>e<ins>cause</ins> <ins>sep</ins>a<ins>ratio</ins>n<ins> of </ins>d<ins>uty</ins> <ins>viola</ins>t<del>est</del>i<ins>o</ins>n<del>g,</del><ins>s</ins> <ins>c</ins>an<del>d</del> <ins>spa</ins>n<del>etwork</del> s<del>ecurit</del>y<del>);</del><ins>stems</ins> and <del>(</del><ins>appl</ins>i<ins>cat</ins>i<del>i)</del><ins>on</ins> <del>e</del><ins>domai</ins>ns<del>u</del><ins>, o</ins>r<ins>gan</ins>i<ins>zatio</ins>n<del>g</del><ins>s</ins> <ins>con</ins>s<ins>id</ins>e<del>cu</del>r<del>i</del><ins> </ins>t<del>y</del><ins>he</ins> <del>p</del>e<del>rso</del>n<del>n</del><ins>tir</ins>e<del>l</del><ins>ty</ins> <ins>of org</ins>a<del>dmi</del>ni<del>s</del><ins>za</ins>t<del>er</del>i<ins>o</ins>n<del>g </del>a<del>cce</del><ins>l </ins>s<ins>y</ins>s<ins>tems</ins> <del>co</del><ins>a</ins>n<ins>d sys</ins>t<del>rol</del><ins>em</ins> <del>fun</del>c<del>ti</del>o<ins>mpo</ins>n<ins>ent</ins>s <del>do </del><ins>whe</ins>n<del>ot</del> <del>a</del><ins>deve</ins>l<del>s</del>o<del> adm</del><ins>p</ins>in<ins>g pol</ins>i<ins>cy on </ins>s<del>t</del>e<ins>pa</ins>r<del> </del>a<del>udi</del>t<ins>ion</ins> <ins>o</ins>f<ins> d</ins>u<del>nc</del>ti<del>on</del><ins>e</ins>s. Related <del>c</del><ins>C</ins>ontrols: AC-<ins>2, AC-</ins>3, AC-6, <ins>AU-9, CM-5, CM-11, C</ins>P<del>E</del>-<ins>9, IA-2, IA-5, MA-</ins>3, <del>PE</del><ins>MA</ins>-<del>4</del><ins>5</ins>, PS-2<ins>, SA-17</ins>.

AC-6:title:LEAST PRIVILEGE
AC-6:text:<del>The organization e</del><ins>E</ins>mploy<del>s</del> the principle of least privilege, allowing only authorized accesses for users (or processes acting on behalf of users) which are necessary to accomplish assigned tasks in accordance with organizational missions and business functions.
AC-6:supplement:Organizations employ least privilege for specific duties and <del>information </del>systems. The principle of least privilege is also applied to <del>information </del>system processes, ensuring that the processes operate at privilege levels no higher than necessary to accomplish required organizational missions<del>/</del><ins> or </ins>business functions. Organizations consider the creation of additional processes, roles, and <del>information </del>system accounts as necessary, to achieve least privilege. Organizations also apply least privilege to the development, implementation, and operation of organizational <del>information </del>systems. Related <del>c</del><ins>C</ins>ontrols: AC-2, AC-3, AC-5, <ins>A</ins>C<del>M</del>-<ins>1</ins>6, CM-<del>7</del><ins>5</ins>, <ins>CM-11, </ins>PL-2<ins>, PM-12, SA-15, SA-17, SC-38</ins>.
AC-6 (1):title:LEAST PRIVILEGE | AUTHORIZE ACCESS TO SECURITY FUNCTIONS
AC-6 (1):text:<del>The organization e</del><ins>E</ins>xplicitly authorize<del>s</del> access to [Assignment: organization-defined security functions (deployed in hardware, software, and firmware) and security-relevant information].
AC-6 (1):supplement:Security functions include, for example, establishing system accounts, configuring access authorizations (i.e., permissions, privileges), setting events to be audited, and <del>s</del>e<ins>s</ins>t<del>t</del><ins>abl</ins>i<ins>shi</ins>ng intrusion detection parameters. Security-relevant information includes, for example, filtering rules for routers/firewalls, cryptographic key management information, configuration parameters for security services, and access control lists. Explicitly authorized personnel include, for example, security administrators, system and network administrators, system security officers, system maintenance personnel, system programmers, and other privileged users. Related <del>c</del><ins>C</ins>ontrols: AC-17, AC-18, AC-19<ins>, AU-9, PE-2</ins>.
AC-6 (2):title:LEAST PRIVILEGE | NON-PRIVILEGED ACCESS FOR NONSECURITY FUNCTIONS
AC-6 (2):text:<del>Th</del><ins>R</ins>e<del> organization re</del>quire<del>s</del> that users of<del> information</del> system accounts, or roles, with access to [Assignment: organization-defined security functions or security-relevant information], use non-privileged accounts or roles, when accessing nonsecurity functions.
AC-6 (2):supplement:This control enhancement limits exposure when operating from within privileged accounts or roles. The inclusion of roles addresses situations where organizations implement access control policies such as role-based access control and where a change of role provides the same degree of assurance in the change of access authorizations for both the user and all processes acting on behalf of the user as would be provided by a change between a privileged and non-privileged account. Related <del>c</del><ins>C</ins>ontrol<ins>s</ins>:<ins> AC-17, AC-18, AC-19,</ins> PL-4.
AC-6 (3):title:LEAST PRIVILEGE | NETWORK ACCESS TO PRIVILEGED COMMANDS
AC-6 (3):text:<del>The organization a</del><ins>A</ins>uthorize<del>s</del> network access to [Assignment: organization-defined privileged commands] only for [Assignment: organization-defined compelling operational needs] and document<del>s</del> the rationale for such access in the security plan for the<del> information</del> system.
AC-6 (3):supplement:Network access is any access across a network connection in lieu of local access (i.e., user being physically present at the device). Related <del>c</del><ins>C</ins>ontrol<ins>s</ins>: AC-17<ins>, AC-18, AC-19</ins>.
AC-6 (4):title:LEAST PRIVILEGE | SEPARATE PROCESSING DOMAINS
AC-6 (4):text:<del>The info</del><ins>P</ins>r<del>mati</del>o<del>n system pro</del>vide<del>s</del> separate processing domains to enable finer-grained allocation of user privileges.
AC-6 (4):supplement:Providing separate processing domains for finer-grained allocation of user privileges includes, for example<del>:</del><ins>,</ins> <del>(i) </del>using virtualization techniques to allow additional <ins>user </ins>privileges within a virtual machine while restricting privileges to other virtual machines or to the underlying actual machine; <del>(ii) </del>employing hardware<del> and</del>/<del>or </del>software domain separation mechanisms; and <del>(</del>i<del>ii) i</del>mplementing separate physical domains. Related <del>c</del><ins>C</ins>ontrols: AC-4, SC-<ins>2, SC-</ins>3, SC-30, SC-32<ins>, SC-39</ins>.
AC-6 (5):title:LEAST PRIVILEGE | PRIVILEGED ACCOUNTS
AC-6 (5):text:<del>Th</del><ins>R</ins>e<del> organization re</del>strict<del>s</del> privileged accounts on the<del> information</del> system to [Assignment: organization-defined personnel or roles].
AC-6 (5):supplement:Privileged accounts, including super user accounts, are typically described as system administrator for various types of commercial off-the-shelf operating systems. Restricting privileged accounts to specific personnel or roles prevents day-to-day users from having access to privileged information/functions. Organizations may differentiate in the application of this control enhancement between allowed privileges for local accounts and for domain accounts provided <del>organiza</del>t<del>ions</del><ins>hey</ins> retain the ability to control <del>information </del>system configurations for key security parameters and as otherwise necessary to sufficiently mitigate risk. Related <del>c</del><ins>C</ins>ontrol<ins>s</ins>: <del>C</del><ins>IA-2, </ins>M<ins>A</ins>-<del>6</del><ins>3, MA-4</ins>.
AC-6 (6):title:LEAST PRIVILEGE | PRIVILEGED ACCESS BY NON-ORGANIZATIONAL USERS
AC-6 (6):text:<del>The o</del><ins>P</ins>r<del>ganizati</del>o<del>n pro</del>hibit<del>s</del> privileged access to the<del> information</del> system by non-organizational users.
AC-6 (6):supplement:<ins>None. </ins>Related <del>c</del><ins>C</ins>ontrol<ins>s</ins>:<ins> AC-18, AC-19, IA-2,</ins> IA-8.
AC-6 (7):title:LEAST PRIVILEGE | REVIEW OF USER PRIVILEGES
AC-6 (7):text:<del>The organization:</del>
AC-6 (7) (a):text:<del>The organization: </del>Review<del>s</del> [Assignment: organization-defined frequency] the privileges assigned to [Assignment: organization-defined roles or classes of users] to validate the need for such privileges; and
AC-6 (7) (b):text:<del>The organization: </del>Reassign<del>s</del> or remove<del>s</del> privileges, if necessary, to correctly reflect organizational mission<del>/</del><ins> and </ins>business needs.
AC-6 (7):supplement:The need for certain assigned user privileges may change over time reflecting changes in organizational missions<del>/</del><ins> and </ins>business function<ins>s</ins>, environments of operation, technologies, or threat. Periodic review of assigned user privileges is necessary to determine if the rationale for assigning such privileges remains valid. If the need cannot be revalidated, organizations take appropriate corrective actions. Related <del>c</del><ins>C</ins>ontrol<ins>s</ins>: CA-7.
AC-6 (8):title:LEAST PRIVILEGE | PRIVILEGE LEVELS FOR CODE EXECUTION
AC-6 (8):text:<del>The info</del><ins>P</ins>r<del>mation syst</del>e<del>m pre</del>vent<del>s</del> <del>[Assignmen</del>t<del>:</del><ins>he</ins> <ins>f</ins>o<del>rganizati</del><ins>ll</ins>o<del>n-def</del><ins>w</ins>in<del>ed</del><ins>g</ins> software<del>]</del> from executing at higher privilege levels than users executing the software<ins>: [Assignment: organization-defined software]</ins>.
AC-6 (8):supplement:In certain situations, software applications/programs need to execute with elevated privileges to perform required functions. However, if the privileges required for execution are at a higher level than the privileges assigned to organizational users invoking such applications/programs, those users are indirectly provided with greater privileges than assigned by organizations.<ins> Related Controls: None.</ins>
AC-6 (9):title:LEAST PRIVILEGE | AUDITING USE OF PRIVILEGED FUNCTIONS
AC-6 (9):text:<del>The information system a</del><ins>A</ins>udit<del>s</del> the execution of privileged functions.
AC-6 (9):supplement:Misuse of privileged functions, either intentionally or unintentionally by authorized users, or by unauthorized external entities that have compromised <del>information </del>system accounts, is a serious and ongoing concern and can have significant adverse impacts on organizations. Auditing the use of privileged functions is one way to detect such misuse, and in doing so, help mitigate the risk from insider threats and the advanced persistent threat<del> (APT)</del>. Related <del>c</del><ins>C</ins>ontrol<ins>s</ins>: AU-<ins>2, AU-1</ins>2.
AC-6 (10):title:LEAST PRIVILEGE | PROHIBIT NON-PRIVILEGED USERS FROM EXECUTING PRIVILEGED FUNCTIONS
AC-6 (10):text:<del>The info</del><ins>P</ins>r<del>mation syst</del>e<del>m pre</del>vent<del>s</del> non-privileged users from executing privileged function<del>s to include disabling, circumventing, or altering implemented security safeguards/countermeasure</del>s.
AC-6 (10):supplement:Privileged functions include, for example, <del>e</del><ins>di</ins>s<del>t</del>abli<del>shi</del>ng<ins>,</ins> <ins>c</ins>i<ins>rcumve</ins>n<del>f</del><ins>ting, </ins>or<del>m</del><ins> </ins>a<ins>l</ins>t<ins>er</ins>i<ins>ng implemented security </ins>o<ins>r privacy co</ins>n<ins>trols,</ins> <ins>e</ins>s<ins>tablishing s</ins>ystem accounts, performing system integrity checks, or administering cryptographic key management activities. Non-privileged users are individuals that do not possess appropriate authorizations. Circumventing intrusion detection and prevention mechanisms or malicious code protection mechanisms are examples of privileged functions that require protection from non-privileged users<ins>. Related Controls: None</ins>.

AC-7:title:UNSUCCESSFUL LOGON ATTEMPTS
AC-7:text:<del>The information system:</del>
AC-7 a:text:<del>The information system: </del>Enforce<del>s</del> a limit of [Assignment: organization-defined number] consecutive invalid logon attempts by a user during a [Assignment: organization-defined time<del> </del><ins>-</ins>period]; and
AC-7 b:text:<del>The information system: </del>Automatically [Selection<ins> (one or more)</ins>: lock<del>s</del> the account/node for an [Assignment: organization-defined time<del> </del><ins>-</ins>period]; lock<del>s</del> the account/node until released by an administrator; delay<del>s</del> next logon prompt <del>acco</del><ins>pe</ins>r<del>ding</del> <del>to </del>[Assignment: organization-defined delay algorithm<ins>]; take [Assignment: organization-defined action</ins>]] when the maximum number of unsuccessful attempts is exceeded.
AC-7:supplement:This control applies regardless of whether the logon occurs via a local or network connection. Due to the potential for denial of service, automatic lockouts initiated by <del>information </del>systems are usually temporary and automatically release after a predetermined time <del>p</del>e<del>riod e</del>stablished by organizations. If a delay algorithm is selected, organizations may <del>choos</del>e<del> to e</del>mploy different algorithms for different <del>inf</del><ins>c</ins>o<del>r</del>m<del>ati</del><ins>p</ins>on<ins>ents</ins> <ins>of the </ins>system <del>components </del>based on the capabilities of those components. Responses to unsuccessful logon attempts may be implemented at both the operating system and the application levels. Related <del>c</del><ins>C</ins>ontrols: AC-2, AC-9, A<del>C</del><ins>U</ins>-<del>14</del><ins>2, AU-6</ins>, IA-5.

AC-7 (1):withdrawn:Incorporated into AC-7
AC-7 (2):title:UNSUCCESSFUL LOGON ATTEMPTS | PURGE <del>/</del><ins>OR</ins> WIPE MOBILE DEVICE
AC-7 (2):text:<del>Th</del><ins>Purg</ins>e <del>inf</del>or<del>mation</del> <del>system purges/</del>wipe<del>s</del> information from [Assignment: organization-defined mobile devices] based on [Assignment: organization-defined purging<del>/</del><ins> or </ins>wiping requirements<del>/</del><ins> and </ins>techniques] after [Assignment: organization-defined number] consecutive, unsuccessful device logon attempts.
AC-7 (2):supplement:This control enhancement applies only to mobile devices for which a logon occurs<del> (e</del>.<del>g.,</del> <del>personal digital assistants, smart phones, tablets). </del>The logon is to the mobile device, not to any one account on the device. <del>Therefore, s</del><ins>S</ins>uccessful logons to a<del>ny a</del>ccounts on mobile devices reset the unsuccessful logon count to zero. <del>O</del><ins>Pu</ins>rg<del>an</del>i<del>zatio</del>n<del>s define information to be pur</del>g<del>ed/wiped</del> <del>carefully in </del>or<del>der</del> <del>to avoid over purging/</del>wiping <del>which </del>may <del>result in devices </del>be<del>coming</del> un<del>usable. Purgi</del>n<del>g/wiping may b</del>e<del> unne</del>cessary if the information on the device is protected with sufficiently strong encryption mechanisms. Related <del>c</del><ins>C</ins>ontrols: AC-19, MP-5, MP-6<del>, SC-13</del>.
AC-7 (3):title:<ins>UNSUCCESSFUL LOGON ATTEMPTS | BIOMETRIC ATTEMPT LIMITING</ins>
AC-7 (3):text:<ins>Limit the number of unsuccessful biometric logon attempts to [Assignment: organization-defined number].</ins>
AC-7 (3):supplement:<ins>Biometrics are probabilistic in nature. The ability to successfully authenticate can be impacted by many factors, including matching performance and presentation attack detection mechanisms. Organizations select the appropriate number of attempts and fall back mechanisms for users based on these, and other organizationally defined factors. Related Controls: IA-3.</ins>
AC-7 (4):title:<ins>UNSUCCESSFUL LOGON ATTEMPTS | USE OF ALTERNATE FACTOR</ins>
AC-7 (4):text:<ins>Allow the use of one or more additional authentication factors after the number of organization-defined consecutive invalid logon attempts have been exceeded.</ins>
AC-7 (4):supplement:<ins>This control enhancement supports the objective of availability and allows a user that has inadvertently been locked out to use additional authentication factors to bypass the lockout. Related Controls: IA-3.</ins>

AC-10:supplement:Organizations may define the maximum number of concurrent sessions for <del>information </del>system accounts globally, by account type<del> (e.g.</del>, <del>privileged user, non-privileged user, domain, specific application), </del>by account, or a combination<ins> thereof</ins>. AC-11:title:<del>S</del><ins>D</ins>E<del>SS</del><ins>V</ins>I<del>ON</del><ins>CE</ins> LOCK

AC-11 a:text:<del>The information system: </del>Prevent<del>s</del> further access to the system by initiating a <del>s</del><ins>d</ins>e<del>ss</del><ins>v</ins>i<del>on</del><ins>ce</ins> lock after [Assignment: organization-defined time<del> </del><ins>-</ins>period] of inactivity or upon receiving a request from a user; and
AC-11 b:text:<del>The information system: </del>Retain<del>s</del> the <del>s</del><ins>d</ins>e<del>ss</del><ins>v</ins>i<del>on</del><ins>ce</ins> lock until the user reestablishes access using established identification and authentication procedures.
AC-11:supplement:<del>S</del><ins>D</ins>e<del>ss</del><ins>v</ins>i<del>on</del><ins>ce</ins> locks are temporary actions taken <ins>to prevent logical access to organizational systems </ins>when users stop work and move away from the immediate vicinity of <del>informa</del>t<del>i</del><ins>h</ins>o<del>n</del><ins>se</ins> systems but do not want to log out because of the temporary nature of their absences. <del>S</del><ins>D</ins>e<del>ss</del><ins>v</ins>i<del>on</del><ins>ce</ins> locks are implemented where session activities can be determined. This is typically at the operating system level, but can also be at the application level. <del>S</del><ins>D</ins>e<del>ss</del><ins>v</ins>i<del>on</del><ins>ce</ins> locks are not an acceptable substitute for logging out of <del>information </del>systems, for example, if organizations require users to log out at the end of workdays. Related <del>c</del><ins>C</ins>ontrol<ins>s</ins>: AC-<ins>2, AC-</ins>7<ins>, IA-11</ins>.

AC-11 (1):supplement:<del>Publicly vi</del><ins>Th</ins>e<del>w</del><ins> p</ins>a<del>bl</del><ins>tt</ins>e<del> </del><ins>rn-h</ins>i<del>ma</del><ins>din</ins>g<del>e</del><ins> di</ins>s<ins>play</ins> can include static or dynamic images, for example, patterns used with screen savers, photographic images, solid colors, clock, battery life indicator, or a blank screen, with the <del>additional </del>caveat that <del>n</del><ins>c</ins>on<del>e of </del>t<del>he images c</del><ins>r</ins>o<del>nv</del><ins>ll</ins>e<del>y</del><ins>d</ins> <del>se</del><ins>u</ins>n<ins>cla</ins>s<ins>s</ins>i<del>t</del><ins>f</ins>i<del>v</del>e<ins>d</ins> information<ins> is not displayed. AC-12:title:SESSION TERMINATION
AC-12:text:<del>The information system a</del><ins>A</ins>utomatically terminate<del>s</del> a user session after [Assignment: organization-defined conditions or trigger events requiring session disconnect].
AC-12:supplement:This control addresses the termination of user-initiated logical sessions in contrast to SC-10 which addresses the termination of network connections that are associated with communications sessions (i.e., network disconnect). A logical session (for local, network, and remote access) is initiated whenever a user (or process acting on behalf of a user) accesses an organizational <del>information </del>system. Such user sessions can be terminated <del>(and thus terminate user access) </del>without terminating network sessions. Session termination terminates all processes associated with a user<del>'</del><ins>’</ins>s logical session except those processes that are specifically created by the user (i.e., session owner) to continue after the session is terminated. Conditions or trigger events requiring automatic session termination can include, for example, organization-defined periods of user inactivity, targeted responses to certain types of incidents, time-of-day restrictions on <del>information </del>system use. Related <del>c</del><ins>C</ins>ontrols:<ins> MA-4,</ins> SC-10, SC-23.
AC-12 (1):title:SESSION TERMINATION | USER-INITIATED LOGOUTS<del> / MESSAGE DISPLAYS</del>
AC-12 (1):text:<del>Th</del><ins>Provid</ins>e <ins>a logout capab</ins>i<del>n</del><ins>lity </ins>for<ins> user-initiated co</ins>m<ins>munic</ins>ation<ins>s</ins> s<del>y</del><ins>e</ins>s<ins>sions whenever au</ins>t<ins>h</ins>e<ins>ntication is used to gain access to [Assign</ins>m<ins>ent</ins>:<ins> organization-defined information resources].</ins>
AC-12 (1) (a):text:<del>The information system: Provides a logout capability for user-initiated communications sessions whenever authentication is used to gain access to [Assignment: organization-defined information resources]; and</del>
AC-12 (1) (b):text:<del>The information system: Displays an explicit logout message to users indicating the reliable termination of authenticated communications sessions.</del>
AC-12 (1):supplement:Information resources to which users gain access via authentication include, for example, local workstations, databases, and password-protected websites/web-based services. <del>Logout m</del><ins>R</ins>e<del>ssages for web page access, for examp</del>l<del>e, c</del>a<del>n be displayed af</del>te<del>r authenticate</del>d <del>sessi</del><ins>C</ins>on<del>s have been </del>t<del>e</del>r<del>minated. H</del>o<del>wever, for some types of interactive sessions inc</del>l<del>uding, for example, file tran</del>s<del>fer</del><ins>:</ins> <del>pr</del><ins>N</ins>o<del>tocol (FTP) sessio</del>n<del>s, information syst</del>e<del>ms typically send logout messages as final messages prior to terminating sessions</del>.
AC-12 (2):title:<ins>SESSION TERMINATION | TERMINATION MESSAGE</ins>
AC-12 (2):text:<ins>Display an explicit logout message to users indicating the reliable termination of authenticated communications sessions.</ins>
AC-12 (2):supplement:<ins>Logout messages for web page access, for example, can be displayed after authenticated sessions have been terminated. However, for some types of interactive sessions including, for example, file transfer protocol (FTP) sessions, systems typically send logout messages as final messages prior to terminating sessions. Related Controls: None.</ins>
AC-12 (3):title:<ins>SESSION TERMINATION | TIMEOUT WARNING MESSAGE</ins>
AC-12 (3):text:<ins>Display an explicit message to users indicating that the session is about to end.</ins>
AC-12 (3):supplement:<ins>To increase usability, notify users of pending session termination and prompt for activity if users desire to continue the session. Related Controls: None.</ins>

AC-14:title:PERMITTED ACTIONS WITHOUT IDENTIFICATION OR AUTHENTICATION
AC-14:text:<del>The organization:</del>
AC-14 a:text:<del>The organization: </del>Identif<del>ies</del><ins>y</ins> [Assignment: organization-defined user actions] that can be performed on the <del>information </del>system without identification or authentication consistent with organizational missions<del>/</del><ins> and </ins>business functions; and
AC-14 b:text:<del>The organization: </del>Document<del>s</del> and provide<del>s</del> supporting rationale in the security plan for the<del> information</del> system, user actions not requiring identification or authentication.
AC-14:supplement:This control addresses situations in which organizations determine that no identification or authentication is required in organizational <del>information </del>systems. Organizations may allow a limited number of user actions without identification or authentication including, for example, when individuals access public websites or other publicly accessible federal <del>information </del>systems, when individuals use mobile phones to receive calls, or when facsimiles are received. Organizations also identify actions that normally require identification or authentication but may under certain circumstances<del> (e.g.</del>, <del>emergencies), </del>allow identification or authentication mechanisms to be bypassed. Such bypasses may occur, for example, via a software-readable physical switch that commands bypass of the logon functionality and is protected from accidental or unmonitored use. This control does not apply to situations where identification and authentication have already occurred and are not repeated, but rather to situations where identification and authentication have not yet occurred. Organizations may decide that there are no user actions that can be performed on organizational <del>information </del>systems without identification and authentication and th<del>us</del><ins>erefore</ins>, the values for assignment statements can be none. Related <del>c</del><ins>C</ins>ontrols: <ins>A</ins>C<del>P</del>-<del>2</del><ins>8</ins>, IA<ins>-2, PL</ins>-2.

AC-16:title:SECURITY A<ins>ND PRIVACY A</ins>TTRIBUTES
AC-16:text:<del>The organization:</del>
AC-16 a:text:<del>The organization: </del>Provide<del>s</del> the means to associate [Assignment: organization-defined types of security a<ins>nd privacy a</ins>ttributes] having [Assignment: organization-defined securit<ins>y and privac</ins>y attribute values] with information in storage, in process, and/or in transmission;
AC-16 b:text:<del>The organization: </del>Ensure<del>s</del> that the securit<ins>y and privac</ins>y attribute associations are made and retained with the information;
AC-16 c:text:<del>The organization: </del>Establish<del>es</del> the permitted [Assignment: organization-defined security attributes] for [Assignment: organization-defined<del> information</del> systems]; and
AC-16 d:text:<del>The organization: </del>Determine<del>s</del> the permitted [Assignment: organization-defined values or ranges] for each of the established securit<ins>y and privac</ins>y attributes.
AC-16:supplement:Information is represented internally within <del>information </del>systems using abstractions known as data structures. Internal data structures can represent different types of entities, both active and passive. Active entities, also known as subjects, are typically associated with individuals, devices, or processes acting on behalf of individuals. Passive entities, also known as objects, are typically associated with data structures such as records, buffers, tables, files, inter-process pipes, and communications ports. Security attributes, a form of metadata, are abstractions representing the basic properties or characteristics of active and passive entities with respect to safeguarding information. <del>T</del><ins>Privacy attributes, w</ins>h<ins>ich may b</ins>e<ins> u</ins>se<ins>d</ins> <ins>independently, or in conjunction with security </ins>attributes<ins>,</ins> <ins>represent the basic properties or characteristics of an entity with respect to the </ins>ma<ins>nagement of personall</ins>y <ins>identifia</ins>b<ins>l</ins>e <ins>inform</ins>a<ins>tion. Such attribute</ins>s<ins> are u</ins>s<ins>ed t</ins>o<ins> enable the implementation of the need for the re</ins>c<ins>ord </ins>i<ins>n the perform</ins>a<ins>nce of du</ins>t<ins>i</ins>e<ins>s, the i</ins>d<ins>entification</ins> <ins>of personal information </ins>with<ins>in</ins> <ins>d</ins>a<ins>ta obje</ins>ct<ins>s, and the </ins>i<ins>dentification of permitted uses of personal information. Attributes can be explicitly or implicitly associated with the information contained in organizational systems or system components. Security and pri</ins>v<ins>acy attribut</ins>e<ins>s</ins> <ins>may b</ins>e<ins> associated with active e</ins>ntities (i.e., subjects) that have the potential to send or receive information, to cause information to flow among objects, or to change the <del>information </del>system state. These attributes may also be associated with passive entities (i.e., objects) that contain or receive information. The association of security a<ins>nd privacy a</ins>ttributes to subjects and objects is referred to as binding and is <del>typ</del>i<del>cally i</del>nclusive of setting the attribute value and the attribute type. Security a<ins>nd privacy a</ins>ttributes when bound to data<del>/</del><ins> or </ins>information, enable<del>s</del> the enforcement of <del>information </del>security policies for access control and information flow control<ins> and privacy policies including</ins>, <ins>for </ins>e<ins>xample, for data retent</ins>i<ins>on limi</ins>t<ins>s and permitted uses of personally identifiable information. Suc</ins>h<ins> </ins>e<ins>nfo</ins>r<ins>cement</ins> <ins>occurs </ins>through organizational processes or <ins>system funct</ins>i<ins>o</ins>n<del>f</del><ins>s </ins>or<ins> </ins>m<ins>ech</ins>a<ins>nisms. Binding </ins>t<ins>echn</ins>i<del>o</del><ins>ques impleme</ins>n<ins>ted</ins> <ins>by </ins>system<ins>s</ins> <ins>a</ins>f<ins>fect the strength of attrib</ins>u<ins>te bi</ins>n<ins>ding to information. Binding strength and the assuran</ins>c<ins>e associa</ins>t<ins>ed w</ins>i<ins>th binding techniques play an imp</ins>o<ins>rta</ins>n<ins>t part in the tru</ins>s<ins>t</ins> or<ins>ganizations</ins> <ins>have in the infor</ins>m<ins>ation flow </ins>e<ins>nfor</ins>c<ins>ement process. T</ins>h<del>a</del><ins>e bi</ins>n<ins>d</ins>i<ins>ng technique</ins>s<ins> affect the nu</ins>m<ins>ber and degree of additional review</ins>s<ins> required by organizations</ins>. The content or assigned values of <ins>the </ins>security a<ins>nd privacy a</ins>ttributes can directly affect the ability of individuals to access organizational information. Organizations can define the types of attributes needed for selected <del>information </del>systems to support missions<del>/</del><ins> or </ins>business functions. There is potentially a wide range of values that can be assigned to any given security attribute. Release markings c<del>ould</del><ins>an</ins> include, for example, US only, NATO, or NOFORN (not releasable to foreign nationals). By specifying permitted attribute ranges and values, organizations <del>can </del>ensure that the security a<ins>nd privacy a</ins>ttribute values are meaningful and relevant. <del>The term security l</del><ins>L</ins>abeling refers to the association of security a<ins>nd privacy a</ins>ttributes with subjects and objects represented by <ins>the </ins>internal data structures within organizational <del>information </del>systems<del>,</del><ins>.</ins> <del>to</del><ins>This</ins> <del>en</del><ins>f</ins>a<del>b</del><ins>ci</ins>l<del>e </del>i<del>nform</del><ins>t</ins>at<del>ion</del><ins>es</ins> system-based enforcement of information security <ins>and </ins>p<ins>rivacy p</ins>olicies. <del>Security l</del><ins>L</ins>abels include, for example, access authorizations, <ins>nationality, </ins>data life cycle protection (i.e., encryption and data expiration), <del>n</del><ins>d</ins>at<del>i</del><ins>a subject c</ins>on<del>al</del><ins>sents, perm</ins>i<ins>ssible da</ins>t<del>y</del><ins>a uses</ins>, affiliation as contractor, and classification of information in accordance with legal and compliance requirements. <del>Th</del><ins>Conv</ins>e<del> te</del>r<del>m </del>se<del>curit</del><ins>l</ins>y<ins>,</ins> marking refers to the association of security a<ins>nd privacy a</ins>ttributes with objects in a human-readable form<del>,</del><ins>.</ins> <del>to</del><ins>This</ins> enable<ins>s</ins> <del>org</del><ins>m</ins>an<del>iz</del><ins>u</ins>a<del>ti</del><ins>l, pr</ins>o<del>n</del><ins>cedur</ins>al<ins>,</ins> <ins>or </ins>process-based enforcement of information security <del>policies. The AC-16 b</del>a<del>se co</del>n<del>trol</del><ins>d</ins> <del>re</del>pr<del>esents the requ</del>i<del>rement for user-b</del><ins>v</ins>a<del>sed</del><ins>cy</ins> <del>attribute ass</del><ins>p</ins>o<ins>li</ins>ci<del>ation (marking)</del><ins>es</ins>. <del>The enh</del><ins>Ex</ins>a<del>nce</del>m<del>ents to AC-16 re</del>p<del>resent additiona</del>l<del> r</del>e<del>quirement</del>s <del>including inf</del>o<del>rmation</del><ins>f</ins> <del>system-b</del>a<del>sed a</del>ttribute <del>associa</del>t<del>ion (labeling). T</del>ypes <del>of attr</del>i<del>butes i</del>nclude<del>,</del> <del>for example, </del>classification level for objects and clearance (access authorization) level for subjects. An <del>ex</del>a<del>mpl</del><ins>ttribut</ins>e <del>of a </del>value for both <del>of these </del>attribute types is Top Secret. Related <del>c</del><ins>C</ins>ontrols: AC-3, AC-4, AC-6, AC-21, A<ins>C-25, A</ins>U-2, AU-10, <ins>IP-2, MP-3, PE-22, </ins>SC-1<ins>1, SC-1</ins>6, <del>MP</del><ins>SI</ins>-<del>3</del><ins>12</ins>.
AC-16 (1):title:SECURITY A<ins>ND PRIVACY A</ins>TTRIBUTES | DYNAMIC ATTRIBUTE ASSOCIATION
