AC-17:title:REMOTE ACCESS
AC-17:text:<del>The organization:</del>
AC-17 a:text:<del>The organization: </del>Establish<del>es</del> and document<del>s</del> usage restrictions, configuration/connection requirements, and implementation guidance for each type of remote access allowed; and
AC-17 b:text:<del>The organization: </del>Authorize<del>s</del> remote access to the<del> information</del> system prior to allowing such connections.
AC-17:supplement:Remote access is access to organizational <del>information </del>systems <del>by users </del>(or processes acting on behalf of users) communicating through external networks <del>(e.g.,</del><ins>such</ins> <ins>as </ins>the Internet<del>)</del>. Remote access methods include, for example, dial-up, broadband, and wireless. Organizations often employ encrypted virtual private networks (VPNs) to enhance confidentiality and integrity over remote connections. The use of encrypted VPNs <del>d</del><ins>pr</ins>o<ins>vid</ins>es <ins>sufficie</ins>n<del>o</del>t <del>m</del>a<del>k</del><ins>ssuranc</ins>e t<ins>o t</ins>he <ins>org</ins>a<del>ccess </del>n<ins>izati</ins>on<del>-remote;</del> <ins>t</ins>h<del>owever,</del><ins>at</ins> <ins>i</ins>t<del>he</del> <del>use of VPNs, whe</del><ins>ca</ins>n <del>ad</del>e<del>qua</del><ins>ffec</ins>t<ins>iv</ins>ely <del>p</del><ins>t</ins>r<del>ovision</del>e<del>d with </del>a<del>ppropria</del>t<del>e</del> s<del>ec</del>u<del>rity</del><ins>ch</ins> con<ins>nec</ins>t<del>r</del><ins>i</ins>o<del>l</del><ins>n</ins>s <del>(e.g.,</del><ins>as</ins> <del>employ</del>in<del>g app</del><ins>te</ins>r<ins>nal netw</ins>o<del>p</del>r<ins>ks </ins>i<del>a</del><ins>f </ins>t<ins>h</ins>e <del>en</del>crypt<del>i</del>o<del>n</del><ins>graphic</ins> <del>t</del><ins>m</ins>ech<ins>a</ins>ni<del>q</del><ins>sms </ins>u<del>e</del>s<ins>ed</ins> <del>fo</del><ins>a</ins>r<ins>e</ins> <del>conf</del>i<del>d</del><ins>mpl</ins>e<ins>me</ins>nt<del>iality an</del><ins>e</ins>d in<del>tegrity</del> <del>prote</del><ins>a</ins>c<del>ti</del><ins>c</ins>o<del>n) may p</del>r<del>ovi</del>d<del>e sufficient </del>a<del>ssura</del>nce <ins>wi</ins>t<del>o t</del>h<del>e</del> <del>org</del>a<del>n</del><ins>ppl</ins>i<del>z</del><ins>c</ins>a<del>tion</del><ins>ble</ins> <del>th</del><ins>l</ins>a<del>t</del><ins>ws,</ins> <del>i</del><ins>Execu</ins>t<ins>ive</ins> <del>can</del><ins>Orders,</ins> <ins>dir</ins>e<del>ffe</del>ctive<del>ly</del><ins>s,</ins> <del>t</del>re<ins>gul</ins>at<del> </del><ins>ion</ins>s<del>uch</del><ins>,</ins> <del>c</del><ins>p</ins>o<del>nne</del><ins>li</ins>c<del>t</del>i<del>on</del><ins>e</ins>s<ins>,</ins> <ins>st</ins>a<ins>ndard</ins>s<ins>,</ins> <del>i</del><ins>a</ins>n<del>t</del><ins>d guid</ins>e<del>rna</del>l<del> </del><ins>i</ins>ne<del>twork</del>s. Still, VPN connections traverse external networks, and the encrypted VPN does not enhance the availability of remote connections. <del>Also, </del>VPNs with encrypted tunnels can a<ins>lso a</ins>ffect the <del>organizational </del>capability to adequately monitor network communications traffic for malicious code. Remote access controls apply to <del>information </del>systems other than public web servers or systems designed for public access. This control addresses authorization prior to allowing remote access without specifying the <ins>speci</ins>f<ins>ic f</ins>ormats for such authorization. While organizations may use interconnection security agreements to authorize remote access connections, such agreements are not required by this control. Enforcing access restrictions for remote connections is addressed in AC-3. AC-19:title:ACCESS CONTROL FOR MOBILE DEVICES
AC-19:text:<del>The organization:</del>
AC-19 a:text:<del>The organization: </del>Establish<del>es</del> usage restrictions, configuration requirements, connection requirements, and implementation guidance for organization-controlled mobile devices;<del> and</del>
AC-19 b:text:<del>The organization: </del>Authorize<del>s</del> the connection of mobile devices to organizational <del>information </del>systems<del>.</del><ins>; and</ins>
AC-19 c:text:<ins>Protect and control mobile devices when outside of controlled areas.</ins>
AC-19:supplement:A mobile device is a computing device that<del>:</del> <del>(i) </del>has a small form factor such that it can easily be carried by a single individual; <del>(</del>i<del>i) i</del>s designed to operate without a physical connection<del> (e.g., wirelessly transmit or receive information)</del>; <del>(iii) </del>possesses local, non-removable or removable data storage; and <del>(</del>i<del>v) i</del>ncludes a self-contained power source. Mobile device<del>s</del> <ins>functionality </ins>may also include voice communication capabilities, on-board sensors that allow the device to capture information, and/or built-in features for synchronizing local data with remote locations. Examples include smart phones, E-readers, and tablets. Mobile devices are typically associated with a single individual and the device is usually <del>i</del>n<del> clos</del>e<del> p</del><ins>a</ins>r<del>oximity</del> t<del>o t</del>he individual; however, the degree of proximity can vary depending upon on the form factor and size of the device. The processing, storage, and transmission capability of the mobile device may be comparable to or merely a subset of <ins>notebook/</ins>desktop systems, depending upon the nature and intended purpose of the device. <ins>Controlled areas are areas or spaces for which organizations provide sufficient physical or procedural safeguards to meet the requirements established for protecting information and systems. </ins>Due to the large variety of mobile devices with different <del>te</del>ch<del>nic</del>a<del>l cha</del>racteristics and capabilities, organizational restrictions may vary for the different classes/types of such devices. Usage restrictions and specific implementation guidance for mobile devices include, for example, configuration management, device identification and authentication, implementation of mandatory protective software<del> (e.g.</del>, <del>maliciou</del>s<del> </del>c<del>ode detection, firew</del>a<del>ll), sca</del>nning devices for malicious code, updating virus protection software, scanning for critical software updates and patches, conducting primary operating system (and possibly other resident software) integrity checks, and disabling unnecessary hardware<del> (e</del>.<ins> Usa</ins>g<del>.,</del><ins>e</ins> <del>w</del><ins>restr</ins>i<ins>ctions and autho</ins>r<ins>ization to conn</ins>e<ins>ct may vary among organizationa</ins>l<del>e</del><ins> </ins>s<ins>y</ins>s<ins>tems. For example</ins>, <ins>the organ</ins>i<ins>zatio</ins>n<del>fr</del><ins> m</ins>a<ins>y autho</ins>r<ins>iz</ins>e<ins> the connection of mobile </ins>d<del>).</del><ins>evices</ins> <del>O</del><ins>to the o</ins>rganization<ins>al network and impo</ins>s<ins>e</ins> a<del>r</del><ins> s</ins>e<ins>t</ins> <ins>of usage restri</ins>c<ins>tions while </ins>a<ins> system owner may withhold a</ins>ut<ins>hor</ins>i<ins>zati</ins>on<ins> for mobil</ins>e<ins> </ins>d<ins>evice</ins> <ins>connec</ins>t<del>h</del><ins>ion to specific </ins>a<ins>pplica</ins>t<ins>ions</ins> <ins>or may impose addi</ins>t<ins>ional usage restrictions before allowing mobile device connections to a system. T</ins>he need to provide adequate security for mobile devices goes beyond the requirements in this control. AC-20:title:USE OF EXTERNAL <del>INFORMATION </del>SYSTEMS
AC-20:text:<del>The organization e</del><ins>E</ins>stablish<del>es</del> terms and conditions, consistent with any trust relationships established with other organizations owning, operating, and/or maintaining external<del> information</del> systems, allowing authorized individuals to:
AC-20 a:text:<del>The organization e</del><ins>E</ins>stablish<del>es</del> terms and conditions, consistent with any trust relationships established with other organizations owning, operating, and/or maintaining external <del>information </del>systems, allowing authorized individuals to: Access the <del>information </del>system from external<del> information</del> systems; and
AC-20 b:text:<del>The organization e</del><ins>E</ins>stablish<del>es</del> terms and conditions, consistent with any trust relationships established with other organizations owning, operating, and/or maintaining external <del>information </del>systems, allowing authorized individuals to: Process, store, or transmit organization-controlled information using external<del> information</del> systems.
AC-20:supplement:External <del>information </del>systems are <del>information </del>systems or components of <del>information </del>systems that are outside of the authorization boundary established by organizations and for which organizations typically have no direct supervision and authority over the application of required security controls or the assessment of control effectiveness. External <del>information </del>systems include, for example<del>:</del><ins>,</ins> <del>(i) </del>personally owned <del>information </del>systems<del>/devices (e.g.</del>, <del>notebook </del>comp<del>uters, smart ph</del>one<del>s, </del><ins>n</ins>t<del>ablet</del>s, <del>pers</del>o<del>nal</del><ins>r</ins> d<ins>ev</ins>i<del>gital a</del><ins>ce</ins>s<del>sistants)</del>; <del>(ii) </del>privately owned computing and communications devices <del>res</del>i<del>de</del>n<del>t</del> <del>in </del>commercial or public facilities<del> (e.g., hotels, train stations, convention centers, shopping malls, or airports)</del>; <del>(iii) information </del>systems owned or controlled by nonfederal <del>g</del>o<del>ve</del>r<del>nmental or</del>ganizations; and <del>(iv) </del>federal <del>information </del>systems that are not owned by, operated by, or under the direct supervision and authority of <ins>the </ins>organization<del>s</del>. This <ins>in</ins>c<ins>ludes systems managed by c</ins>ontr<ins>act</ins>o<del>l</del><ins>rs,</ins> <ins>systems owned by other feder</ins>al<ins> agencie</ins>s<ins>, and systems </ins>o<ins>wned</ins> <ins>by other org</ins>a<ins>nizations within the same agency. This control a</ins>ddresses the use of external <del>information </del>systems for the processing, storage, or transmission of organizational information, including, for example, accessing cloud services <del>(e.g., in</del>fr<del>astructure as a service, platf</del>o<del>r</del>m <del>as a service, </del>or<del> software as a service) from or</del>ganizational <del>information </del>systems. For some external <del>information </del>systems (i.e., <del>information </del>systems operated by other federal agencies<del>,</del> <del>i</del><ins>a</ins>n<del>clu</del>d<del>ing</del> organizations subordinate to those agencies), the trust relationships that have been established between those organizations and the originating organization may be such, that no explicit terms and conditions are required. <del>Information s</del><ins>S</ins>ystems within these organizations <del>would</del><ins>may</ins> not be considered external. These situations occur when, for example, there are pre-existing sharing<del>/</del><ins> and </ins>trust agreements (either implicit or explicit) established between federal agencies or organizations subordinate to those agencies, or when such trust agreements are specified by applicable laws, Executive Orders, directives, <ins>regulati</ins>o<ins>ns, o</ins>r policies. Authorized individuals include, for example, organizational personnel, contractors, or other individuals with authorized access to organizational <del>information </del>systems and over which organizations have the authority to impose <ins>specific </ins>rules of behavior with regard to system access. Restrictions that organizations impose on authorized individuals need not be uniform, as those restrictions may vary depending <del>up</del>on the trust relationships between organizations. Therefore, organizations may choose to impose different security restrictions on contractors than on state, local, or tribal governments. This control does not apply to <del>th</del>e<del> use of e</del>xternal <del>information </del>systems <ins>used </ins>to access public interfaces to organizational <del>information </del>systems<del> (e</del>.<del>g.,</del> <del>individuals accessing federal information through www.usa.gov). </del>Organizations establish <ins>specific </ins>terms and conditions for the use of external <del>information </del>systems in accordance with organizational security policies and procedures. Terms and conditions address as a minimum: t<ins>he specific t</ins>ypes of applications that can be accessed on organizational <del>information </del>systems from external <del>information </del>systems; and the highest security category of information that can be processed, stored, or transmitted on external <del>information </del>systems. If t<ins>h</ins>e<ins> te</ins>rms and conditions with the owners of external <del>information </del>systems cannot be established, organizations may impose restrictions on organizational personnel using those external systems. Related <del>c</del><ins>C</ins>ontrols: AC-<ins>2, AC-</ins>3, AC-17, AC-19, CA-3, PL-<ins>2, PL-</ins>4, SA-9<ins>, SC-7</ins>.

AC-23:title:DATA MINING PROTECTION
AC-23:text:<del>The organization e</del><ins>E</ins>mploy<del>s</del> [Assignment: organization-defined data mining prevention and detection techniques] for [Assignment: organization-defined data storage objects] to <del>a</del>de<del>qua</del>te<del>ly dete</del>ct and protect against<ins> unauthorized</ins> data mining.
AC-23:supplement:Data storage objects include, for example, databases, database records, and database fields. Data mining prevention and detection techniques include, for example<del>:</del><ins>,</ins> <del>(i) </del>limiting the types of responses provided to database queries; <del>(ii) </del>limiting the number<del>/</del><ins> and the </ins>frequency of database queries to increase the work factor needed to determine the contents of such databases; and <del>(iii) </del>notifying organizational personnel when atypical database queries or accesses occur. This control focuses on the protection of organizational information from data mining while such information resides in organizational data stores. In contrast, AU-13 focuses on monitoring for organizational information that may have been mined or otherwise obtained from data stores and is now available as open source information residing on external sites, for example, through social networking or social media websites<ins>. Related Controls: None</ins>.

AC-24:title:ACCESS CONTROL DECISIONS
AC-24:text:<del>The organization e</del><ins>E</ins>stablish<del>es</del> procedures to ensure [Assignment: organization-defined access control decisions] are applied to each access request prior to access enforcement.
AC-24:supplement:Access control decisions (also known as authorization decisions) occur when authorization information is applied to specific accesses. In contrast, access enforcement occurs when <del>information </del>systems enforce access control decisions. While it is very common to have access control decisions and access enforcement implemented by the same entity, it is not required and it is not always an optimal implementation choice. For some architectures and distributed <del>information </del>systems, different entities may perform access control decisions and access enforcement<ins>. Related Controls: AC-2, AC-3</ins>.
AC-24 (1):title:ACCESS CONTROL DECISIONS | TRANSMIT ACCESS AUTHORIZATION INFORMATION
AC-24 (1):text:T<del>he info</del>r<del>m</del>a<del>tio</del>n<del> </del>s<del>yste</del>m<del> transm</del>it<del>s</del> [Assignment: organization-defined access authorization information] using [Assignment: organization-defined security safeguards] to [Assignment: organization-defined<del> information</del> systems] that enforce access control decisions.
AC-24 (1):supplement:In distributed <del>information </del>systems, authorization processes and access control decisions may occur in separate parts of the systems. In such instances, authorization information is transmitted securely so timely access control decisions can be enforced at the appropriate locations. To support the access control decisions, it may be necessary to transmit as part of the access authorization information, supporting security attributes. This is <del>du</del><ins>b</ins>e<del> to the fa</del>c<del>t th</del>a<del>t</del><ins>use</ins> in distributed <del>information </del>systems, there are various access control decisions that need to be made and different entities <del>(e.g., services) </del>make these decisions in a serial fashion, each requiring s<del>om</del>e<del> se</del>curity attributes to make the decisions. Protecting access authorization information <del>(i.</del>e<del>., access co</del>n<del>trol deci</del>s<del>ions) ens</del>ures that such information cannot be altered, spoofed, or <del>otherwise </del>compromised during transmission<ins>. Related Controls: None</ins>.
AC-24 (2):title:ACCESS CONTROL DECISIONS | NO USER OR PROCESS IDENTITY
AC-24 (2):text:<del>The i</del><ins>E</ins>nfor<del>mation system enfor</del>ce<del>s</del> access control decisions based on [Assignment: organization-defined security attributes] that do not include the identity of the user or process acting on behalf of the user.
AC-24 (2):supplement:In certain situations, it is important that access control decisions can be made without information regarding the identity of the users issuing the requests. These are generally instances where preserving individual privacy is of paramount importance. In other situations, user identification information is simply not needed for access control decisions and, especially in the case of distributed <del>information </del>systems, transmitting such information with the needed degree of assurance may be very expensive or difficult to accomplish<ins>. Related Controls: None</ins>.

AC-25:title:REFERENCE MONITOR
AC-25:text:<del>The infor</del><ins>I</ins>m<del>ation system im</del>plement<del>s</del> a reference monitor for [Assignment: organization-defined access control policies] that is tamperproof, always invoked, and small enough to be subject to analysis and testing, the completeness of which can be assured.
AC-25:supplement:Information is represented internally within <del>information </del>systems using abstractions known as data structures. Internal data structures can represent different types of entities, both active and passive. Active entities, also known as subjects, are <del>typic</del>a<del>lly a</del>ssociated with individuals, devices, or processes acting on behalf of individuals. Passive entities, also known as objects, are typically associated with data structures such as records, buffers, tables, files, inter-process pipes, and communications ports. Reference monitors <del>typically </del>enforce mandatory access control policies<del>-</del><ins>, </ins>a type of access control that restricts access to objects based on the identity of subjects or groups to which the subjects belong. The access controls are mandatory because subjects with certain privileges (i.e., access permissions) are restricted from passing those privileges on to any other subjects, either directly or indirectly<del>-</del><ins>—</ins>that is, the <del>information </del>system strictly enforces the access control policy based on the rule set established by the policy. The tamperproof property of the reference monitor prevents adversaries from compromising the functioning of the mechanism. The always invoked property prevents adversaries from bypassing the mechanism and hence violating the security policy. The smallness property helps to ensure the completeness in the analysis and testing of the mechanism to detect weaknesses or deficiencies (i.e., latent flaws) that would prevent the enforcement of the security policy. Related <del>c</del><ins>C</ins>ontrols: AC-3, AC-16, SC-3, SC-<ins>11, SC-</ins>39<ins>, SI-13</ins>.
AC-25:references:None

AC-25:mod:<del>Not Selected</del>

AP-1:title:<del>AUTHORITY TO COLLECT</del>
AP-1:text:<del>The organization determines and documents the legal authority that permits the collection, use, maintenance, and sharing of personally identifiable information (PII), either generally or in support of a specific program or information system need.</del>
AP-1:supplement:<del>Before collecting PII, the organization determines whether the contemplated collection of PII is legally authorized. Program officials consult with the Senior Agency Official for Privacy (SAOP)/Chief Privacy Officer (CPO) and legal counsel regarding the authority of any program or activity to collect PII. The authority to collect PII is documented in the System of Records Notice (SORN) and/or Privacy Impact Assessment (PIA) or other applicable documentation such as Privacy Act Statements or Computer Matching Agreements. Related controls: AR-2, DM-1, TR-1, TR-2.</del>
AP-1:references:<del>The Privacy Act of 1974, 5 U.S.C. § 552a (e); Section 208(c), E-Government Act of 2002 (P.L. 107-347); OMB Circular A-130, Appendix I</del>
AP-2:title:<del>PURPOSE SPECIFICATION</del>
AP-2:text:<del>The organization describes the purpose(s) for which personally identifiable information (PII) is collected, used, maintained, and shared in its privacy notices.</del>
AP-2:supplement:<del>Often, statutory language expressly authorizes specific collections and uses of PII. When statutory language is written broadly and thus subject to interpretation, organizations ensure, in consultation with the Senior Agency Official for Privacy (SAOP)/Chief Privacy Officer (CPO) and legal counsel, that there is a close nexus between the general authorization and any specific collection of PII. Once the specific purposes have been identified, the purposes are clearly described in the related privacy compliance documentation, including but not limited to Privacy Impact Assessments (PIAs), System of Records Notices (SORNs), and Privacy Act Statements provided at the time of collection (e.g., on forms organizations use to collect PII). Further, in order to avoid unauthorized collections or uses of PII, personnel who handle PII receive training on the organizational authorities for collecting PII, authorized uses of PII, and on the contents of the notice. Related controls: AR-2, AR-4, AR-5, DM-1, DM-2, TR-1, TR-2, UL-1, UL-2.</del>
AP-2:references:<del>The Privacy Act of 1974, 5 U.S.C. § 552a (e)(3)(A)-(B); Sections 208(b), (c), E-Government Act of 2002 (P.L. 107-347)</del>
AR-1:title:<del>GOVERNANCE AND PRIVACY PROGRAM</del>
AR-1:text:<del>The organization:</del>
AR-1 a:text:<del>The organization: Appoints a Senior Agency Official for Privacy (SAOP)/Chief Privacy Officer (CPO) accountable for developing, implementing, and maintaining an organization-wide governance and privacy program to ensure compliance with all applicable laws and regulations regarding the collection, use, maintenance, sharing, and disposal of personally identifiable information (PII) by programs and information systems;</del>
AR-1 b:text:<del>The organization: Monitors federal privacy laws and policy for changes that affect the privacy program;</del>
AR-1 c:text:<del>The organization: Allocates [Assignment: organization-defined allocation of budget and staffing] sufficient resources to implement and operate the organization-wide privacy program;</del>
AR-1 d:text:<del>The organization: Develops a strategic organizational privacy plan for implementing applicable privacy controls, policies, and procedures;</del>
AR-1 e:text:<del>The organization: Develops, disseminates, and implements operational privacy policies and procedures that govern the appropriate privacy and security controls for programs, information systems, or technologies involving PII; and</del>
AR-1 f:text:<del>The organization: Updates privacy plan, policies, and procedures [Assignment: organization-defined frequency, at least biennially].</del>
AR-1:supplement:<del>The development and implementation of a comprehensive governance and privacy program demonstrates organizational accountability for and commitment to the protection of individual privacy. Accountability begins with the appointment of an SAOP/CPO with the authority, mission, resources, and responsibility to develop and implement a multifaceted privacy program. The SAOP/CPO, in consultation with legal counsel, information security officials, and others as appropriate: (i) ensures the development, implementation, and enforcement of privacy policies and procedures; (ii) defines roles and responsibilities for protecting PII; (iii) determines the level of information sensitivity with regard to PII holdings; (iv) identifies the laws, regulations, and internal policies that apply to the PII; (v) monitors privacy best practices; and (vi) monitors/audits compliance with identified privacy controls. To further accountability, the SAOP/CPO develops privacy plans to document the privacy requirements of organizations and the privacy and security controls in place or planned for meeting those requirements. The plan serves as evidence of organizational privacy operations and supports resource requests by the SAOP/CPO. A single plan or multiple plans may be necessary depending upon the organizational structures, requirements, and resources, and the plan(s) may vary in comprehensiveness. For example, a one-page privacy plan may cover privacy policies, documentation, and controls already in place, such as Privacy Impact Assessments (PIA) and System of Records Notices (SORN). A comprehensive plan may include a baseline of privacy controls selected from this appendix and include: (i) processes for conducting privacy risk assessments; (ii) templates and guidance for completing PIAs and SORNs; (iii) privacy training and awareness requirements; (iv) requirements for contractors processing PII; (v) plans for eliminating unnecessary PII holdings; and (vi) a framework for measuring annual performance goals and objectives for implementing identified privacy controls.</del>
AR-1:references:<del>The Privacy Act of 1974, 5 U.S.C. § 552a; E-Government Act of 2002 (P.L. 107-347); Federal Information Security Management Act (FISMA) of 2002, 44 U.S.C. § 3541; OMB Memoranda 03-22, 05-08, 07-16; OMB Circular A-130; Federal Enterprise Architecture Security and Privacy Profile</del>
AR-2:title:<del>PRIVACY IMPACT AND RISK ASSESSMENT</del>
AR-2:text:<del>The organization:</del>
AR-2 a:text:<del>The organization: Documents and implements a privacy risk management process that assesses privacy risk to individuals resulting from the collection, sharing, storing, transmitting, use, and disposal of personally identifiable information (PII); and</del>
AR-2 b:text:<del>The organization: Conducts Privacy Impact Assessments (PIAs) for information systems, programs, or other activities that pose a privacy risk in accordance with applicable law, OMB policy, or any existing organizational policies and procedures.</del>
AR-2:supplement:<del>Organizational privacy risk management processes operate across the life cycles of all mission/business processes that collect, use, maintain, share, or dispose of PII. The tools and processes for managing risk are specific to organizational missions and resources. They include, but are not limited to, the conduct of PIAs. The PIA is both a process and the document that is the outcome of that process. OMB Memorandum 03-22 provides guidance to organizations for implementing the privacy provisions of the E-Government Act of 2002, including guidance on when PIAs are required for information systems. Some organizations may be required by law or policy to extend the PIA requirement to other activities involving PII or otherwise impacting privacy (e.g., programs, projects, or regulations). PIAs are conducted to identify privacy risks and identify methods to mitigate those risks. PIAs are also conducted to ensure that programs or information systems comply with legal, regulatory, and policy requirements. PIAs also serve as notice to the public of privacy practices. PIAs are performed before developing or procuring information systems, or initiating programs or projects, that collect, use, maintain, or share PII and are updated when changes create new privacy risks.</del>
AR-2:references:<del>Section 208, E-Government Act of 2002 (P.L. 107-347); Federal Information Security Management Act (FISMA) of 2002, 44 U.S.C. § 3541; OMB Memoranda 03-22, 05-08, 10-23</del>
AR-3:title:<del>PRIVACY REQUIREMENTS FOR CONTRACTORS AND SERVICE PROVIDERS</del>
AR-3:text:<del>The organization:</del>
AR-3 a:text:<del>The organization: Establishes privacy roles, responsibilities, and access requirements for contractors and service providers; and</del>
AR-3 b:text:<del>The organization: Includes privacy requirements in contracts and other acquisition-related documents.</del>
AR-3:supplement:<del>Contractors and service providers include, but are not limited to, information providers, information processors, and other organizations providing information system development, information technology services, and other outsourced applications. Organizations consult with legal counsel, the Senior Agency Official for Privacy (SAOP)/Chief Privacy Officer (CPO), and contracting officers about applicable laws, directives, policies, or regulations that may impact implementation of this control. Related control: AR-1, AR-5, SA-4.</del>
AR-3:references:<del>The Privacy Act of 1974, 5 U.S.C. § 552a(m); Federal Acquisition Regulation, 48 C.F.R. Part 24; OMB Circular A-130</del>
AR-4:title:<del>PRIVACY MONITORING AND AUDITING</del>
AR-4:text:<del>The organization monitors and audits privacy controls and internal privacy policy [Assignment: organization-defined frequency] to ensure effective implementation.</del>
AR-4:supplement:<del>To promote accountability, organizations identify and address gaps in privacy compliance, management, operational, and technical controls by conducting regular assessments (e.g., internal risk assessments). These assessments can be self-assessments or third-party audits that result in reports on compliance gaps identified in programs, projects, and information systems. In addition to auditing for effective implementation of all privacy controls identified in this appendix, organizations assess whether they: (i) implement a process to embed privacy considerations into the life cycle of personally identifiable information (PII), programs, information systems, mission/business processes, and technology; (ii) monitor for changes to applicable privacy laws, regulations, and policies; (iii) track programs, information systems, and applications that collect and maintain PII to ensure compliance; (iv) ensure that access to PII is only on a need-to-know basis; and (v) ensure that PII is being maintained and used only for the legally authorized purposes identified in the public notice(s). Organizations also: (i) implement technology to audit for the security, appropriate use, and loss of PII; (ii) perform reviews to ensure physical security of documents containing PII; (iii) assess contractor compliance with privacy requirements; and (iv) ensure that corrective actions identified as part of the assessment process are tracked and monitored until audit findings are corrected. The organization Senior Agency Official for Privacy (SAOP)/Chief Privacy Officer (CPO) coordinates monitoring and auditing efforts with information security officials and ensures that the results are provided to senior managers and oversight officials. Related controls: AR-6, AR-7, AU-1, AU-2, AU-3, AU-6, AU-12, CA-7, TR-1, UL-2.</del>
AR-4:references:<del>The Privacy Act of 1974, 5 U.S.C. § 552a; Federal Information Security Management Act (FISMA) of 2002, 44 U.S.C. § 3541; Section 208, E-Government Act of 2002 (P.L. 107-347); OMB Memoranda 03-22, 05-08, 06-16, 07-16; OMB Circular A-130</del>
AR-5:title:<del>PRIVACY AWARENESS AND TRAINING</del>
AR-5:text:<del>The organization:</del>
AR-5 a:text:<del>The organization: Develops, implements, and updates a comprehensive training and awareness strategy aimed at ensuring that personnel understand privacy responsibilities and procedures;</del>
AR-5 b:text:<del>The organization: Administers basic privacy training [Assignment: organization-defined frequency, at least annually] and targeted, role-based privacy training for personnel having responsibility for personally identifiable information (PII) or for activities that involve PII [Assignment: organization-defined frequency, at least annually]; and</del>
AR-5 c:text:<del>The organization: Ensures that personnel certify (manually or electronically) acceptance of responsibilities for privacy requirements [Assignment: organization-defined frequency, at least annually].</del>
AR-5:supplement:<del>Through implementation of a privacy training and awareness strategy, the organization promotes a culture of privacy. Privacy training and awareness programs typically focus on broad topics, such as responsibilities under the Privacy Act of 1974 and E-Government Act of 2002 and the consequences of failing to carry out those responsibilities, how to identify new privacy risks, how to mitigate privacy risks, and how and when to report privacy incidents. Privacy training may also target data collection and use requirements identified in public notices, such as Privacy Impact Assessments (PIAs) or System of Records Notices (SORNs) for a program or information system. Specific training methods may include: (i) mandatory annual privacy awareness training; (ii) targeted, role-based training; (iii) internal privacy program websites; (iv) manuals, guides, and handbooks; (v) slide presentations; (vi) events (e.g., privacy awareness week, privacy clean-up day); (vii) posters and brochures; and (viii) email messages to all employees and contractors. Organizations update training based on changing statutory, regulatory, mission, program, business process, and information system requirements, or on the results of compliance monitoring and auditing. Where appropriate, organizations may provide privacy training as part of existing information security training. Related controls: AR-3, AT-2, AT-3, TR-1.</del>
AR-5:references:<del>The Privacy Act of 1974, 5 U.S.C. § 552a(e); Section 208, E-Government Act of 2002 (P.L. 107-347); OMB Memoranda 03-22, 07-16</del>
AR-6:title:<del>PRIVACY REPORTING</del>
AR-6:text:<del>The organization develops, disseminates, and updates reports to the Office of Management and Budget (OMB), Congress, and other oversight bodies, as appropriate, to demonstrate accountability with specific statutory and regulatory privacy program mandates, and to senior management and other personnel with responsibility for monitoring privacy program progress and compliance.</del>
AR-6:supplement:<del>Through internal and external privacy reporting, organizations promote accountability and transparency in organizational privacy operations. Reporting also helps organizations to determine progress in meeting privacy compliance requirements and privacy controls, compare performance across the federal government, identify vulnerabilities and gaps in policy and implementation, and identify success models. Types of privacy reports include: (i) annual Senior Agency Official for Privacy (SAOP) reports to OMB; (ii) reports to Congress required by the Implementing Regulations of the 9/11 Commission Act; and (iii) other public reports required by specific statutory mandates or internal policies of organizations. The organization Senior Agency Official for Privacy (SAOP)/Chief Privacy Officer (CPO) consults with legal counsel, where appropriate, to ensure that organizations meet all applicable privacy reporting requirements.</del>
AR-6:references:<del>The Privacy Act of 1974, 5 U.S.C. § 552a; Section 208, E-Government Act of 2002 (P.L. 107-347); Federal Information Security Management Act (FISMA) of 2002, 44 U.S.C. § 3541; Section 803, 9/11 Commission Act, 42 U.S.C. § 2000ee-1; Section 804, 9/11 Commission Act, 42 U.S.C. § 2000ee-3; Section 522, Consolidated Appropriations Act of 2005 (P.L. 108-447); OMB Memoranda 03-22; OMB Circular A-130</del>
AR-7:title:<del>PRIVACY-ENHANCED SYSTEM DESIGN AND DEVELOPMENT</del>
AR-7:text:<del>The organization designs information systems to support privacy by automating privacy controls.</del>
AR-7:supplement:<del>To the extent feasible, when designing organizational information systems, organizations employ technologies and system capabilities that automate privacy controls on the collection, use, retention, and disclosure of personally identifiable information (PII). By building privacy controls into system design and development, organizations mitigate privacy risks to PII, thereby reducing the likelihood of information system breaches and other privacy-related incidents. Organizations also conduct periodic reviews of systems to determine the need for updates to maintain compliance with the Privacy Act and the organization's privacy policy. Regardless of whether automated privacy controls are employed, organizations regularly monitor information system use and sharing of PII to ensure that the use/sharing is consistent with the authorized purposes identified in the Privacy Act and/or in the public notice of organizations, or in a manner compatible with those purposes. Related controls: AC-6, AR-4, AR-5, DM-2, TR-1.</del>
AR-7:references:<del>The Privacy Act of 1974, 5 U.S.C. § 552a(e)(10); Sections 208(b) and(c), E-Government Act of 2002 (P.L. 107-347); OMB Memorandum 03-22</del>
AR-8:title:<del>ACCOUNTING OF DISCLOSURES</del>
AR-8:text:<del>The organization:</del>
AR-8 a:text:<del>The organization: Keeps an accurate accounting of disclosures of information held in each system of records under its control, including:</del>
AR-8 a 1:text:<del>The organization: Keeps an accurate accounting of disclosures of information held in each system of records under its control, including: Date, nature, and purpose of each disclosure of a record; and</del>
AR-8 a 2:text:<del>The organization: Keeps an accurate accounting of disclosures of information held in each system of records under its control, including: Name and address of the person or agency to which the disclosure was made;</del>
AR-8 b:text:<del>The organization: Retains the accounting of disclosures for the life of the record or five years after the disclosure is made, whichever is longer; and</del>
AR-8 c:text:<del>The organization: Makes the accounting of disclosures available to the person named in the record upon request.</del>
AR-8:supplement:<del>The Senior Agency Official for Privacy (SAOP)/Chief Privacy Officer (CPO) periodically consults with managers of organization systems of record to ensure that the required accountings of disclosures of records are being properly maintained and provided to persons named in those records consistent with the dictates of the Privacy Act. Organizations are not required to keep an accounting of disclosures when the disclosures are made to individuals with a need to know, are made pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, or are made to a law enforcement agency pursuant to 5 U.S.C. § 552a(c)(3). Heads of agencies can promulgate rules to exempt certain systems of records from the requirement to provide the accounting of disclosures to individuals. Related control: IP-2.</del>
AR-8:references:<del>The Privacy Act of 1974, 5 U.S.C. § 552a (c)(1), (c)(3), (j), (k)</del>

AT-2:supplement:Organizations determine the <del>appropriate </del>content of security a<ins>nd privacy a</ins>wareness training and security a<ins>nd privacy a</ins>wareness techniques based on the specific organizational requirements and the <del>information </del>systems to which personnel have authorized access. The content includes a<ins>n</ins> <del>basic </del>understanding of the need for information security and <del>use</del><ins>p</ins>r<ins>ivacy</ins> a<ins>nd a</ins>ctions <ins>by users </ins>to maintain security and <ins>privacy and </ins>to respond to suspected security <ins>and pr</ins>i<ins>vacy i</ins>ncidents. Such training may be satisfied by one or more short ad hoc sessions and include topical information on recent attack schemes, changes to organizational security and privacy policies, revised security and privacy expectations, and/or a subset of topics from the initial training. AT-2 (1):title:<del>SECURITY </del>AWARENESS<ins> TRAINING</ins> | PRACTICAL EXERCISES
AT-2 (1):text:<del>The orga</del><ins>I</ins>n<del>ization in</del>clude<del>s</del> practical exercises in <del>security </del>awareness training that simulate <del>a</del><ins>se</ins>c<del>t</del>u<ins>rity </ins>a<del>l</del><ins>nd</ins> <ins>priva</ins>cy<del>ber</del> <del>atta</del><ins>in</ins>c<del>k</del><ins>ident</ins>s.
AT-2 (1):supplement:Practical exercises may include, for example, no-notice social engineering attempts to collect information, gain unauthorized access, or simulate the adverse impact of opening malicious email attachments or invoking, via spear phishing attacks, malicious web links. <del>R</del><ins>Privacy-r</ins>elated <ins>pra</ins>c<ins>tical exercises may include, for example, practice modules with quizzes on handling personally identifiable information and affected individuals in various scenarios. Related C</ins>ontrols: CA-2, CA-7, CP-4, IR-3.
AT-2 (2):title:<del>SECURITY </del>AWARENESS<ins> TRAINING</ins> | INSIDER THREAT
AT-2 (2):text:<del>The orga</del><ins>I</ins>n<del>ization in</del>clude<del>s security</del> awareness training on recognizing and reporting potential indicators of insider threat.
AT-2 (2):supplement:Potential indicators and possible precursors of insider threat can include behaviors such as inordinate, long-term job dissatisfaction, attempts to gain access to information not required for job performance, unexplained access to financial resources, bullying or sexual harassment of fellow employees, workplace violence, and other serious violations of organizational policies, procedures, directives, rules, or practices. Security a<ins>nd privacy a</ins>wareness training includes how to communicate <ins>th</ins>e<ins> concerns of e</ins>mployee<ins>s</ins> and management <del>conce</del>r<del>ns r</del>egarding potential indicators of insider threat through <del>appr</del>o<del>p</del>r<del>iate or</del>ganizational channels in accordance with established <del>organizational </del>policies and procedures. Related <del>c</del><ins>C</ins>ontrols: P<del>L-4, P</del>M-12<del>, PS-3, PS-6</del>.
AT-2 (3):title:<ins>AWARENESS TRAINING | SOCIAL ENGINEERING AND MINING</ins>
AT-2 (3):text:<ins>Include awareness training on recognizing and reporting potential and actual instances of social engineering and social mining.</ins>
AT-2 (3):supplement:<ins>Social engineering is an attempt to trick someone into revealing information or taking an action that can be used to attack or compromise systems. Examples of social engineering include phishing, pretexting, baiting, quid pro quo, and tailgaiting. Social mining is an attempt, in a social setting, to gather information about the organization that may support future attacks. Security and privacy awareness training includes information on how to communicate concerns of employees and management regarding potential and actual instances of social engineering and mining through organizational channels based on established policies and procedures. Related Controls: None.</ins>

AT-3 (3):supplement:Practical exercises <ins>for security </ins>may include, for example, security training for software developers that includes simulated cyber<del> </del><ins>-</ins>attacks exploiting common software vulnerabilities<del> (e.g.</del>, <del>buffer </del>o<del>ve</del>r<del>flows),</del> <del>or </del>spear/whale phishing attacks targeted at senior leaders/executives. <del>These types of p</del><ins>P</ins>ractical exercises <del>hel</del><ins>for </ins>p<ins>rivacy</ins> <ins>may inclu</ins>de<del>vel</del><ins>, f</ins>o<del>pe</del>r<del>s</del> <del>b</del>e<del>tt</del><ins>xampl</ins>e<ins>, p</ins>r<ins>actice</ins> <del>un</del><ins>mo</ins>d<ins>ul</ins>e<del>r</del>s<del>tand</del> <ins>wi</ins>th<del>e</del> <ins>quizz</ins>e<del>ffect</del>s o<del>f</del><ins>n</ins> <del>suc</del>h<del> vu</del><ins>and</ins>l<ins>i</ins>n<ins>g p</ins>er<ins>son</ins>a<del>bi</del>l<ins>ly </ins>i<ins>den</ins>ti<ins>fiabl</ins>e<del>s</del> <ins>inform</ins>a<ins>tio</ins>n<del>d</del> <ins>in v</ins>a<del>pp</del>r<del>ec</del>i<del>ate</del><ins>ous</ins> <del>th</del><ins>sc</ins>e<ins>narios,</ins> <ins>a</ins>n<del>ee</del>d <del>f</del><ins>m</ins>o<del>r</del><ins>del</ins> s<del>e</del>c<del>u</del><ins>ena</ins>ri<del>ty</del><ins>os</ins> <ins>on </ins>co<ins>n</ins>d<ins>uct</ins>ing <del>s</del><ins>privacy impac</ins>t<ins> </ins>a<ins>ssessme</ins>n<del>dard</del><ins>t</ins>s<ins>.</ins> <ins>Rel</ins>a<del>n</del><ins>te</ins>d <del>p</del><ins>Cont</ins>ro<del>ce</del><ins>l</ins>s<del>s</del><ins>: Non</ins>e<del>s</del>.
AT-3 (4):title:ROLE-BASED <del>SECURITY </del>TRAINING | SUSPICIOUS COMMUNICATIONS AND ANOMALOUS SYSTEM BEHAVIOR
AT-3 (4):text:<del>The o</del><ins>P</ins>r<del>ganizati</del>o<del>n pro</del>vide<del>s</del> training to <del>its </del>personnel on [Assignment: organization-defined indicators of malicious code] to recognize suspicious communications and anomalous behavior in organizational<del> information</del> systems.
AT-3 (4):supplement:A well-trained workforce provides another organizational safeguard that can be employed as part of a defense-in-depth strategy to protect organizations against malicious code coming in to organizations via email or the web applications. Personnel are trained to look for indications of potentially suspicious email <del>(</del><ins>for </ins>e<del>.g.</del><ins>xample</ins>, receiving an unexpected email, receiving an email containing strange or poor grammar, or receiving an email from an unfamiliar sender but who appears to be from a known sponsor or contractor<del>)</del>. Personnel are also trained on how to respond to su<del>ch </del>s<del>us</del>picious email or web communications<del> (e</del>.<del>g.,</del> <del>not opening attachments, not clicking on embedded web links, and checking the source of email addresses). </del>For this process to work effectively, <del>all </del>organizational personnel are trained and made aware of what constitutes suspicious communications. Training personnel on how to recognize anomalous behaviors in organizational <del>information </del>systems can potentially provide early warning for the presence of malicious code. Recognition of such anomalous behavior by organizational personnel can supplement automated malicious code detection and protection tools and systems employed by organizations<ins>. Related Controls: None</ins>.
AT-3 (5):title:<ins>ROLE-BASED TRAINING | PERSONALLY IDENTIFIABLE INFORMATION PROCESSING</ins>
AT-3 (5):text:<ins>Provide personnel who process personally identifiable information with initial and [Assignment: organization-defined frequency] training on:</ins>
AT-3 (5) (a):text:<ins>Provide personnel who process personally identifiable information with initial and [Assignment: organization-defined frequency] training on: Organizational authority for collecting personally identifiable information;</ins>
AT-3 (5) (b):text:<ins>Provide personnel who process personally identifiable information with initial and [Assignment: organization-defined frequency] training on: Authorized uses of personally identifiable information;</ins>
AT-3 (5) (c):text:<ins>Provide personnel who process personally identifiable information with initial and [Assignment: organization-defined frequency] training on: Content of System of Records Notices;</ins>
AT-3 (5) (d):text:<ins>Provide personnel who process personally identifiable information with initial and [Assignment: organization-defined frequency] training on: Authorized sharing of personally identifiable information with external parties; and</ins>
AT-3 (5) (e):text:<ins>Provide personnel who process personally identifiable information with initial and [Assignment: organization-defined frequency] training on: Consequences of unauthorized use or sharing of personally identifiable information.</ins>
AT-3 (5):supplement:<ins>Role-based training on handling personally identifiable information helps prevent unauthorized collections or uses of personally identifiable information. Related Controls: PA-3, PA-4.</ins>

AU-2:title:AUDIT EVENTS
AU-2:text:<del>The organization:</del>
AU-2 a:text:<del>Th</del><ins>V</ins>e<del> o</del>r<del>gan</del>i<del>zation:</del><ins>fy</ins> <del>De</del>t<del>ermines t</del>hat the <del>information </del>system <del>is </del>ca<del>pable</del><ins>n</ins> <del>of </del>audit<del>ing</del> the following event<ins> type</ins>s: [Assignment: organization-defined auditable event<ins> type</ins>s];
AU-2 b:text:<del>The organization: </del>Coordinate<del>s</del> the security audit function with other organizational entities requiring audit-related information to enhance mutual support and to help guide the selection of auditable event<ins> type</ins>s;
AU-2 c:text:<del>The organization: </del>Provide<del>s</del> a rationale for why the auditable event<ins> type</ins>s are deemed to be adequate to support after-the-fact investigations of securit<ins>y and privac</ins>y incidents; and
AU-2 d:text:<del>Th</del><ins>Sp</ins>e<del> organ</del><ins>c</ins>i<del>zation:</del><ins>fy</ins> <del>De</del>t<del>ermines t</del>hat the following event<ins> type</ins>s are to be audited within the <del>information </del>system: [Assignment: organization-defined audited events (the subset of the auditable events defined in AU-2 a<del>.</del>) along with the frequency of (or situation requiring) auditing for each identified event].
AU-2:supplement:An event is any observable occurrence in an organizational <del>information </del>system. Organizations identify audit event<ins> type</ins>s as those events which are significant and relevant to the security of <del>information </del>systems and the environments in which those systems operate <del>in order </del>to meet specific and ongoing audit needs. Audit event<ins> type</ins>s can include, for example, password changes<del>,</del><ins>;</ins> failed logons<del>,</del> or failed accesses related to <del>information </del>systems<ins>; security attribute changes</ins>, administrative privilege usage, PIV credential usage, <del>o</del><ins>que</ins>r<ins>y</ins> <del>third-</del>par<ins>ame</ins>t<del>y</del><ins>ers,</ins> <ins>or external </ins>credential usage. In determining the set of auditable event<ins> type</ins>s, organizations consider the auditing appropriate for each of the security controls to be implemented. To balance auditing requirements with other <del>information </del>system needs, this control also requires identifying that subset of auditable event<ins> type</ins>s that are audited at a given point in time. For example, organizations may determine that <del>information </del>systems must have the capability to log every file access both successful and unsuccessful, but not activate that capability except for specific circumstances due to the potential burden on system performance. Auditing requirements, including the need for auditable events, may be referenced in other security <ins>and priva</ins>c<ins>y c</ins>ontrols and control enhancements<ins> for example, AC-2(4), AC-3(10), AC-6(9), AC-16(11), AC-17(1), CM-3</ins>.<ins>f,</ins> <ins>CM-5(1), IA-3(3.b), MA-4(1), MP-4(2), PA-4.d, PE-3, PM-22, RA-8, SC-7(9), SC-7(15), SI-3(8), SI-4(22), SI-7(8), and SI-10(1). </ins>Organizations also include auditable event<ins> type</ins>s that are required by applicable <del>federa</del>l<del> l</del>aws, Executive Orders, directives, policies, regulations, <del>and </del>standards<ins>, and guidelines</ins>. Audit records can be generated at various levels<del> of abstraction</del>, including at the packet level as information traverses the network. Selecting the appropriate level of a<del>bs</del><ins>udi</ins>t<del>ract</del>i<del>o</del>n<ins>g</ins> is a<ins>n</ins> <del>cr</del>i<ins>mpor</ins>t<del>ic</del>a<del>l</del><ins>nt</ins> aspect of an audit capability and can facilitate the identification of root causes to problems. Organizations consider in the definition of auditable event<ins> type</ins>s, the auditing necessary to cover related event<ins> type</ins>s such as the steps in distributed, transaction-based processes <del>(e.g., processes th</del>a<del>t are distributed across multiple orga</del>n<del>izations) an</del>d actions that occur in service-oriented architectures. Related <del>c</del><ins>C</ins>ontrols: AC-<ins>2, AC-3, AC-</ins>6, AC-<ins>7, AC-8, AC-</ins>1<ins>6, AC-1</ins>7, AU-3, AU-<ins>4, AU-5, AU-6, AU-7, AU-</ins>1<ins>1, AU-1</ins>2, <ins>C</ins>M<ins>-3, CM-5, CM-6, I</ins>A-<ins>3, MA-</ins>4, MP-<del>2</del><ins>4</ins>, <del>M</del>P<ins>A</ins>-4, <ins>PE-3, PM-22, RA-8, </ins>S<ins>C-7, SC-18, S</ins>I-<ins>3, SI-</ins>4<ins>, SI-7, SI-10, SI-11</ins>.

AU-2 (3):supplement:Over time, the events that organizations believe should be audited may change. Reviewing and updating the set of audited events periodically is necessary to ensure that the current set is still necessary and sufficient.<ins> Related Controls: None.</ins>

AU-3:title:CONTENT OF AUDIT RECORDS
AU-3:text:The <del>information </del>system generates audit records containing information that establishes what type of event occurred, when the event occurred, where the event occurred, the source of the event, the outcome of the event, and the identity of any individuals or subjects associated with the event.
AU-3:supplement:Audit record content that may be necessary to satisfy the requirement of this control, includes, for example, time stamps, source and destination addresses, user<del>/</del><ins> or </ins>process identifiers, event descriptions, success/fail indications, filenames involved, and access control or flow control rules invoked. Event outcomes can include indicators of event success or failure and event-specific results<ins>,</ins> <del>(</del><ins>for </ins>e<del>.g.</del><ins>xample</ins>, the security <ins>and privacy </ins>state of the <del>information </del>system after the event occurred<del>)</del>. Related <del>c</del><ins>C</ins>ontrols: AU-2, AU-8, AU-12<ins>, AU-14, MA-4, SI-7</ins>, SI-11.
AU-3 (1):title:CONTENT OF AUDIT RECORDS | ADDITIONAL AUDIT INFORMATION
AU-3 (1):text:<del>Th</del><ins>G</ins>e<del> i</del>n<del>formation syst</del>e<del>m gene</del>rate<del>s</del> audit records containing the following additional information: [Assignment: organization-defined additional, more detailed information].
AU-3 (1):supplement:<ins>Implementation of this control enhancement is dependent on system functionality to configure audit record content. </ins>Detailed information that organizations may consider in audit records includes, for example, full text recording of privileged commands or the individual identities of group account users. Organizations consider limiting the additional audit information to only that information explicitly needed for specific audit requirements. This facilitates the use of audit trails and audit logs by not including information that could potentially be misleading or could make it more difficult to locate information of interest<ins>. Related Controls: None</ins>.
AU-3 (2):title:CONTENT OF AUDIT RECORDS | CENTRALIZED MANAGEMENT OF PLANNED AUDIT RECORD CONTENT
AU-3 (2):text:<del>The info</del><ins>P</ins>r<del>mati</del>o<del>n system pro</del>vide<del>s</del> centralized management and configuration of the content to be captured in audit records generated by [Assignment: organization-defined<del> information</del> system components].
AU-3 (2):supplement:This control enhancement requires that the content to be captured in audit records be configured from a central location (necessitating automation). Organizations coordinate the selection of required audit content to support the centralized management and configuration capability provided by the <del>information </del>system. Related <del>c</del><ins>C</ins>ontrols: AU-6, AU-7.
AU-3 (3):title:<ins>CONTENT OF AUDIT RECORDS | LIMIT PERSONALLY IDENTIFIABLE INFORMATION ELEMENTS</ins>
AU-3 (3):text:<ins>Limit personally identifiable information contained in audit records to the following elements identified in the privacy risk assessment: [Assignment: organization-defined elements].</ins>
AU-3 (3):supplement:<ins>Limiting personally identifiable information in audit records when such information is not needed for operational purposes helps reduce the level of privacy risk created by a system. Related Controls: None.</ins>

AU-4:title:AUDIT STORAGE CAPACITY
AU-4:text:<del>The organization a</del><ins>A</ins>llocate<del>s</del> audit record storage capacity <del>in</del><ins>to</ins> acco<del>r</del><ins>mmo</ins>da<del>nc</del><ins>t</ins>e <del>with </del>[Assignment: organization-defined audit record <del>sto</del>r<del>ag</del>e<ins>tention</ins> requirements].
AU-4:supplement:Organizations consider the types of auditing to be performed and the audit processing requirements when allocating audit storage capacity. Allocating sufficient audit storage capacity reduces the likelihood of such capacity being exceeded and resulting in the potential loss or reduction of auditing capability. Related <del>c</del><ins>C</ins>ontrols: AU-2, AU-5, AU-6, AU-7, AU-<ins>9, AU-</ins>11<ins>, AU-12, AU-14</ins>, SI-4.
AU-4 (1):title:AUDIT STORAGE CAPACITY | TRANSFER TO ALTERNATE STORAGE
AU-4 (1):text:<del>The in</del><ins>O</ins>f<del>ormation system o</del>f<del>f</del>-load<del>s</del> audit records [Assignment: organization-defined frequency] onto a different system or media than the system being audited.
AU-4 (1):supplement:Off-loading is a process designed to preserve the confidentiality and integrity of audit records by moving the records from the primary <del>information </del>system to a secondary or alternate system. It is a common process in <del>information </del>systems with limited audit storage capacity; the audit storage is used only in a transitory fashion until the system can communicate with the secondary or alternate system designated for storing the audit records, at which point the information is transferred<ins>. Related Controls: None</ins>.

AU-5:title:RESPONSE TO AUDIT PROCESSING FAILURES
AU-5:text:<del>The information system:</del>
AU-5 a:text:<del>The information system: </del>Alert<del>s</del> [Assignment: organization-defined personnel or roles] in the event of an audit processing failure<ins> within [Assignment: organization-defined time-period]</ins>; and
AU-5 b:text:T<del>he inform</del>a<del>tion system: Ta</del>ke<del>s</del> the following additional actions: [Assignment: organization-defined actions to be taken<del> (e.g., shut down information system, overwrite oldest audit records, stop generating audit records)</del>].
AU-5:supplement:<del>A</del><ins>Organization-defined actions incl</ins>ud<ins>e, for example, shutt</ins>i<ins>ng down </ins>t<ins>he</ins> <ins>system; overwriting oldest audit records; and sto</ins>p<ins>ping the gene</ins>r<ins>ati</ins>o<ins>n of audit re</ins>c<ins>ords. Exampl</ins>es<ins> of audit proce</ins>s<ins>s</ins>ing failures include, for example, software<del>/</del><ins> and </ins>hardware errors<del>,</del><ins>;</ins> failures in the audit capturing mechanisms<del>,</del><ins>;</ins> and audit storage capacity being reached or exceeded. Organizations may choose to define additional actions for <del>different </del>audit processing failures <del>(</del><ins>bas</ins>e<del>.g.,</del><ins>d</ins> <del>by</del><ins>on</ins> t<ins>he t</ins>ype<ins> of failure</ins>, <del>by</del><ins>the</ins> location<ins> of the failure</ins>, <del>by</del><ins>the</ins> severity<ins> of the failure</ins>, or a combination of such factors<del>)</del>. This control applies to each audit data storage repository (i.e., distinct <del>information </del>system component where audit records are stored), the total audit storage capacity of organizations (i.e., all audit data storage repositories combined), or both. Related <del>c</del><ins>C</ins>ontrols: AU<ins>-2, AU-4, AU-7, AU-9, AU-11, AU-12, AU-14, SI</ins>-4, SI-12.
AU-5 (1):title:RESPONSE TO AUDIT PROCESSING FAILURES | AUDIT STORAGE CAPACITY
AU-5 (1):text:<del>The info</del><ins>P</ins>r<del>mati</del>o<del>n system pro</del>vide<del>s</del> a warning to [Assignment: organization-defined personnel, roles, and/or locations] within [Assignment: organization-defined time<del> </del><ins>-</ins>period] when allocated audit record storage volume reaches [Assignment: organization-defined percentage] of repository maximum audit record storage capacity.
AU-5 (1):supplement:Organizations may have multiple audit data storage repositories distributed across multiple <del>information </del>system components, with each repository having different storage volume capacities<ins>. Related Controls: None</ins>.
AU-5 (2):title:RESPONSE TO AUDIT PROCESSING FAILURES | REAL-TIME ALERTS
AU-5 (2):text:<del>The info</del><ins>P</ins>r<del>mati</del>o<del>n system pro</del>vide<del>s</del> an alert in [Assignment: organization-defined real-time<del> </del><ins>-</ins>period] to [Assignment: organization-defined personnel, roles, and/or locations] when the following audit failure events occur: [Assignment: organization-defined audit failure events requiring real-time alerts].
AU-5 (2):supplement:Alerts provide organizations with urgent messages. Real-time alerts provide these messages at information technology speed (i.e., the time from event detection to alert occurs in seconds or less).<ins> Related Controls: None.</ins>
AU-5 (3):title:RESPONSE TO AUDIT PROCESSING FAILURES | CONFIGURABLE TRAFFIC VOLUME THRESHOLDS
AU-5 (3):text:<del>The i</del><ins>E</ins>nfor<del>mation system enfor</del>ce<del>s</del> configurable network communications traffic volume thresholds reflecting limits on auditing capacity and [Selection: rejects; delays] network traffic above those thresholds.
AU-5 (3):supplement:Organizations have the capability to reject or delay the processing of network communications traffic if auditing such traffic is determined to exceed the storage capacity of the <del>information </del>system audit function. The rejection or delay response is triggered by the established organizational traffic volume thresholds which can be adjusted based on changes to audit storage capacity<ins>. Related Controls: None</ins>.
AU-5 (4):title:RESPONSE TO AUDIT PROCESSING FAILURES | SHUTDOWN ON FAILURE
AU-5 (4):text:<del>The i</del><ins>I</ins>n<del>formation system in</del>voke<del>s</del> a [Selection: full system shutdown; partial system shutdown; degraded operational mode with limited mission/business functionality available] in the event of [Assignment: organization-defined audit failures], unless an alternate audit capability exists.
AU-5 (4):supplement:Organizations determine the types of audit failures that can trigger automatic <del>information </del>system shutdowns or degraded operations. Because of the importance of ensuring mission<del>/</del><ins> and </ins>business continuity, organizations may determine that the nature of the audit failure is not so severe that it warrants a complete shutdown of the <del>information </del>system supporting the core organizational missions<del>/</del><ins> and </ins>business operations. In those instances, partial <del>information </del>system shutdowns or operating in a degraded mode with reduced capability may be viable alternatives. Related <del>c</del><ins>C</ins>ontrol<ins>s</ins>: AU-15.

AU-6:title:AUDIT REVIEW, ANALYSIS, AND REPORTING
AU-6:text:<del>The organization:</del>
AU-6 a:text:<del>The organization: </del>Review<del>s</del> and analyze<del>s</del> <del>information </del>system audit records [Assignment: organization-defined frequency] for indications of [Assignment: organization-defined inappropriate or unusual activity];<del> and</del>
AU-6 b:text:<del>The organization: </del>Report<del>s</del> findings to [Assignment: organization-defined personnel or roles]<del>.</del><ins>; and</ins>
AU-6 c:text:<ins>Adjust the level of audit review, analysis, and reporting within the system when there is a change in risk based on law enforcement information, intelligence information, or other credible sources of information.</ins>

Findings can be reported to organizational entities that include, for example, <ins>the </ins>incident response team, help desk, information security group/department. AU-6 (4):title:AUDIT REVIEW, ANALYSIS, AND REPORTING | CENTRAL REVIEW AND ANALYSIS
AU-6 (4):text:<del>Th</del><ins>Provid</ins>e <del>inform</del>a<del>tio</del>n<ins>d</ins> <del>syste</del><ins>i</ins>m<del> </del>p<del>rovid</del><ins>l</ins>e<del>s</del><ins>ment</ins> the capability to centrally review and analyze audit records from multiple components within the system.

AU-6 (5):title:AUDIT REVIEW, ANALYSIS, AND REPORTING | INTEGRAT<del>ION</del><ins>ED</ins> <del>/ SC</del>AN<del>N</del><ins>ALYS</ins>I<del>NG</del><ins>S</ins> <del>AND M</del>O<del>NITORING</del><ins>F</ins> <del>C</del>A<del>PAB</del><ins>UD</ins>I<del>LI</del>T<del>I</del><ins> R</ins>E<ins>CORD</ins>S
AU-6 (5):text:<del>The orga</del><ins>I</ins>n<del>iza</del>t<del>ion int</del>egrate<del>s</del> analysis of audit records with analysis of [Selection (one or more): vulnerability scanning information; performance data;<del> information</del> system monitoring information; [Assignment: organization-defined data/information collected from other sources]] to further enhance the ability to identify inappropriate or unusual activity.
AU-6 (5):supplement:This control enhancement does not require vulnerability scanning, the generation of performance data, or <del>information </del>system monitoring. Rather, the enhancement requires that the analysis of information being otherwise produced in these areas is integrated with the analysis of audit information. Security Event and Information Management System tools can facilitate audit record aggregation/consolidation from multiple <del>information </del>system components as well as audit record correlation and analysis. The use of standardized audit record analysis scripts developed by organizations (with localized script adjustments, as necessary) provides more cost-effective approaches for analyzing audit record information collected. The correlation of audit record information with vulnerability scanning information is important in determining the veracity of vulnerability scans and correlating attack detection events with scanning results. Correlation with performance data can <del>help </del>uncover denial of service attacks or <del>cyb</del><ins>oth</ins>er <ins>types of </ins>attacks resulting in unauthorized use of resources. Correlation with system monitoring information can assist in uncovering attacks and in better relating audit information to operational situations. Related <del>c</del><ins>C</ins>ontrols: AU-12, IR-4<del>, RA-5</del>.
AU-6 (6):title:AUDIT REVIEW, ANALYSIS, AND REPORTING | CORRELATION WITH PHYSICAL MONITORING
AU-6 (6):text:<del>The </del><ins>C</ins>or<del>ganization co</del>r<del>r</del>elate<del>s</del> information from audit records with information obtained from monitoring physical access to further enhance the ability to identify suspicious, inappropriate, unusual, or malevolent activity.
AU-6 (6):supplement:The correlation of physical audit information and audit logs from <del>information </del>systems may assist organizations in identifying examples of suspicious behavior or supporting evidence of such behavior. For example, the correlation of an individual<del>'</del><ins>’</ins>s identity for logical access to certain <del>information </del>systems with the additional physical security information that the individual was <del>actually </del>present at the facility when the logical access occurred, may <del>prove to </del>be useful in investigations<ins>. Related Controls: None</ins>.
AU-6 (7):title:AUDIT REVIEW, ANALYSIS, AND REPORTING | PERMITTED ACTIONS
AU-6 (7):text:<del>The organization s</del><ins>S</ins>pecif<del>ies</del><ins>y</ins> the permitted actions for each [Selection (one or more):<del> information</del> system process; role; user] associated with the review, analysis, and reporting of audit information.
AU-6 (7):supplement:Organizations specify permitted actions for <del>information </del>system processes, roles, and/or users associated with the review, analysis, and reporting of audit records through account management techniques. Specifying permitted actions on audit information is a way to enforce the principle of least privilege. Permitted actions are enforced by the <del>information </del>system and include, for example, read, write, execute, append, and delet<ins>e. Related Controls: Non</ins>e.
AU-6 (8):title:AUDIT REVIEW, ANALYSIS, AND REPORTING | FULL TEXT ANALYSIS OF PRIVILEGED COMMANDS
AU-6 (8):text:<del>Th</del><ins>P</ins>e<del> o</del>r<del>ganization per</del>form<del>s</del> a full text analysis of audited privileged commands in a physically distinct component or subsystem of the <del>information </del>system, or other<del> information</del> system that is dedicated to that analysis.
AU-6 (8):supplement:This control enhancement requires a distinct environment for the dedicated analysis of audit information related to privileged users without compromising such information on the <del>information </del>system where the users have elevated privileges including the capability to execute privileged commands. Full text analysis refers to analysis that considers the full text of privileged commands (i.e., commands and all parameters) as opposed to analysis that considers only the name of the command. Full text analysis includes, for example, the use of pattern matching and heuristics. Related <del>c</del><ins>C</ins>ontrols: AU-3, AU-9, AU-11, AU-12.
AU-6 (9):title:AUDIT REVIEW, ANALYSIS, AND REPORTING | CORRELATION WITH INFORMATION FROM NONTECHNICAL SOURCES
AU-6 (9):text:<del>The </del><ins>C</ins>or<del>ganization co</del>r<del>r</del>elate<del>s</del> information from nontechnical sources with audit information to enhance organization-wide situational awareness.
AU-6 (9):supplement:Nontechnical sources include, for example, human resources records documenting organizational policy violations <del>(e.</del><ins>includin</ins>g<del>.</del>, <ins>for example, </ins>sexual harassment incidents<del>,</del> <ins>and </ins>improper use of organizational information assets<del>)</del>. Such information can lead <del>organiza</del>t<del>i</del>o<del>ns</del> <del>to </del>a more directed analytical effort to detect potential malicious insider activity. Due to the sensitive nature of the information available from nontechnical sources, organizations limit access to such information to minimize the potential for the inadvertent release of privacy-related information to individuals that do not have a need to know. Thus, correlation of information from nontechnical sources with audit information generally occurs only when individuals are suspected of being involved in a security incident. Organizations obtain legal advice prior to initiating such actions. Related <del>c</del><ins>C</ins>ontrol<ins>s</ins>: <del>AT</del><ins>PM</ins>-<ins>1</ins>2.

AU-7:title:AUDIT REDUCTION AND REPORT GENERATION
AU-7:text:<del>Th</del><ins>Provid</ins>e <del>inform</del>a<del>tio</del>n<ins>d</ins> <del>syste</del><ins>i</ins>m<del> </del>p<del>rovid</del><ins>l</ins>e<del>s</del><ins>ment</ins> an audit reduction and report generation capability that:
AU-7 a:text:<del>Th</del><ins>Provid</ins>e <del>inform</del>a<del>tio</del>n<ins>d</ins> <del>syste</del><ins>i</ins>m<del> </del>p<del>rovid</del><ins>l</ins>e<del>s</del><ins>ment</ins> an audit reduction and report generation capability that: Supports on-demand audit review, analysis, and reporting requirements and after-the-fact investigations of security incidents; and
AU-7 b:text:<del>Th</del><ins>Provid</ins>e <del>inform</del>a<del>tio</del>n<ins>d</ins> <del>syste</del><ins>i</ins>m<del> </del>p<del>rovid</del><ins>l</ins>e<del>s</del><ins>ment</ins> an audit reduction and report generation capability that: Does not alter the original content or time ordering of audit records.
AU-7:supplement:Audit reduction is a process that manipulates collected audit information and organizes such information in a summary format that is more meaningful to analysts. Audit reduction and report generation capabilities do not always emanate from the same <del>information </del>system or from the same organizational entities conducting auditing activities. Audit reduction capability can include, for example, modern data mining techniques with advanced data filters to identify anomalous behavior in audit records. The report generation capability provided by the <del>information </del>system can generate customizable reports. Time ordering of audit records can be a significant issue if the granularity of the timestamp in the record is insufficient. Related <del>c</del><ins>C</ins>ontrol<ins>s</ins>: A<ins>C-2, A</ins>U-<ins>2, AU-3, AU-4, AU-5, AU-</ins>6<ins>, AU-12, AU-16, CM-5, IA-5, IR-4, PM-12, SI-4</ins>.
AU-7 (1):title:AUDIT REDUCTION AND REPORT GENERATION | AUTOMATIC PROCESSING

AU-8:title:TIME STAMPS
AU-8:text:<del>The information system:</del>
AU-8 a:text:<del>The information system: </del>Use<del>s</del> internal system clocks to generate time stamps for audit records; and
AU-8 b:text:<del>The information system: </del>Record<del>s</del> time stamps for audit records that can be mapped to Coordinated Universal Time <del>(UTC) </del>or Greenwich Mean Time<del> (GMT)</del> and meets [Assignment: organization-defined granularity of time measurement].
AU-8:supplement:Time stamps generated by the <del>information </del>system include date and time. Time is commonly expressed in Coordinated Universal Time (UTC), a modern continuation of Greenwich Mean Time (GMT), or local time with an offset from UTC. Granularity of time measurements refers to the degree of synchronization between <del>information </del>system clocks and reference clocks, for example, clocks synchronizing within hundreds of milliseconds or <del>wi</del>t<del>hin t</del>ens of milliseconds. Organizations may define different time granularities for different system components. Time service can also be critical to other security capabilities such as access control and identification and authentication, depending on the nature of the mechanisms used to support those capabilities. Related <del>c</del><ins>C</ins>ontrols: AU-3, AU-12<ins>, AU-14</ins>.

AU-8 (1):text:<del>The information system:</del>
AU-8 (1) (a):text:<del>The information system: </del>Compare<del>s</del> the internal<del> information</del> system clocks [Assignment: organization-defined frequency] with [Assignment: organization-defined authoritative time source]; and
AU-8 (1) (b):text:<del>The information system: </del>Synchronize<del>s</del> the internal system clocks to the authoritative time source when the time difference is greater than [Assignment: organization-defined time<del> </del><ins>-</ins>period].
AU-8 (1):supplement:This control enhancement provides uniformity of time stamps for <del>information </del>systems with multiple system clocks and systems connected over a network<ins>. Related Controls: None</ins>.
AU-8 (2):title:TIME STAMPS | SECONDARY AUTHORITATIVE TIME SOURCE
AU-8 (2):text:<del>The information system identifies a secondary authoritative time source that is located in a different geographic region than the primary authoritative time source.</del>

AU-8 (2) (b):text:<ins>Synchronize the internal system clocks to the secondary authoritative time source if the primary authoritative time source is unavailable.</ins>
AU-8 (2):supplement:<ins>It may be necessary to employ geolocation information to determine that the secondary authoritative time source is in a different geographic region. Related Controls: None.</ins>
