AU-9:title:PROTECTION OF AUDIT INFORMATION
AU-9:text:<del>The info</del><ins>P</ins>r<del>mati</del>o<del>n sys</del>te<del>m prote</del>ct<del>s</del> audit information and audit tools from unauthorized access, modification, and deletion.
AU-9:supplement:Audit information includes all information<ins>,</ins> <del>(</del><ins>for </ins>e<del>.g.</del><ins>xample</ins>, audit records, audit settings, a<del>nd a</del>udit reports<del>)</del><ins>,</ins> <ins>a</ins>n<ins>d p</ins>e<ins>rsonally id</ins>e<ins>ntifiable information, nee</ins>ded to successfully audit <del>information </del>system activity. This control focuses on technical <ins>or automated </ins>protection of audit information. Physical protection of audit information is addressed by media protection controls and physical and environmental protection controls. Related <del>c</del><ins>C</ins>ontrols: AC-3, AC-6, <ins>AU-6, AU-11, AU-14, AU-15, </ins>MP-2, MP-4, PE-2, PE-3, PE-6<ins>, SC-8, SI-4</ins>.
AU-9 (1):title:PROTECTION OF AUDIT INFORMATION | HARDWARE WRITE-ONCE MEDIA
AU-9 (1):text:<del>The info</del><ins>W</ins>r<del>mat</del>i<del>on sys</del>te<del>m writes</del> audit trails to hardware-enforced, write-once media.
AU-9 (1):supplement:This control enhancement applies to the initial generation of audit trails (i.e., the collection of audit records that represents the audit information to be used for detection, analysis, and reporting purposes) and to the backup of those audit trails. The enhancement does not apply to the initial generation of audit records prior to being written to an audit trail. Write-once, read-many (WORM) media includes, for example, Compact Disk-Recordable (CD-R) and Digital Video Disk-Recordable (DVD-R). In contrast, the use of switchable write-protection media such as on tape cartridges or Universal Serial Bus (USB) drives results in write-protected, but not write-once, media. Related <del>c</del><ins>C</ins>ontrols: AU-4, AU-5.
AU-9 (2):title:PROTECTION OF AUDIT INFORMATION | <del>AUDI</del><ins>S</ins>T<ins>ORE</ins> <del>BACKUP </del>ON SEPARATE PHYSICAL SYSTEMS <del>/</del><ins>OR</ins> COMPONENTS
AU-9 (2):text:<del>The informa</del><ins>S</ins>t<del>i</del>o<del>n syst</del><ins>r</ins>e<del>m</del> <del>b</del>a<del>cks </del>u<del>p au</del>dit records [Assignment: organization-defined frequency] <del>o</del><ins>i</ins>n<ins> a reposi</ins>to<ins>ry that is part of</ins> a physically different system or system component than the system or component being audited.
AU-9 (2):supplement:<del>Th</del><ins>Stor</ins>i<del>s</del><ins>ng</ins> <del>co</del><ins>audit i</ins>n<ins>forma</ins>t<ins>ion in a </ins>r<ins>ep</ins>o<del>l</del><ins>sitory</ins> <ins>s</ins>e<del>n</del><ins>parate from t</ins>h<ins>e </ins>a<del>nc</del><ins>udit</ins>e<ins>d syste</ins>m<ins> or syst</ins>e<ins>m compo</ins>n<ins>en</ins>t helps to ensure that a compromise of the <del>information </del>system being audited does not also result in a compromise of the audit records. <del>R</del><ins>It may also </ins>e<ins>nab</ins>l<ins>e m</ins>a<ins>nagemen</ins>t<ins> of audit r</ins>e<ins>cor</ins>d<ins>s</ins> <ins>as an organization-wide a</ins>c<ins>tivity. This c</ins>ontrol<ins> enhancement applie</ins>s<ins> to initial generation as well as backup or long-term storage of audit information. Related Controls</ins>: AU-4, AU-5<del>, AU-11</del>.
AU-9 (3):title:PROTECTION OF AUDIT INFORMATION | CRYPTOGRAPHIC PROTECTION
AU-9 (3):text:<del>The infor</del><ins>I</ins>m<del>ation system im</del>plement<del>s</del> cryptographic mechanisms to protect the integrity of audit information and audit tools.
AU-9 (3):supplement:Cryptographic mechanisms used for protecting the integrity of audit information include, for example, signed hash functions using asymmetric cryptography enabling distribution of the public key to verify the hash information while maintaining the confidentiality of the secret key used to generate the hash. Related <del>c</del><ins>C</ins>ontrols: AU-10, SC-12, SC-13.
AU-9 (4):title:PROTECTION OF AUDIT INFORMATION | ACCESS BY SUBSET OF PRIVILEGED USERS
AU-9 (4):text:<del>The organization a</del><ins>A</ins>uthorize<del>s</del> access to management of audit functionality to only [Assignment: organization-defined subset of privileged users].
AU-9 (4):supplement:Individuals with privileged access to a<del>n</del> <del>information </del>system and who are also the subject of an audit by that system, may affect the reliability of audit information by inhibiting audit activities or modifying audit records. This control enhancement requires that privileged access be further defined between audit-related privileges and other privileges, thus limiting the users with audit-related privileges. Related <del>c</del><ins>C</ins>ontrol<ins>s</ins>: AC-5.
AU-9 (5):title:PROTECTION OF AUDIT INFORMATION | DUAL AUTHORIZATION
AU-9 (5):text:<del>The orga</del><ins>E</ins>n<del>ization en</del>force<del>s</del> dual authorization for [Selection (one or more): movement; deletion] of [Assignment: organization-defined audit information].
AU-9 (5):supplement:Organizations may choose different selection options for different types of audit information. Dual authorization mechanisms require the approval of two authorized individuals <del>in order </del>to execute. Dual authorization may also be known as two-person control. Related <del>c</del><ins>C</ins>ontrols: AC-3<del>, MP-2</del>.

AU-9 (6):text:<del>The organization a</del><ins>A</ins>uthorize<del>s</del> read-only access to audit information to [Assignment: organization-defined subset of privileged users].
AU-9 (6):supplement:Restricting privileged user authorizations to read-only helps to limit the potential damage to organizations that could be initiated by such users<ins>,</ins> <del>(</del><ins>for </ins>e<del>.g.</del><ins>xample</ins>, deleting audit records to cover up malicious activity<del>)</del><ins>. Related Controls: None</ins>.

AU-10:title:NON-REPUDIATION
AU-10:text:<del>The info</del><ins>P</ins>r<del>mati</del>o<del>n sys</del>te<del>m prote</del>ct<del>s</del> against an individual (or process acting on behalf of an individual) falsely denying having performed [Assignment: organization-defined actions to be covered by non-repudiation].
AU-10:supplement:Types of individual actions covered by non-repudiation include<del>,</del> <del>for example, </del>creating information, sending and receiving messages, a<ins>nd a</ins>pproving information<del> (e</del>.<del>g.,</del> <del>indicating concurrence or signing a contract). </del>Non-repudiation protects individuals against later claims by<del>:</del> <del>(i) </del>authors of not having authored <del>pa</del><ins>ce</ins>rt<del>icul</del>a<del>r</del><ins>in</ins> documents; <del>(ii) </del>senders of not having transmitted messages; <del>(iii) </del>receivers of not having received messages; <del>or</del><ins>and</ins> <del>(</del>i<ins>ndi</ins>v<del>)</del><ins>idual</ins> signatories of not having signed documents. Non-repudiation services can be used to determine if information originated from a <del>pa</del><ins>ce</ins>rt<del>icul</del>a<del>r</del><ins>in</ins> individual, or if an individual took specific actions<ins>,</ins> <del>(</del><ins>for </ins>e<del>.g.</del><ins>xample</ins>, sending an email, signing a contract, <ins>or </ins>approving a procurement request<del>)</del><ins>,</ins> or received specific information. Organizations obtain non-repudiation services by employing various techniques or mechanisms <del>(e.</del><ins>includin</ins>g<del>.</del>, <ins>for example, </ins>digital signatures<del>,</del> <ins>an</ins>d<ins> d</ins>igital message receipts<del>)</del>. Related <del>c</del><ins>C</ins>ontrols: <del>SC</del><ins>AU</ins>-<ins>9, PM-</ins>12, SC-8<ins>, SC-12</ins>, SC-13, SC-16, SC-17, SC-23.
AU-10 (1):title:NON-REPUDIATION | ASSOCIATION OF IDENTITIES
AU-10 (1):text:<del>The information system:</del>
AU-10 (1) (a):text:<del>The information system: </del>Bind<del>s</del> the identity of the information producer with the information to [Assignment: organization-defined strength of binding]; and
AU-10 (1) (b):text:<del>The information system: </del>Provide<del>s</del> the means for authorized individuals to determine the identity of the producer of the information.
AU-10 (1):supplement:This control enhancement supports audit requirements that provide organizational personnel with the means to identify who produced specific information in the event of an information transfer. Organizations determine and approve the strength of the binding between the information producer and the information based on the security category of the information and relevant risk factors. Related <del>c</del><ins>C</ins>ontrols: AC-4, AC-16.
AU-10 (2):title:NON-REPUDIATION | VALIDATE BINDING OF INFORMATION PRODUCER IDENTITY
AU-10 (2):text:<del>The information system:</del>
AU-10 (2) (a):text:<del>The information system: </del>Validate<del>s</del> the binding of the information producer identity to the information at [Assignment: organization-defined frequency]; and
AU-10 (2) (b):text:<del>The information system: </del>Perform<del>s</del> [Assignment: organization-defined actions] in the event of a validation error.
AU-10 (2):supplement:This control enhancement prevents the modification of information between production and review. The validation of bindings can be achieved, for example, <del>by the </del>us<del>e</del><ins>ing</ins> <del>of </del>cryptographic checksums. Organizations determine if validations are in response to user requests or generated automatically. Related <del>c</del><ins>C</ins>ontrols: AC-3, AC-4, AC-16.
AU-10 (3):title:NON-REPUDIATION | CHAIN OF CUSTODY
AU-10 (3):text:<del>The inform</del><ins>M</ins>a<del>t</del>i<del>o</del>n<del> sys</del>t<del>em m</del>ain<del>tains</del> reviewer<del>/</del><ins> or </ins>releaser identity and credentials within the established chain of custody for all information reviewed or released.
AU-10 (3):supplement:Chain of custody is a process that tracks the movement of evidence through its collection, safeguarding, and analysis life cycle by documenting each person who handled the evidence, the date and time it was collected or transferred, and the purpose for the transfer. If the reviewer is a human or if the review function is automated but separate from the release/transfer function, the <del>information </del>system associates the identity of the reviewer of the information to be released with the information and the information label. In the case of human reviews, this control enhancement provides organizational officials the means to identify who reviewed and released the information. In the case of automated reviews, this control enhancement ensures that only approved review functions are employed. Related <del>c</del><ins>C</ins>ontrols: AC-4, AC-16.

The validation of bindings can be achieved, for example, <del>by the </del>us<del>e</del><ins>ing</ins> <del>of </del>cryptographic checksums. Organizations determine validations are in response to user requests or generated automatically. Related <del>c</del><ins>C</ins>ontrols: AC-4, AC-16.

AU-11:title:AUDIT RECORD RETENTION
AU-11:text:<del>Th</del><ins>R</ins>e<del> organiza</del>t<del>ion ret</del>ain<del>s</del> audit records for [Assignment: organization-defined time<del> </del><ins>-</ins>period consistent with records retention policy] to provide support for after-the-fact investigations of securit<ins>y and privac</ins>y incidents and to meet regulatory and organizational information retention requirements.
AU-11:supplement:Organizations retain audit records until it is determined that they are no longer needed for administrative, legal, audit, or other operational purposes. This includes, for example, retention and availability of audit records relative to Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) requests, subpoenas, and law enforcement actions. Organizations develop standard categories of audit records relative to such types of actions and standard response processes for each type of action. The National Archives and Records Administration (NARA) General Records Schedules provide federal policy on record retention. Related <del>c</del><ins>C</ins>ontrols: AU-<ins>2, AU-</ins>4, AU-5, AU-<ins>6, AU-</ins>9, <ins>AU-14, </ins>MP-6<ins>, RA-5, SI-12</ins>.
AU-11 (1):title:AUDIT RECORD RETENTION | LONG-TERM RETRIEVAL CAPABILITY
AU-11 (1):text:<del>The organization e</del><ins>E</ins>mploy<del>s</del> [Assignment: organization-defined measures] to ensure that long-term audit records generated by the<del> information</del> system can be retrieved.
AU-11 (1):supplement:<ins>This control enhancement helps to ensure that, from a technological perspective, audit records requiring long-term storage (on the order of years) can be accessed and read when needed. </ins>Measures employed by organizations to help facilitate the retrieval of audit records include, for example, converting records to newer formats, retaining equipment capable of reading the records, and retaining necessary documentation to help organizational personnel understand how to interpret the records<ins>. Related Controls: None</ins>.

AU-12 b:text:<del>The information system: </del>Allow<del>s</del> [Assignment: organization-defined personnel or roles] to select which auditable event<ins> type</ins>s are to be audited by specific components of the<del> information</del> system; and

AU-12:supplement:Audit records can be generated from many different <del>information </del>system components. The list of audited event<ins> type</ins>s is the set of event<ins> type</ins>s for which audits are to be generated. These event<ins> type</ins>s are <del>typic</del>a<del>lly</del> <del>a </del>subset of all event<ins> type</ins>s for which the <del>information </del>system <del>is </del>ca<del>pable</del><ins>n</ins> <del>of </del>generat<del>ing</del><ins>e</ins> audit records. AU-12 (1):title:AUDIT GENERATION | SYSTEM-WIDE <del>/</del><ins>AND</ins> TIME-CORRELATED AUDIT TRAIL
AU-12 (1):text:<del>The inf</del><ins>C</ins>o<del>r</del>m<del>ation system com</del>pile<del>s</del> audit records from [Assignment: organization-defined<del> information</del> system components] into a system-wide (logical or physical) audit trail that is time-correlated to within [Assignment: organization-defined level of tolerance for the relationship between time stamps of individual records in the audit trail].
AU-12 (1):supplement:Audit trails are time-correlated if the time stamps in the individual audit records can be reliably related to the time stamps in other audit records to achieve a time ordering of the records within organizational tolerances. Related <del>c</del><ins>C</ins>ontrols: AU-8<del>, AU-12</del>.
AU-12 (2):title:AUDIT GENERATION | STANDARDIZED FORMATS
AU-12 (2):text:<del>The info</del><ins>P</ins>r<del>mati</del>o<del>n system pro</del>duce<del>s</del> a system-wide (logical or physical) audit trail composed of audit records in a standardized format.
AU-12 (2):supplement:Audit information that is normalized to common standards promotes interoperability and exchange of such information between dissimilar devices and <del>information </del>systems. This facilitates production of event information that can be more readily analyzed and correlated. Standard formats for audit records include, for example, system log records and audit records compliant with Common Event Expressions (CEE). If logging mechanisms within <del>information </del>systems do not conform to standardized formats, systems may convert individual audit records into standardized formats when compiling system-wide audit trails<ins>. Related Controls: None</ins>.
AU-12 (3):title:AUDIT GENERATION | CHANGES BY AUTHORIZED INDIVIDUALS
AU-12 (3):text:<del>Th</del><ins>Provid</ins>e <del>inform</del>a<del>tio</del>n<ins>d</ins> <del>syste</del><ins>i</ins>m<del> </del>p<del>rovid</del><ins>l</ins>e<del>s</del><ins>ment</ins> the capability for [Assignment: organization-defined individuals or roles] to change the auditing to be performed on [Assignment: organization-defined<del> information</del> system components] based on [Assignment: organization-defined selectable event criteria] within [Assignment: organization-defined time thresholds].
AU-12 (3):supplement:This control enhancement enables organizations to extend or limit auditing as necessary to meet organizational requirements. Auditing that is limited to conserve <del>information </del>system resources may be extended to address certain threat situations. In addition, auditing may be limited to a specific set of event<ins> type</ins>s to facilitate audit reduction, analysis, and reporting. Organizations can establish time thresholds in which audit actions are changed, for example, near real-time, within minutes, or within hours. Related <del>c</del><ins>C</ins>ontrol<ins>s</ins>: A<del>U</del><ins>C</ins>-<del>7</del><ins>3</ins>.
AU-12 (4):title:<ins>AUDIT GENERATION | QUERY PARAMETER AUDITS OF PERSONALLY IDENTIFIABLE INFORMATION</ins>
AU-12 (4):text:<ins>Provide and implement the capability for auditing the parameters of user query events for data sets containing personally identifiable information.</ins>
AU-12 (4):supplement:<ins>Query parameters are explicit criteria that a user or automated system submits to a system to retrieve data. Auditing of query parameters within systems for datasets that contain personally identifiable information augments an organization's ability to track and understand the access, usage, or sharing of personally identifiable information by authorized personnel. Related Controls: None.</ins>

AU-16:title:CROSS-ORGANIZATIONAL AUDITING
AU-16:text:<del>The organization e</del><ins>E</ins>mploy<del>s</del> [Assignment: organization-defined methods] for coordinating [Assignment: organization-defined audit information] among external organizations when audit information is transmitted across organizational boundaries.
AU-16:supplement:When organizations use <del>information </del>systems and/or services of external organizations, the auditing capability necessitates a coordinated approach across organizations. For example, maintaining the identity of individuals that requested <ins>s</ins>p<del>art</del><ins>ec</ins>i<ins>fi</ins>c<del>ular</del> services across organizational boundaries may often be very difficult, and doing so may prove to have significant performance <ins>and p</ins>r<ins>iv</ins>a<ins>cy ra</ins>mifications. Therefore, it is often the case that cross-organizational auditing <del>(e.g., the type of auditing capability provided by </del>s<del>erv</del>i<del>ce-oriented architectures) si</del>mply captures the identity of individuals issuing requests at the initial <del>information </del>system, and subsequent systems record that the requests emanated from authorized individuals. Related <del>c</del><ins>C</ins>ontrol<ins>s</ins>: AU-6<ins>, AU-7</ins>.
AU-16 (1):title:CROSS-ORGANIZATIONAL AUDITING | IDENTITY PRESERVATION
AU-16 (1):text:<del>Th</del><ins>R</ins>e<del> organization re</del>quire<del>s</del> that the identity of individuals <del>be</del><ins>is</ins> preserved in cross-organizational audit trails.
AU-16 (1):supplement:This control enhancement applies when there is a need to be able to trace actions that are performed across organizational boundaries to a specific individual.<ins> Related Controls: IA-2, IA-4, IA-5, IA-8.</ins>
AU-16 (2):title:CROSS-ORGANIZATIONAL AUDITING | SHARING OF AUDIT INFORMATION
AU-16 (2):text:<del>The o</del><ins>P</ins>r<del>ganizati</del>o<del>n pro</del>vide<del>s</del> cross-organizational audit information to [Assignment: organization-defined organizations] based on [Assignment: organization-defined cross-organizational sharing agreements].
AU-16 (2):supplement:Because of the distributed nature of the audit information, cross-organization sharing of audit information may be essential for effective analysis of the auditing being performed. For example, the audit records of one organization may not provide sufficient information to determine the appropriate or inappropriate use of organizational information resources by individuals in other organizations. In some instances, only the home organizations of individuals have the appropriate knowledge to make such determinations, thus requiring the sharing of audit information among organizations.<ins> Related Controls: IR-4, SI-4.</ins>

CA-2:supplement:Organizations assess security <ins>and priva</ins>c<ins>y c</ins>ontrols in organizational <del>information </del>systems and the environments in which those systems operate as part of<del>:</del> <del>(</del>i<del>) i</del>nitial and ongoing <del>security </del>authorizations; <del>(ii) </del>FISMA annual assessments; <del>(iii) </del>continuous monitoring; and <del>(iv) </del>system development life cycle activities. <del>Security a</del><ins>A</ins>ssessments<del>:</del> <del>(i) </del>ensure that <ins>organ</ins>i<ins>zatio</ins>n<ins>s meet in</ins>formation security <del>is built i</del><ins>a</ins>n<del>to</del><ins>d</ins> <del>o</del><ins>p</ins>r<del>gan</del>i<del>z</del><ins>v</ins>a<del>tional</del><ins>cy</ins> <ins>requ</ins>i<del>nfo</del>r<ins>e</ins>m<del>atio</del><ins>e</ins>n<del> sys</del>t<del>em</del>s; <del>(</del>i<del>i) i</del>dentify weaknesses and deficiencies <del>early </del>in the development process; <del>(iii) </del>provide essential information needed to make risk-based decisions as part of <del>security </del>authorization processes; and <del>(iv) </del>ensure compliance to vulnerability mitigation procedures. <del>Assessme</del><ins>Orga</ins>n<ins>iza</ins>t<ins>ion</ins>s <del>are </del>conduct<ins> ass</ins>e<del>d</del><ins>ssments</ins> on the implemented <del>se</del>c<del>urity c</del>ontrols from <del>Appendix F (m</del><ins>Ch</ins>a<del>in catalog) and A</del>p<del>p</del><ins>t</ins>e<del>ndix G (P</del>r<del>ogram</del> <del>Manag</del><ins>Thr</ins>e<del>m</del>e<del>nt</del> <del>controls) </del>as documented in <del>Sy</del>s<del>t</del>e<del>m Se</del>curity <del>P</del><ins>p</ins>lans and <del>Info</del><ins>p</ins>r<del>mat</del>i<del>on Se</del><ins>va</ins>c<del>urit</del>y <del>Program P</del><ins>p</ins>lans. Organizations can use other types of assessment activities such as vulnerability scanning and system monitoring to maintain the security <ins>and </ins>p<ins>rivacy p</ins>osture of <del>information </del>systems during the entire life cycle. <del>Security a</del><ins>A</ins>ssessment reports document assessment results in sufficient detail as deemed necessary by organizations, to determine the accuracy and completeness of the reports and whether the <del>se</del>c<del>urity c</del>ontrols are implemented correctly, operating as intended, and producing the desired outcome with respect to meeting <del>secu</del>r<del>ity r</del>equirements. <del>The FISM</del>A<del> requirement for a</del>ssess<del>ing security controls at least annually does not require additional assess</del>ment <del>activities to those activities al</del>re<del>ady in place in organizational </del>s<del>ec</del>u<del>rity authorization processes. Security assessment resu</del>lts are provided to the individuals or roles appropriate for the types of assessments being conducted. For example, assessments conducted in support of <del>security </del>authorization decisions are provided to authorizing officials<ins>,</ins> <ins>seni</ins>or a<ins>gency officials for privacy, and/or a</ins>uthorizing official designated representatives. To satisfy annual assessment requirements, organizations can use assessment results from the following sources: <del>(</del>i<del>) i</del>nitial or ongoing <del>information </del>system authorizations; <del>(ii) </del>continuous monitoring; or <del>(iii) </del>system development life cycle activities. Organizations ensure that <del>security </del>assessment results are current, relevant to the determination of <del>se</del>c<del>urity c</del>ontrol effectiveness, and obtained with the appropriate level of assessor independence. Existing <del>se</del>c<del>urity c</del>ontrol assessment results can be reused to the extent that the results are still valid and can also be supplemented with additional assessments as needed. <del>Subsequen</del><ins>Af</ins>t<ins>er</ins> t<del>o</del><ins>he</ins> initial authorizations<del> and in accordance with OMB policy</del>, organizations assess <del>se</del>c<del>urity c</del>ontrols during continuous monitoring. CA-2 (1):title:<del>SECURITY </del>ASSESSMENTS | INDEPENDENT ASSESSORS
CA-2 (1):text:<del>The organization e</del><ins>E</ins>mploy<del>s</del> <ins>independent </ins>assessors or assessment teams <del>wi</del>t<del>h [Assignment: </del>o<del>rganization-defined</del> <del>level of independen</del>c<del>e] t</del>o<del> co</del>nduct securit<ins>y and privac</ins>y control assessments.
CA-2 (1):supplement:Independent assessors or assessment teams are individuals or groups <del>who </del>conduct<ins>ing</ins> impartial assessments of <del>organizational information </del>systems. Impartiality implies that assessors are free from any perceived or actual conflicts of interest <del>with </del>regard<ins>ing</ins> <del>to the </del>development, operation, <ins>sustainment, </ins>or management of the <del>organizational information </del>systems under assessment or t<del>o t</del>he determination of <del>se</del>c<del>urity c</del>ontrol effectiveness. To achieve impartiality, assessors should not<del>:</del> <del>(i) </del>create a mutual or conflicting interest with the organizations where the assessments are being conducted; <del>(ii) </del>assess their own work; <del>(iii) </del>act as management or employees of the organizations they are serving; or <del>(iv) </del>place themselves in positions of advocacy for the organizations acquiring their services. Independent assessments can be obtained from elements within organizations or can be contracted to public or private sector entities outside of organizations. Authorizing officials determine the required level of independence based on the security categories of <del>information </del>systems and/or the <del>ultimate </del>risk to organizational operations, organizational assets, or individuals. Authorizing officials also determine if the level of assessor independence provides sufficient assurance that the results are sound and can be used to make credible, risk-based decisions. This includes determining whether contracted <del>security </del>assessment services have sufficient independence, for example, when <del>information </del>system owners are not directly involved in contracting processes or cannot <del>unduly </del>influence the impartiality of assessors conducting assessments. <del>In special situations, for example, w</del><ins>W</ins>hen organizations that own the <del>information </del>systems are small or organizational structures require that assessments are conducted by individuals that are in the developmental, operational, or management chain of system owners, independence in assessment processes can be achieved by ensuring that assessment results are carefully reviewed and analyzed by independent teams of experts to validate the completeness, accuracy, integrity, and reliability of the results. Organizations recognize that assessments performed for purposes other than direct support to authorization decisions are, when performed by assessors with sufficient independence, more likely to be useable for such decisions, thereby reducing the need to repeat assessments<ins>. Related Controls: None</ins>.

CA-3:supplement:This control applies to dedicated connections between <del>inf</del><ins>tw</ins>o<ins> o</ins>r<ins> </ins>m<del>ati</del>o<del>n</del><ins>re</ins> s<del>ys</del><ins>epara</ins>te<del>ms</del> <del>(i.e., </del>system<del> interconnection</del>s<del>)</del> and does not apply to transitory, user-controlled connections such as email and website browsing. If interconnecting systems have the same authorizing official, organizations do not need to develop Interconnection Security Agreements. Organizations may also incorporate Interconnection Security Agreement information into formal contracts, especially for interconnections established between federal agencies and nonfederal <del>(i.e., private sect</del>or<del>) or</del>ganizations. CA-3 (6):title:<ins>SYSTEM INTERCONNECTIONS | SECONDARY AND TERTIARY CONNECTIONS</ins>
CA-3 (6) (a):text:<ins>Identify secondary and tertiary connections to the interconnected systems; and</ins>
CA-3 (6) (b):text:<ins>Take measures to ensure that connections are severed when security and privacy controls on identified secondary and tertiary systems cannot be verified or validated.</ins>
CA-3 (6):supplement:<ins>For certain critical systems and applications including, for example, high-value assets, it may be necessary to identify second and third level connections to the interconnected systems. The transparency of the protection measures in place in secondary and tertiary systems connected directly or indirectly to organizational systems is essential in understanding the actual security and privacy risks resulting from those interconnections. Organizational systems can inherit risk from secondary and tertiary systems through those connections and make the organizational systems more susceptible to threats, hazards, and adverse consequences. Related Controls: None.</ins>

CA-6 (1):title:<ins>AUTHORIZATION | JOINT AUTHORIZATION - SAME ORGANIZATION</ins>
CA-6 (1):text:<ins>Employ a joint authorization process for the system that includes multiple authorizing officials from the same organization conducting the authorization.</ins>
CA-6 (1):supplement:<ins>Assigning multiple authorizing officials from the same organization to serve as co-authorizing officials for the system, increases the level of independence in the risk-based decision making process for security and privacy. It also implements the concepts of separation of duties and dual authorization as applied to the system authorization process. This enhancement is most relevant for interconnected systems, shared systems, and systems with one or more information owners. Related Controls: AC-6.</ins>
CA-6 (2):title:<ins>AUTHORIZATION | JOINT AUTHORIZATION - DIFFERENT ORGANIZATIONS</ins>
CA-6 (2):text:<ins>Employ a joint authorization process for the system that includes multiple authorizing officials with at least one authorizing official from an organization external to the organization conducting the authorization.</ins>
CA-6 (2):supplement:<ins>Assigning multiple authorizing officials, at least one of which comes from an external organization, to serve as co-authorizing officials for the system, increases the level of independence in the risk-based decision making process for security and privacy. It also implements the concepts of separation of duties and dual authorization and as applied to the system authorization process. Employing authorizing officials from external organizations to supplement the authorization official from the organization owning or hosting the system may be necessary when those organizations have a vested interest or equities in the outcome of the authorization decision. This situation may occur with interconnected systems, shared systems, and systems with one or more information owners. Accordingly, the authorizing officials from the external organizations may be considered key stakeholders of the system undergoing authorization. Related Controls: AC-6.</ins>

CA-7:supplement:Continuous monitoring programs facilitate ongoing awareness of threats, vulnerabilities, and information security <ins>and privacy </ins>to support organizational risk management decisions. The terms continuous and ongoing imply that organizations assess<del>/analyze</del> security <ins>and priva</ins>c<ins>y c</ins>ontrols and <del>inform</del>a<del>tion </del>s<del>e</del><ins>so</ins>c<del>ur</del>i<del>ty-rel</del>ated risks at a frequency sufficient to support <del>o</del>r<del>gan</del>i<del>zational ri</del>sk-based decisions. The results of continuous monitoring <del>pro</del>g<del>rams g</del>enerate <del>app</del>r<del>opr</del>i<del>ate ri</del>sk response actions by organizations. <ins>When monitoring the effectiveness of controls that have been grouped into capabilities, a root-cause analysis may be needed to determine the specific control that has failed. </ins>Continuous monitoring programs also allow organizations to maintain the <del>security </del>authorizations of <del>information </del>systems and common controls over time in highly dynamic environments of operation with changing mission<del>/</del><ins> and </ins>business needs, threats, vulnerabilities, and technologies. Having access to security-<ins> and p</ins>r<ins>ivacy-r</ins>elated information on a continuing basis through reports<del>/</del><ins> an</ins>d<ins> d</ins>ashboards gives organizational officials the capability to make more effective and timely risk management decisions, including ongoing <del>security </del>authorization decisions. Automation supports more frequent updates to <del>security aut</del>h<del>oriz</del>a<del>tion packages, ha</del>rdware<del>/</del><ins>, </ins>software<del>/</del><ins>, and </ins>firmware inventories, a<ins>uthorizatio</ins>n<ins> packages, an</ins>d other system information. Effectiveness is further enhanced when continuous monitoring outputs are formatted to provide information that is specific, measurable, actionable, relevant, and timely. Continuous monitoring activities are scaled in accordance with the security categories of <del>information </del>systems. Related <del>c</del><ins>C</ins>ontrols: <ins>A</ins>C<ins>-2, </ins>A<ins>C</ins>-<ins>6, AU-6, CA-</ins>2, CA-5, CA-6, CM-3, CM-4, <ins>CM-6, CM-11, IA-5, </ins>P<ins>E-6, PL-2, P</ins>M-<ins>4, PM-</ins>6, PM-9, <ins>PM-10, PM-12, PM-14, PM-32, </ins>RA-<ins>3, RA-</ins>5, <ins>RA-7, </ins>SA-11, S<del>A</del><ins>C</ins>-<del>12</del><ins>5</ins>, S<ins>C-38, S</ins>I-<del>2</del><ins>3</ins>, SI-4<ins>, SI-12</ins>.
CA-7 (1):title:CONTINUOUS MONITORING | INDEPENDENT ASSESSMENT
CA-7 (1):text:<del>The organization e</del><ins>E</ins>mploy<del>s</del> <ins>independent </ins>assessors or assessment teams <del>wi</del>t<del>h [Assignment: </del>o<del>rganization-defined</del> <del>level of independence] to </del>monitor the security <ins>and priva</ins>c<ins>y c</ins>ontrols in the<del> information</del> system on an ongoing basis.
CA-7 (1):supplement:Organizations can maximize the value of <ins>control </ins>assessments <del>of security controls </del>during the continuous monitoring process by requiring that <del>such </del>assessments be conducted by assessors <del>or assessment teams </del>with appropriate levels of independence<ins>.</ins> <ins>The level of assessor independence required is </ins>based on <ins>organizational </ins>continuous monitoring strategies. Assessor independence provides a degree of impartiality to the monitoring process. To achieve such impartiality, assessors should not<del>:</del> <del>(i) </del>create a mutual or conflicting interest with the organizations where the assessments are being conducted; <del>(ii) </del>assess their own work; <del>(iii) </del>act as management or employees of the organizations they are serving; or <del>(iv) </del>place themselves in advocacy positions for the organizations acquiring their services<ins>. Related Controls: None</ins>.

CA-7 (3):text:<del>The organization e</del><ins>E</ins>mploy<del>s</del> trend analyses to determine if security <ins>and priva</ins>c<ins>y c</ins>ontrol implementations, the frequency of continuous monitoring activities, and<del>/or</del> the types of activities used in the continuous monitoring process need to be modified based on empirical data.

CA-7 (4):title:<ins>CONTINUOUS MONITORING | RISK MONITORING</ins>
CA-7 (4):text:<ins>Ensure risk monitoring is an integral part of the continuous monitoring strategy that includes the following:</ins>
CA-7 (4) (a):text:<ins>Ensure risk monitoring is an integral part of the continuous monitoring strategy that includes the following: Effectiveness monitoring;</ins>
CA-7 (4) (b):text:<ins>Ensure risk monitoring is an integral part of the continuous monitoring strategy that includes the following: Compliance monitoring; and</ins>
CA-7 (4) (c):text:<ins>Ensure risk monitoring is an integral part of the continuous monitoring strategy that includes the following: Change monitoring.</ins>
CA-7 (4):supplement:<ins>Effectiveness monitoring determines the ongoing effectiveness of implemented risk response measures. Compliance monitoring verifies that the required risk response measures are implemented. It also verifies that security and privacy requirements are satisfied. Change monitoring identifies changes to organizational systems and environments of operation that may affect security and privacy risk. Related Controls: None.</ins>

CA-8:title:PENETRATION TESTING
CA-8:text:<del>The </del><ins>C</ins>o<del>rga</del>n<del>ization con</del>duct<del>s</del> penetration testing [Assignment: organization-defined frequency] on [Assignment: organization-defined<del> information</del> systems or system components].
CA-8:supplement:Penetration testing is a specialized type of assessment conducted on <del>information </del>systems or individual system components to identify vulnerabilities that could be exploited by adversaries. <del>S</del><ins>Penetration testing goes beyond a</ins>u<ins>tomated vulnerability s</ins>c<ins>anning and is most effectively conducted by penetration testing agents and teams wit</ins>h <ins>demons</ins>t<ins>rabl</ins>e<ins> </ins>s<ins>kills and experience </ins>t<ins>hat, depend</ins>ing <ins>on the s</ins>c<ins>ope of the penetr</ins>a<ins>tio</ins>n <ins>testing, include technical expertise in network, operating system, and/or application level security. Penetration testing can </ins>be used to either validate vulnerabilities or determine the degree of <del>r</del><ins>p</ins>e<del>sista</del>n<del>c</del>e<del> o</del><ins>t</ins>r<del>g</del>a<del>niza</del>tion<del>al</del> <del>info</del>r<del>mat</del><ins>es</ins>i<del>o</del><ins>sta</ins>n<ins>ce</ins> <ins>of </ins>systems <del>have </del>to adversaries within <del>a </del>s<del>et of s</del>pecified constraints<ins>.</ins> <del>(</del><ins>Such constraints includ</ins>e<del>.g.</del>, <ins>for example, </ins>time, resources, and<del>/or</del> skills<del>)</del>. Penetration testing attempts to duplicate the actions of adversaries in carrying out <del>hostile cyber </del>attacks against organizations and provides a more in-depth analysis of security-<ins> and p</ins>r<ins>ivacy-r</ins>elated weaknesses<del>/</del><ins> or </ins>deficiencies. Organizations can <del>also </del>use the results of vulnerability analyses to support penetration testing activities. Penetration testing can be conducted on the hardware, software, or firmware components of a<del>n</del> <del>information </del>system and can exercise both physical and technical <del>se</del>c<del>urity c</del>ontrols. A standard method for penetration testing includes, for example<del>:</del><ins>,</ins> <del>(i) </del>pretest analysis based on full knowledge of the target system; <del>(ii) </del>pretest identification of potential vulnerabilities based on pretest analysis; and <del>(iii) </del>testing designed to determine exploitability of identified vulnerabilities. All parties agree to the rules of engagement before <del>the </del>commencement of penetration testing scenarios. Organizations correlate the <del>penet</del>r<del>ation testing r</del>ules of engagement <ins>for the penetration tests </ins>with the tools, techniques, and procedures that are anticipated to be employed by adversaries carrying out attacks. <del>Organ</del><ins>R</ins>i<del>zational ri</del>sk assessments guide <ins>the </ins>decisions on the level of independence required for personnel conducting penetration testing. Related <del>c</del><ins>C</ins>ontrol<ins>s</ins>:<ins> SA-11,</ins> SA-12.
CA-8 (1):title:PENETRATION TESTING | INDEPENDENT PENETRATION AGENT OR TEAM
CA-8 (1):text:<del>The organization e</del><ins>E</ins>mploy<del>s</del> an independent penetration agent or penetration team to perform penetration testing on the<del> information</del> system or system components.
CA-8 (1):supplement:Independent penetration agents or teams are individuals or groups who conduct impartial penetration testing of organizational <del>information </del>systems. Impartiality implies that penetration agents or teams are free from any perceived or actual conflicts of interest with re<del>gard</del><ins>spect</ins> to the development, operation, or management of the <del>information </del>systems that are the targets of the penetration testing. Supplemental guidance for CA-2<del> </del>(1) provides additional information <del>regardi</del><ins>o</ins>n<del>g</del> independent assessments that can be applied to penetration testing. Related <del>c</del><ins>C</ins>ontrol<ins>s</ins>: CA-2.

CA-8 (2):text:<del>The organization e</del><ins>E</ins>mploy<del>s</del> [Assignment: organization-defined red team exercises] to simulate attempts by adversaries to compromise organizational <del>information </del>systems in accordance with <del>[Assignment: org</del>a<del>n</del><ins>ppl</ins>i<del>z</del><ins>c</ins>a<del>tion-d</del><ins>bl</ins>e<del>fined</del> rules of engagement<del>]</del>.
CA-8 (2):supplement:Red team exercises extend the objectives of penetration testing by examining the security <ins>and </ins>p<ins>rivacy p</ins>osture of organizations and their ability to implement effective cyber defenses. <del>As such, r</del><ins>R</ins>ed team exercises reflect simulated a<ins>ttempts by a</ins>dversari<del>al att</del>e<del>mpt</del>s to compromise organizational mission<del>/</del><ins>s and </ins>business functions and provide a comprehensive assessment of the security <ins>and privacy </ins>state of <del>information </del>systems and organizations. Simulated a<ins>ttempts by a</ins>dversari<del>al att</del>e<del>mpt</del>s to compromise <del>organizational </del>missions<del>/</del><ins> and </ins>business functions and the <del>information </del>systems that support those missions<del>/</del><ins> and </ins>functions may include technology-<del>f</del><ins>based attacks and s</ins>oc<del>u</del><ins>ial engineering-ba</ins>sed attacks<ins>.</ins> <del>(</del><ins>T</ins>e<del>.</del><ins>chnolo</ins>g<del>.,</del><ins>y-based</ins> <ins>attacks </ins>in<ins>clude in</ins>teractions with hardware, software, or firmware components and/or mission<del>/</del><ins> and </ins>business processes<del>)</del><ins>.</ins> <del>and s</del><ins>S</ins>ocial engineering-based attacks <del>(</del><ins>includ</ins>e<del>.g.,</del> interactions via email, telephone, shoulder surfing, or personal conversations<del>)</del>. <ins>Red team exercises are most effectively conducted by penetration testing agents and teams with knowledge of and experience with current adversarial tactics, techniques, procedures, and tools. </ins>While penetration testing may be <del>l</del><ins>prim</ins>ar<del>ge</del><ins>i</ins>ly laboratory-based testing, organizations <ins>can </ins>use red team exercises to provide more comprehensive assessments that reflect real-world conditions. Related Controls: None</ins>.

CM-2:title:BASELINE CONFIGURATION
CM-2:text:<del>The organization develops, documents, and maintains under configuration control, a current baseline configuration of the information system.</del>
CM-2 a:text:<ins>Develop, document, and maintain under configuration control, a current baseline configuration of the system; and</ins>
CM-2 b:text:<ins>Review and update the baseline configuration of the system:</ins>
CM-2 b 1:text:<ins>Review and update the baseline configuration of the system: [Assignment: organization-defined frequency];</ins>
CM-2 b 2:text:<ins>Review and update the baseline configuration of the system: When required due to [Assignment organization-defined circumstances]; and</ins>
CM-2 b 3:text:<ins>Review and update the baseline configuration of the system: When system components are installed or upgraded.</ins>
CM-2:supplement:This control establishes baseline configurations for <del>information </del>systems and system components including communications and connectivity-related aspects of systems. Baseline configurations are documented, formally reviewed and agreed-upon sets of specifications for <del>information </del>systems or configuration items within those systems. Baseline configurations serve as a basis for future builds, releases, and/or changes to <del>information </del>systems. Baseline configurations include information about <del>information </del>system components<del> (e.g.</del>, <del>sta</del>n<del>dard softwar</del>e<del> packages ins</del>t<del>alled on </del>work<del>stations,</del> <del>no</del>t<del>eb</del>o<del>ok com</del>p<del>uters, servers, netw</del>o<del>rk components, or mobi</del>l<del>e devices; current versi</del>o<del>n numbers and patch information on operatin</del>g<del> s</del>y<del>stems and applications; and configuration settings/parameters)</del>, <del>network topology, </del>and the logical placement of those components within the system architecture. Maintaining baseline configurations requires creating new baselines as organizational <del>information </del>systems change over time. Baseline configurations of <del>information </del>systems reflect the current enterprise architecture. Related <del>c</del><ins>C</ins>ontrols: <ins>A</ins>C<ins>-19, AU-6, CA-9, C</ins>M-<ins>1, CM-</ins>3, CM-<ins>5, CM-</ins>6, CM-8, CM-9, <del>SA</del><ins>CP</ins>-<ins>9, CP-</ins>10, <ins>C</ins>P<del>M</del>-<del>5</del><ins>12</ins>, P<ins>L-8, P</ins>M-<del>7</del><ins>5, SA-10, SC-18</ins>.

CM-2 (1):text:<del>The organization reviews and updates the baseline configuration of the information system:</del>
CM-2 (1) (a):text:<del>The organization reviews and updates the baseline configuration of the information system: [Assignment: organization-defined frequency];</del>
CM-2 (1) (b):text:<del>The organization reviews and updates the baseline configuration of the information system: When required due to [Assignment organization-defined circumstances]; and</del>
CM-2 (1) (c):text:<del>The organization reviews and updates the baseline configuration of the information system: As an integral part of information system component installations and upgrades.</del>
CM-2 (1):supplement:<del>Related control: CM-5.</del>
CM-2 (2):title:BASELINE CONFIGURATION | AUTOMATION SUPPORT FOR ACCURACY <del>/</del><ins>AND</ins> CURRENCY
CM-2 (2):text:<del>The organization e</del><ins>E</ins>mploy<del>s</del> automated mechanisms to maintain an up-to-date, complete, accurate, and readily available baseline configuration of the<del> information</del> system.
CM-2 (2):supplement:Automated mechanisms that help organizations maintain consistent baseline configurations for <del>information </del>systems include, for example, hardware and software inventory tools, configuration management tools, and network management tools. Such tools can be deployed and/or allocated as common controls, at the <del>information </del>system level, or at the operating system or component level <del>(e.</del><ins>includin</ins>g<del>.</del>, <ins>f</ins>o<ins>r example, o</ins>n workstations, servers, notebook computers, network components, or mobile devices<del>)</del>. Tools can be used, for example, to track version numbers on operating system<ins>s,</ins> applications, types of software installed, and current patch levels. This control enhancement can be satisfied by the implementation of CM-8<del> </del>(2) for organizations that choose to combine <del>information </del>system component inventory and baseline configuration activities. Related <del>c</del><ins>C</ins>ontrols: CM-7<ins>, IA-3</ins>, RA-5.
CM-2 (3):title:BASELINE CONFIGURATION | RETENTION OF PREVIOUS CONFIGURATIONS
CM-2 (3):text:<del>Th</del><ins>R</ins>e<del> organiza</del>t<del>ion ret</del>ain<del>s</del> [Assignment: organization-defined previous versions of baseline configurations of the<del> information</del> system] to support rollback.
CM-2 (3):supplement:Retaining previous versions of baseline configurations to support rollback may include, for example, hardware, software, firmware, configuration files, and configuration records.<ins> Related Controls: None.</ins>

CM-2 (6):title:BASELINE CONFIGURATION | DEVELOPMENT AND TEST ENVIRONMENTS
CM-2 (6):text:<del>The org</del><ins>M</ins>a<del>n</del>i<del>zatio</del>n<del> main</del>tain<del>s</del> a baseline configuration for<del> information</del> system development and test environments that is managed separately from the operational baseline configuration.
CM-2 (6):supplement:Establishing separate baseline configurations for development, testing, and operational environments helps protect <del>information </del>systems from unplanned/unexpected events related to development and testing activities. Separate baseline configurations allow organizations to apply the configuration management that is most appropriate for each type of configuration. For example, management of operational configurations typically emphasizes the need for stability, while management of development/test configurations requires greater flexibility. Configurations in the test environment mirror the configurations in the operational environment to the extent practicable so that the results of the testing are representative of the proposed changes to the operational systems. This control enhancement requires separate configurations but not necessarily separate physical environments. Related <del>c</del><ins>C</ins>ontrols: CM-4, SC-3, SC-7.
CM-2 (7):title:BASELINE CONFIGURATION | CONFIGURE SYSTEMS<del>,</del> <ins>AND </ins>COMPONENT<del>S, OR DEVICE</del>S FOR HIGH-RISK AREAS
CM-2 (7):text:<del>The organization:</del>
CM-2 (7) (a):text:<del>The organization: </del>Issue<del>s</del> [Assignment: organization-defined <del>information </del>systems<del>,</del> <ins>or </ins>system component<del>s, or device</del>s] with [Assignment: organization-defined configurations] to individuals traveling to locations that the organization deems to be of significant risk; and
CM-2 (7) (b):text:<del>The organization: </del>Appl<del>ies</del><ins>y</ins> [Assignment: organization-defined security safeguards] to the <del>devi</del>c<ins>ompon</ins>e<ins>nt</ins>s when the individuals return<ins> from travel</ins>.
CM-2 (7):supplement:When it is known that <del>information </del>systems<del>,</del> <ins>or </ins>system components<del>,</del> <del>or devices (e.g., notebook computers, mobile devices) </del>will be <del>located </del>in high-risk areas, additional <del>se</del>c<del>urity c</del>ontrols may be implemented to counter the <del>greater threat </del>in<del> su</del>c<del>h a</del>reas<del> coupl</del>ed <del>wi</del>th<del> the lack of physical secu</del>r<del>ity r</del>e<del>l</del>at<del>ive</del> <del>to organ</del>i<del>zatio</del>n<del>al-</del><ins> su</ins>c<del>ontrolled</del><ins>h</ins> areas. For example, organization<ins>s c</ins>a<del>l</del><ins>n</ins> <ins>take s</ins>p<del>oli</del><ins>e</ins>ci<del>es</del><ins>fic</ins> a<del>nd pro</del>c<del>edure</del><ins>tion</ins>s for notebook computers used by individuals departing on and returning from travel<ins>.</ins> <ins>These act</ins>i<ins>o</ins>n<ins>s </ins>c<ins>an inc</ins>lude, for example, determining which locations are of concern, defining required configurations for the devices, ensuring that the devices are configured as intended before travel is initiated, and applying specific safeguards to the <del>devi</del>c<ins>ompon</ins>e<ins>nt</ins> after travel is completed. Specially configured notebook computers include, for example, computers with sanitized hard drives, limited applications, and <del>additional hardening (e.g., </del>more stringent configuration settings<del>)</del>. Specified safeguards applied to mobile devices upon return from travel include, for example, examining the device for signs of physical tampering<ins>;</ins> and purging<del>/</del><ins> and </ins>reimaging the hard disk drive. Protecting information residing on mobile devices is covered in the media protection family<ins>. Related Controls: None</ins>.

CM-3 b:text:<del>The organization: </del>Review<del>s</del> proposed configuration-controlled changes to the <del>information </del>system and approve<del>s</del> or disapprove<del>s</del> such changes with explicit consideration for security impact analyses;

CM-3 d:text:<del>The organization: </del>Implement<del>s</del> approved configuration-controlled changes to the<del> information</del> system;
CM-3 e:text:<del>The organization: </del>Retain<del>s</del> records of configuration-controlled changes to the <del>information </del>system for [Assignment: organization-defined time<del> </del><ins>-</ins>period];
CM-3 f:text:<del>The </del><ins>M</ins>o<del>rga</del>ni<del>za</del>t<del>i</del>o<del>n:</del><ins>r</ins> <del>Audits </del>and review<del>s</del> activities associated with configuration-controlled changes to the<del> information</del> system; and
CM-3 g:text:<del>The organization: </del>Coordinate<del>s</del> and provide<del>s</del> oversight for configuration change control activities through [Assignment: organization-defined configuration change control element<del> (e.g., committee, board)</del>] that convenes [Selection (one or more): [Assignment: organization-defined frequency]; [Assignment: organization-defined configuration change conditions]].
CM-3:supplement:Configuration change controls for organizational <del>information </del>systems involve the systematic proposal, justification, implementation, testing, review, and disposition of changes to the systems, including system upgrades and modifications. Configuration change control includes changes to baseline configurations for components and configuration items of <del>information </del>systems<del>,</del><ins>;</ins> changes to configuration settings for <del>inf</del><ins>c</ins>o<del>r</del>m<del>ati</del><ins>p</ins>on<del> t</del>e<del>ch</del>n<del>ology</del><ins>t</ins> products<ins>;</ins> <del>(e.g., operating systems, applications, firewalls, ro</del>u<del>ters, a</del>n<del>d mobile device</del>s<del>), uns</del>cheduled<del>/</del><ins> or </ins>unauthorized changes<del>,</del><ins>;</ins> and changes to remediate vulnerabilities. <ins>Configuration change control elements can include such entities as committees or boards. </ins>Typical processes for managing configuration changes to <del>information </del>systems include, for example, Configuration Control Boards <ins>or Change Advisory Boards </ins>that <ins>review </ins>a<ins>nd a</ins>pprove proposed changes to systems. For new development <del>information </del>systems or systems undergoing major upgrades, organizations consider including representatives from development organizations on the Configuration Control Boards<ins> or Change Advisory Boards</ins>. Auditing of changes includes activities before and after changes are made to organizational <del>information </del>systems and the auditing activities required to implement such changes. Related <del>c</del><ins>C</ins>ontrols: CA-7, CM-2, CM-4, CM-5, CM-6, CM-9, <ins>CM-11, IA-3, MA-2, PE-16, </ins>SA-10, S<ins>A-19, SC-28, SC-34, SC-37, S</ins>I-2, SI-<ins>3, SI-4, SI-7, SI-</ins>1<del>2</del><ins>0</ins>.
CM-3 (1):title:CONFIGURATION CHANGE CONTROL | AUTOMATED DOCUMENT<ins>ATION,</ins> <del>/ </del>NOTIFICATION<ins>,</ins> <del>/</del><ins>AND</ins> PROHIBITION OF CHANGES

CM-3 (2):title:CONFIGURATION CHANGE CONTROL | TEST<ins>ING,</ins> <del>/ </del>VALIDAT<del>E</del><ins>ION,</ins> <del>/</del><ins>AND</ins> DOCUMENT<ins>ATION OF</ins> CHANGES
CM-3 (2):text:T<del>h</del>e<del> organization te</del>st<del>s</del>, validate<del>s</del>, and document<del>s</del> changes to the <del>information </del>system before <ins>fully </ins>implementing the changes on the<del> operational</del> system.
CM-3 (2):supplement:Changes to <del>information </del>systems include modifications to hardware, software, or firmware components and configuration settings defined in CM-6. Organizations ensure that testing does not interfere with <del>information </del>system operations. Individuals<del>/</del><ins> or </ins>groups conducting tests understand organizational security <ins>and </ins>p<ins>rivacy p</ins>olicies and procedures, <del>information </del>system security <ins>and </ins>p<ins>rivacy p</ins>olicies and procedures, and the <del>specific </del>health, safety, and environmental risks associated with <ins>s</ins>p<del>art</del><ins>ec</ins>i<ins>fi</ins>c<del>ular</del> facilities<del>/</del><ins> or </ins>processes. Operational systems may need to be taken off-line, or replicated to the extent feasible, before testing can be conducted. If <del>information </del>systems must be taken off-line for testing, the tests are scheduled to occur during planned system outages whenever possible. If t<ins>h</ins>e<ins> te</ins>sting cannot be conducted on operational systems, organizations employ compensating controls<del> (e</del>.<del>g.,</del> <del>t</del><ins>R</ins>e<del>sting on rep</del>l<del>ic</del>ated <del>sys</del><ins>Con</ins>t<del>em</del><ins>rol</ins>s<del>)</del><ins>: None</ins>.

CM-3 (4):title:CONFIGURATION CHANGE CONTROL | SECURITY REPRESENTATIVE
CM-3 (4):text:<del>Th</del><ins>R</ins>e<ins>quire</ins> <ins>an [Assignment: </ins>organization<del> r</del><ins>-d</ins>e<del>qu</del><ins>f</ins>i<del>r</del><ins>n</ins>e<del>s</del><ins>d</ins> <del>an </del>information security representative<ins>]</ins> to be a member of the [Assignment: organization-defined configuration change control element].
CM-3 (4):supplement:Information security representatives can include, for example, <del>s</del><ins>S</ins>enior <del>a</del><ins>A</ins>gency <del>i</del><ins>I</ins>nformation <del>s</del><ins>S</ins>ecurity <del>o</del><ins>O</ins>fficers, <del>information </del>system security officers, or <del>information </del>system security managers. Representation by personnel with information security expertise is important because changes to <del>information </del>system configurations can have unintended side effects, some of which may be security-relevant. Detecting such changes early in the process can help avoid unintended, negative consequences that could ultimately affect the security state of organizational <del>information </del>systems. The configuration change control element in this control enhancement reflects the change control elements defined by organizations in CM-3<ins>. Related Controls: None</ins>.

CM-4 (1):title:SECURITY <ins>AND PR</ins>I<ins>VACY I</ins>MPACT ANALYS<del>I</del><ins>E</ins>S | SEPARATE TEST ENVIRONMENTS
CM-4 (1):text:<del>The orga</del><ins>A</ins>n<del>iz</del>a<del>tion ana</del>lyze<del>s</del> changes to the <del>information </del>system in a separate test environment before implementation in an operational environment, looking for securit<ins>y and privac</ins>y impacts due to flaws, weaknesses, incompatibility, or intentional malice.
CM-4 (1):supplement:Separate test environment in this context means an environment that is physically or logically isolated and distinct from the operational environment. The separation is sufficient to ensure that activities in the test environment do not impact activities in the operational environment, and information in the operational environment is not inadvertently transmitted to the test environment. Separate environments can be achieved by physical or logical means. If physically separate test environments are not used, organizations determine the strength of mechanism required when implementing logical separation<del> (e</del>.<del>g.,</del> <del>separation achieved through virtual machines). </del>Related <del>c</del><ins>C</ins>ontrols: SA-11<del>, SC-3</del>, SC-7.

CM-5:title:ACCESS RESTRICTIONS FOR CHANGE
CM-5:text:<del>Th</del><ins>D</ins>e<del> organization de</del>fine<del>s</del>, document<del>s</del>, approve<del>s</del>, and enforce<del>s</del> physical and logical access restrictions associated with changes to the<del> information</del> system.
CM-5:supplement:Any changes to the hardware, software, and/or firmware components of <del>information </del>systems can potentially have significant effects on the overall security of the systems. Therefore, organizations permit only qualified and authorized individuals to access <del>information </del>systems for purposes of initiating changes, including upgrades and modifications. <del>Organizations maintain records of access to ensure that configuration change control is implemented and to support after-the-fact actions should organizations discover any unauthorized changes. </del>Access restrictions for change also include software libraries. Access restrictions include, for example, physical and logical access controls (see AC-3 and PE-3), workflow automation, media libraries, abstract layers (<ins>i.</ins>e.<del>g.</del>, changes implemented into <ins>ex</ins>t<del>hi</del><ins>e</ins>r<del>d-p</del><ins>n</ins>a<del>rty</del><ins>l</ins> interfaces rather than directly into <del>information </del>systems), and change windows (<ins>i.</ins>e.<del>g.</del>, changes occur only during specified times<del>, making unauthorized changes easy to discover</del>). Related <del>c</del><ins>C</ins>ontrols: AC-3, AC-<ins>5, AC-</ins>6, <ins>CM-9, </ins>PE-3<ins>, SC-28, SC-34, SC-37, SI-2, SI-10</ins>.

CM-5 (3):title:ACCESS RESTRICTIONS FOR CHANGE | SIGNED COMPONENTS

CM-5 (3):supplement:Software and firmware components prevented from installation unless signed with recognized and approved certificates include, for example, software and firmware version updates, patches, service packs, device drivers, and basic input output system (BIOS) updates. Digital signatures and organizational verification of such signatures, is a method of code authentication. Related <del>c</del><ins>C</ins>ontrols: CM-7, SC-13, SI-7.

CM-6:title:CONFIGURATION SETTINGS
CM-6:text:<del>The organization:</del>
CM-6 a:text:<del>The organization: </del>Establish<del>es</del> and document<del>s</del> configuration settings for <del>inf</del><ins>c</ins>o<del>r</del>m<del>ati</del><ins>p</ins>on<del> t</del>e<del>ch</del>n<del>ology produc</del>ts employed within the <del>information </del>system using [Assignment: organization-defined <ins>common </ins>secur<del>ity</del><ins>e</ins> configuration<del> checklist</del>s] that reflect the most restrictive mode consistent with operational requirements;
CM-6 b:text:<del>The organization: </del>Implement<del>s</del> the configuration settings;
CM-6 c:text:<del>The organization: </del>Identif<del>ies</del><ins>y</ins>, document<del>s</del>, and approve<del>s</del> any deviations from established configuration settings for [Assignment: organization-defined<del> information</del> system components] based on [Assignment: organization-defined operational requirements]; and
CM-6 d:text:<del>The organization: </del>Monitor<del>s</del> and control<del>s</del> changes to the configuration settings in accordance with organizational policies and procedures.
CM-6:supplement:Configuration settings are the <del>set of </del>parameters that can be changed in hardware, software, or firmware components of the <del>information </del>system that affect the security posture <del>and/</del>or functionality of the system. Information technology products for which security-related configuration settings can be defined include, for example, mainframe computers, servers<del> (e.g.</del>, <del>database, electronic mail, authentication, </del>w<del>eb, pr</del>o<del>xy, file, domain name), wo</del>rkstations, input/output devices<del> (e.g.</del>, <del>sca</del>n<del>n</del>e<del>rs, copiers, and prin</del>t<del>ers), net</del>work <del>compon</del><ins>d</ins>e<del>nts (e.g., firewalls, routers, gateways, </del>v<del>o</del>ice<del> and data </del>s<del>witches</del>, <del>wireless access p</del>o<del>ints, network a</del>p<del>plianc</del>e<del>s, senso</del>r<del>s), oper</del>ating systems, <del>middlew</del>a<del>re, a</del>nd applications. Security-related parameters are those parameters impacting the security state of <del>information </del>systems including the parameters required to satisfy other security control requirements. Security-related parameters include, for example<del>:</del><ins>,</ins> <del>(i) </del>registry settings; <del>(ii) </del>account, file, directory permission settings; and <del>(iii) </del>settings for functions, ports, protocols, <del>services, </del>and remote connections. Organizations establish organization-wide configuration settings and subsequently derive specific <ins>configuration </ins>settings for <del>information </del>systems. The established settings become part of the systems configuration baseline. Common secure configurations (also referred to as security configuration checklists, lockdown and hardening guides, security reference guides, security technical implementation guides) provide recognized, standardized, and established benchmarks that stipulate secure configuration settings for specific information technology platforms/products and instructions for configuring those <del>information </del>system components to meet operational requirements. Common secure configurations can be developed by a variety of organizations including, for example, information technology product developers, manufacturers, vendors, consortia, academia, industry, federal agencies, and other organizations in the public and private sectors. <ins>Implementation of a specific common secure configuration may be mandated at the organizational or mission/business process level or may be mandated at a higher level including, for example, by a regulatory agency. </ins>Common secure configurations include the United States Government Configuration Baseline (USGCB) which affects the implementation of CM-6 and other controls such as AC-19 and CM-7. The Security Content Automation Protocol (SCAP) and the defined standards within the protocol <del>(e.g., Common Configuration Enumeration) </del>provide an effective method to uniquely identify, track, and control configuration settings. <del>OMB establishes federal policy on configuration requirements for federal information systems. </del>Related <del>c</del><ins>C</ins>ontrols: AC-<ins>3, AC-</ins>19, <ins>AU-2, AU-6, </ins>C<ins>A-9, C</ins>M-2, CM-3, CM-<ins>5, CM-</ins>7, <ins>CM-11, CP-7, CP-9, CP-10, IA-3, IA-5, PL-8, RA-5, </ins>S<ins>A-4, SA-5, SA-9, SC-18, SC-19, SC-28, SC-43, S</ins>I-<ins>2, SI-</ins>4<ins>, SI-6</ins>.

CM-7:supplement:<del>Information s</del><ins>S</ins>ystems <del>can </del>provide a wide variety of functions and services. Organizations <del>can utiliz</del>e<ins>mploy</ins> network scanning tools, intrusion detection and prevention systems, and end-point protection<ins> technologie</ins>s such as firewalls and host-based intrusion detection systems to identify and prevent the use of prohibited functions, p<del>o</del>r<ins>o</ins>t<ins>ocol</ins>s, p<del>r</del>o<ins>r</ins>t<del>ocol</del>s, and services. Related <del>c</del><ins>C</ins>ontrols: AC-<del>6</del><ins>3</ins>, <ins>A</ins>C<ins>-4, C</ins>M-2, <ins>CM-5, CM-11, </ins>RA-5, SA-<ins>4, SA-</ins>5, S<ins>A-9, SA-15, S</ins>C-7<ins>, SC-37. CM-7 (5):title:LEAST FUNCTIONALITY | AUTHORIZED SOFTWARE <del>/</del><ins>-</ins> WHITELISTING
CM-7 (5):text:<del>The organization:</del>
CM-7 (5) (a):text:<del>The organization: </del>Identif<del>ies</del><ins>y</ins> [Assignment: organization-defined software programs authorized to execute on the<del> information</del> system];
CM-7 (5) (b):text:<del>The organization: </del>Employ<del>s</del> a deny-all, permit-by-exception policy to allow the execution of authorized software programs on the<del> information</del> system; and
CM-7 (5) (c):text:<del>The organization: </del>Review<del>s</del> and update<del>s</del> the list of authorized software programs [Assignment: organization-defined frequency].
CM-7 (5):supplement:The process used to identify s<ins>pecific s</ins>oftware programs <ins>or en</ins>t<ins>ire categories of software programs t</ins>hat are authorized to execute on organizational <del>information </del>systems is commonly referred to as whitelisting. <del>I</del><ins>To effect comprehe</ins>n<ins>sive</ins> <ins>whitelisting </ins>a<ins>n</ins>d<ins> increase the strength of protection for attacks that bypass application level whitelisting, software programs may be </ins>d<ins>ecomposed </ins>i<ins>n</ins>t<ins>o and mon</ins>i<ins>t</ins>o<ins>red at multiple levels of detail. Software program levels of detail i</ins>n<ins>clude,</ins> <ins>for example, applica</ins>t<ins>i</ins>o<ins>ns,</ins> <ins>application programming interfaces, application modules, scripts, system processes, system services, kernel actions, registries, drivers, and dynamic link libraries. The concept of </ins>whitelisting<ins> may also be applied to user actions</ins>, <ins>p</ins>or<ins>ts, IP addresses, and media access control (MAC) addresses. Or</ins>ganizations consider verifying the integrity of white-listed software programs using, for example, cryptographic checksums, digital signatures, or hash functions. Verification of white-listed software can occur either prior to execution or at system startup. Related <del>c</del><ins>C</ins>ontrols: CM-2, CM-6, CM-8<ins>, CM-10</ins>, PM-5, SA-10, SC-34, SI-7.

CM-9 d:text:<del>Th</del><ins>D</ins>e<del> organization de</del>velop<del>s</del>, document<del>s</del>, and implement<del>s</del> a configuration management plan for the <del>information </del>system that: <del>Protect</del><ins>I</ins>s <del>th</del><ins>r</ins>e<del> conf</del><ins>v</ins>i<del>gur</del><ins>ewed </ins>a<del>tio</del>n<ins>d</ins> <del>m</del>a<del>nag</del><ins>pprov</ins>e<ins>d by [Assign</ins>ment<ins>:</ins> <del>pl</del><ins>org</ins>an<del> from un</del><ins>iz</ins>a<del>u</del>t<del>h</del><ins>i</ins>o<del>r</del><ins>n-def</ins>i<del>z</del><ins>n</ins>ed <del>di</del><ins>per</ins>s<del>c</del><ins>onne</ins>l<ins> </ins>o<del>su</del>r<ins> rol</ins>e<ins>s];</ins> and<del> modification.</del>
CM-9 e:text:<ins>Develop, document, and implement a configuration management plan for the system that: Protects the configuration management plan from unauthorized disclosure and modification.</ins>
CM-9:supplement:Configuration management plans satisfy the requirements in configuration management policies while being tailored to individual <del>information </del>systems. Such plans define <del>detailed </del>processes and procedures for how configuration management is used to support system development life cycle activities<del> at the information system level</del>. Configuration management plans are typically developed during the development<del>/</del><ins> </ins>a<ins>nd a</ins>cquisition phase of the system development life cycle. The plans describe how to move changes through change management processes, how to update configuration settings and baselines, how to maintain <del>information </del>system component inventories, how to control development, test, and operational environments, and how to develop, release, and update key documents. Organizations can employ templates to help ensure consistent and timely development and implementation of configuration management plans. Such templates can represent a master configuration management plan for the organization <del>at large </del>with subsets of the plan implemented on a system by system basis. Configuration management approval processes include designation of key management stakeholders responsible for reviewing and approving proposed changes to <del>information </del>systems, and personnel that conduct security impact analyses prior to the implementation of changes to the systems. Configuration items are the <del>information </del>system <del>ite</del><ins>co</ins>m<ins>ponent</ins>s (<ins>i.e., </ins>hardware, software, firmware, and documentation) to be configuration-managed. As <del>information </del>systems continue through the system development life cycle, new configuration items may be identified and some existing configuration items may no longer need to be under configuration control. Related <del>c</del><ins>C</ins>ontrols: CM-2, CM-3, CM-4, CM-5, CM-8, <ins>PL-2, </ins>SA-10<ins>, SI-12</ins>.
CM-9 (1):title:CONFIGURATION MANAGEMENT PLAN | ASSIGNMENT OF RESPONSIBILITY
CM-9 (1):text:<del>The organization a</del><ins>A</ins>ssign<del>s</del> responsibility for developing the configuration management process to organizational personnel that are not directly involved i<del>n informatio</del>n system development.
CM-9 (1):supplement:In the absence of dedicated configuration management teams assigned within organizations, system developers may be tasked to develop configuration management processes using personnel who are not directly involved in system development or integration. This separation of duties ensures that organizations establish and maintain a sufficient degree of independence between the <del>information </del>system development and integration processes and configuration management processes to facilitate quality control and more effective oversight<ins>. Related Controls: None</ins>.

CM-10 (1):title:SOFTWARE USAGE RESTRICTIONS | OPEN SOURCE SOFTWARE
CM-10 (1):text:<del>The organization e</del><ins>E</ins>stablish<del>es</del> the following restrictions on the use of open source software: [Assignment: organization-defined restrictions].
CM-10 (1):supplement:Open source software refers to software that is available in source code form. Certain software rights normally reserved for copyright holders are routinely provided under software license agreements that permit individuals to study, change, and improve the software. From a security perspective, the major advantage of open source software is that it provides organizations with the ability to examine the source code. However, there are also various licensing issues associated with open source software including, for example, the constraints on derivative use of such software.<ins> Related Controls: SI-7.</ins>

CM-11:supplement:If provided the necessary privileges, users have the ability to install software in organizational <del>information </del>systems. To maintain control over the types of software installed, organizations identify permitted and prohibited actions regarding software installation. Permitted software installations may include, for example, updates and security patches to existing software and downloading applications from organization-approved <del>"</del><ins>“</ins>app stores.<del>"</del><ins>”</ins> Prohibited software installations may include, for example, software with unknown or suspect pedigrees or software that organizations consider potentially malicious. The policies organizations select governing user-installed software may be organization-developed or provided by some external entity. Policy enforcement methods include procedural methods<del> (e.g.</del>, <del>periodic ex</del>a<del>mination of </del>u<del>ser accoun</del>t<del>s), aut</del>omated methods<del> (e.g.</del>, <del>c</del>o<del>nfigu</del>r<del>ation</del> <del>settings implemented on organizational information systems), or </del>both. CM-12:title:<ins>INFORMATION LOCATION</ins>
CM-12 a:text:<ins>Identify the location of [Assignment: organization-defined information] and the specific system components on which the information resides;</ins>
CM-12 b:text:<ins>Identify and document the users who have access to the system and system components where the information resides; and</ins>
CM-12 c:text:<ins>Document changes to the location (i.e., system or system components) where the information resides.</ins>
CM-12:supplement:<ins>This control addresses the need to understand where information is being processed and stored and is typically applied with respect to Controlled Unclassified Information (CUI). The National Archives and Records Administration defines the types of information that are categorized as CUI. Information location includes identifying where specific information types and associated information reside in the system components that compose organizational systems; and how information is being processed so that information flow can be understood and adequate protection and policy management provided for such information and system components. Related Controls: AC-3, AC-4, AC-6, AC-23, CM-8, PM-29, SC-4, SC-16, SC-28, SI-4, SI-7.</ins>

CP-2:title:CONTINGENCY PLAN

CP-2 a 5:text:<del>The organization: </del>Develop<del>s</del> a contingency plan for the <del>information </del>system that: Addresses eventual, full <del>information </del>system restoration without deterioration of the security <del>s</del>a<del>fegu</del><ins>nd priv</ins>a<ins>cy cont</ins>r<del>d</del><ins>ol</ins>s originally planned and implemented; and
CP-2 a 6:text:<del>The organization: </del>Develop<del>s</del> a contingency plan for the<del> information</del> system that: Is reviewed and approved by [Assignment: organization-defined personnel or roles];

CP-2 e:text:<del>The organization: </del>Updates the contingency plan to address changes to the organization,<del> information</del> system, or environment of operation and problems encountered during contingency plan implementation, execution, or testing;
CP-2 f:text:<del>The organization: </del>Communicates contingency plan changes to [Assignment: organization-defined key contingency personnel (identified by name and/or by role) and organizational elements]; and
