CP-2:supplement:Contingency planning for <del>information </del>systems is part of an overall organizational program for achieving continuity of operations for mission/business functions. Contingency planning addresses <del>both information </del>system restoration and implementation of alternative mission<del>/</del><ins> or </ins>business processes when systems are compromised<ins> or breached</ins>. The effectiveness of contingency planning is maximized by considering such planning throughout the <del>pha</del>s<del>es of the s</del>ystem development life cycle. Performing contingency planning on hardware, software, and firmware development can be an effective means of achieving <del>information </del>system resiliency. Contingency plans reflect the degree of restoration required for organizational <del>information </del>systems since not all systems <del>may </del>need to fully recover to achieve the level of continuity of operations desired. <del>Information s</del><ins>S</ins>ystem recovery objectives reflect applicable laws, Executive Orders, directives, policies, standards, regulations, and guidelines. In addition to <del>inform</del>a<del>tion system a</del>vailability, contingency plans a<del>lso a</del>ddress other security-related events resulting in a reduction in mission <del>and/</del>or business effectiveness, such as malicious attacks compromising the confidentiality or integrity of <del>information </del>systems. Actions addressed in contingency plans include, for example, orderly<del>/</del><ins> and </ins>graceful degradation, <del>information </del>system shutdown, fallback to a manual mode, alternate information flows, and operating in modes reserved for when systems are under attack. By c<del>l</del>o<del>sely c</del>o<del>o</del>rdinating contingency planning with incident handling activities, organizations can ensure that the necessary <del>contingency </del>planning activities are in place and activated in the event of a security incident. Related <del>c</del><ins>C</ins>ontrols: <del>A</del>C<ins>P</ins>-<del>1</del><ins>3, CP-</ins>4, CP-6, CP-7, CP-8, CP-9, CP-10, <ins>CP-11, CP-13, </ins>IR-4, IR-<ins>6, IR-</ins>8, <ins>IR-9, </ins>M<ins>A-6, M</ins>P-2, MP-4, MP-5, P<ins>L-2, P</ins>M-8, PM-11<ins>, SA-15, SA-20, SC-7, SC-23, SI-12</ins>.
CP-2 (1):title:CONTINGENCY PLAN | COORDINATE WITH RELATED PLANS
CP-2 (1):text:<del>The </del><ins>C</ins>o<del>rganizati</del>o<del>n coo</del>rdinate<del>s</del> contingency plan development with organizational elements responsible for related plans.
CP-2 (1):supplement:Plans related to contingency plans for organizational <del>information </del>systems include, for example, Business Continuity Plans, Disaster Recovery Plans, Continuity of Operations Plans, Crisis Communications Plans, Critical Infrastructure Plans, Cyber Incident Response Plans, Insider Threat Implementation Plan, and Occupant Emergency Plans<ins>. Related Controls: None</ins>.
CP-2 (2):title:CONTINGENCY PLAN | CAPACITY PLANNING
CP-2 (2):text:<del>The </del><ins>C</ins>o<del>rga</del>n<del>ization con</del>duct<del>s</del> capacity planning so that necessary capacity for information processing, telecommunications, and environmental support exists during contingency operations.
CP-2 (2):supplement:Capacity planning is needed because different types of threats <del>(e.g., natural disasters, targeted </del>c<del>yber </del>a<del>ttacks) ca</del>n result in a reduction of the available processing, telecommunications, and support services <del>or</del>i<del>gi</del>n<del>ally in</del>tended to support the organizational missions<del>/</del><ins> and </ins>business functions. Organizations <del>may </del>need to anticipate degraded operations during contingency operations and factor such degradation into capacity planning<ins>. With respect to capacity planning, environmental support refers to any environmental support factor for which the organization determines that it needs to provide support in a contingency situation, even if in a degraded state. As always, such determinations are based on an assessment of risk, system categorization (impact level), and organizational risk tolerance. Related Controls: PE-11, PE-12, PE-13, PE-14, PE-18, SC-5</ins>.

CP-2 (7):title:CONTINGENCY PLAN | COORDINATE <del> </del>WITH EXTERNAL SERVICE PROVIDERS
CP-2 (7):text:<del>The </del><ins>C</ins>o<del>rganizati</del>o<del>n coo</del>rdinate<del>s</del> <del>i</del>t<del>s</del><ins>he</ins> contingency plan with the contingency plans of external service providers to ensure that contingency requirements can be satisfied.
CP-2 (7):supplement:When the capability of an organization to successfully carry out its core missions<del>/</del><ins> and </ins>business functions is dependent on external service providers, developing a timely and comprehensive contingency plan may become more challenging. In this situation, organizations coordinate contingency planning activities with the external entities to ensure that the individual plans reflect the overall contingency needs of the organization. Related <del>c</del><ins>C</ins>ontrol<ins>s</ins>: SA-9.
CP-2 (8):title:CONTINGENCY PLAN | IDENTIFY CRITICAL ASSETS
CP-2 (8):text:<del>The organization i</del><ins>I</ins>dentif<del>ies</del><ins>y</ins> critical<del> information</del> system assets supporting essential missions and business functions.
CP-2 (8):supplement:Organizations may choose to carry out the contingency planning activities in this control enhancement as part of organizational <ins>criticality analysis or </ins>business continuity planning including, for example, as part of business impact analyses. Organizations identify critical <del>information </del>system assets so <del>th</del>a<del>t a</del>dditional safeguards and countermeasures can be employed (<del>a</del>b<del>ov</del>e<del> and be</del>yond those safeguards and countermeasures routinely implemented) to help ensure that organizational missions/business functions can continue to be conducted during contingency operations. <del>In addition, t</del><ins>T</ins>he identification of critical information assets <ins>also </ins>facilitates the prioritization of organizational resources. Critical <del>information </del>system assets include <ins>bo</ins>t<ins>h t</ins>echnical and operational aspects. Technical aspects include, for example, information technology services, <del>information </del>system components, information technology products, and mechanisms. Operational aspects include, for example, procedures (manually executed operations) and personnel (individuals operating technical safeguards and/or executing manual procedures). Organizational program protection plans can <del>prov</del><ins>a</ins>id<del>e</del> <del>ass</del>i<del>sta</del>n<del>ce</del> i<del>n i</del>dentifying critical assets. CP-3:title:CONTINGENCY TRAINING
CP-3:text:<del>The o</del><ins>P</ins>r<del>ganizati</del>o<del>n pro</del>vide<del>s</del> contingency training to<del> information</del> system users consistent with assigned roles and responsibilities:
CP-3 a:text:<del>The o</del><ins>P</ins>r<del>ganizati</del>o<del>n pro</del>vide<del>s</del> contingency training to <del>information </del>system users consistent with assigned roles and responsibilities: Within [Assignment: organization-defined time<del> </del><ins>-</ins>period] of assuming a contingency role or responsibility;
CP-3 b:text:<del>The o</del><ins>P</ins>r<del>ganizati</del>o<del>n pro</del>vide<del>s</del> contingency training to <del>information </del>system users consistent with assigned roles and responsibilities: When required by<del> information</del> system changes; and
CP-3 c:text:<del>The o</del><ins>P</ins>r<del>ganizati</del>o<del>n pro</del>vide<del>s</del> contingency training to<del> information</del> system users consistent with assigned roles and responsibilities: [Assignment: organization-defined frequency] thereafter.
CP-3:supplement:Contingency training provided by organizations is linked to the assigned roles and responsibilities of organizational personnel to ensure that the appropriate content and level of detail is included in such training. For example, regular users may only need to know when and where to report for duty during contingency operations and if normal duties are affected; system administrators may require additional training on how to set up <del>information </del>systems at alternate processing and storage sites; and managers/senior leaders may receive more specific training on how to conduct mission-essential functions in designated off-site locations and how to establish communications with other governmental entities for purposes of coordination on contingency-related activities. Training for contingency roles/responsibilities reflects the specific continuity requirements in the contingency plan. Related <del>c</del><ins>C</ins>ontrols: AT-2, AT-3, <ins>AT-4, </ins>CP-2, <ins>CP-4, CP-8, </ins>IR-2<ins>, IR-4, IR-9</ins>.

CP-4:title:CONTINGENCY PLAN TESTING
CP-4:text:<del>The organization:</del>
CP-4 a:text:T<del>h</del>e<del> organization: Te</del>st<del>s</del> the contingency plan for the<del> information</del> system [Assignment: organization-defined frequency] using [Assignment: organization-defined tests] to determine the effectiveness of the plan and the organizational readiness to execute the plan;
CP-4 b:text:<del>The organization: </del>Review<del>s</del> the contingency plan test results; and
CP-4 c:text:<del>The organization: </del>Initiate<del>s</del> corrective actions, if needed.
CP-4:supplement:Methods for testing contingency plans to determine the effectiveness of the plans and to identify potential weaknesses in the plans include, for example, walk-through and tabletop exercises, checklists, simulations (parallel, full interrupt), and comprehensive exercises. Organizations conduct testing based on the continuity requirements in contingency plans and include a determination of the effects on organizational operations, assets, and individuals arising due to contingency operations. Organizations have flexibility and discretion in the breadth, depth, and timelines of corrective actions. Related <del>c</del><ins>C</ins>ontrols: <ins>AT-3, </ins>CP-2, CP-3, <ins>CP-8, CP-9, </ins>IR-3<ins>, IR-4, PL-2, PM-14</ins>.

This control enhancement does not require organizations to create organizational elements to handle related plans or to align such elements with specific plans. It does require, however, that if such organizational elements are responsible for related plans, organizations should coordinate with those elements. CP-6:title:ALTERNATE STORAGE SITE
CP-6:text:<del>The organization:</del>
CP-6 a:text:<del>The organization: </del>Establish<del>es</del> an alternate storage site including necessary agreements to permit the storage and retrieval of<del> information</del> system backup information; and
CP-6 b:text:<del>The organization: </del>Ensure<del>s</del> that the alternate storage site provides <del>information </del>security <del>safegua</del><ins>cont</ins>r<del>d</del><ins>ol</ins>s equivalent to that of the primary site.
CP-6:supplement:Alternate storage sites are sites that are geographically distinct from primary storage sites. An alternate storage site maintains duplicate copies of information and data i<del>n</del><ins>f</ins> the <del>event that the </del>primary storage site is not available. Items covered by alternate storage site agreements include, for example, environmental conditions at alternate sites, access rules, physical and environmental protection requirements, and coordination of delivery/retrieval of backup media. Alternate storage sites reflect the requirements in contingency plans so that organizations can maintain essential missions<del>/</del><ins> and </ins>business functions despite disruption, compromise, or failure in organizational <del>information </del>systems. Related <del>c</del><ins>C</ins>ontrols: CP-2, CP-7, CP-<ins>8, CP-</ins>9, CP-10, MP-4<ins>, MP-5, PE-3, SC-36, SI-13</ins>.
CP-6 (1):title:ALTERNATE STORAGE SITE | SEPARATION FROM PRIMARY SITE
CP-6 (1):text:<del>The organization i</del><ins>I</ins>dentif<del>ies</del><ins>y</ins> an alternate storage site that is separated from the primary storage site to reduce susceptibility to the same threats.
CP-6 (1):supplement:Threats that affect alternate storage sites are <del>typically </del>defined in organizational assessments of risk and include, for example, natural disasters, structural failures, hostile <del>cyber </del>attacks, and errors of omission<del>/</del><ins> or </ins>commission. Organizations determine what is considered a sufficient degree of separation between primary and alternate storage sites based on the types of threats that are of concern. For <del>one par</del>t<del>icular type of t</del>hreat<ins>s</ins> <del>(i.e.,</del><ins>such</ins> <ins>as </ins>hostile <del>cyber </del>attack<del>)</del><ins>s</ins>, the degree of separation between sites is less relevant. Related <del>c</del><ins>C</ins>ontrol<ins>s</ins>: RA-3.
CP-6 (2):title:ALTERNATE STORAGE SITE | RECOVERY TIME <del>/</del><ins>AND RECOVERY</ins> POINT OBJECTIVES
CP-6 (2):text:<del>The </del><ins>C</ins>o<del>rga</del>n<del>ization con</del>figure<del>s</del> the alternate storage site to facilitate recovery operations in accordance with recovery time and recovery point objectives.
CP-6 (2):supplement:<ins>None. Related Controls: None.</ins>
CP-6 (3):title:ALTERNATE STORAGE SITE | ACCESSIBILITY
CP-6 (3):text:<del>The organization i</del><ins>I</ins>dentif<del>ies</del><ins>y</ins> potential accessibility problems to the alternate storage site in the event of an area-wide disruption or disaster and outlines explicit mitigation actions.
CP-6 (3):supplement:Area-wide disruptions refer to those types of disruptions that are broad in geographic scope <del>(e.g., hurricane, regional po</del>w<del>er outage) w</del>ith such determinations made by organizations based on organizational assessments of risk. Explicit mitigation actions include, for example<del>:</del><ins>,</ins> <del>(i) </del>duplicating backup information at other alternate storage sites if access problems occur at originally designated alternate sites; or <del>(ii) </del>planning for physical access to retrieve backup information if electronic accessibility to the alternate site is disrupted. Related <del>c</del><ins>C</ins>ontrol<ins>s</ins>: RA-3.

CP-7 (3):supplement:Priority-of-service agreements refer to negotiated agreements with service providers that ensure that organizations receive priority treatment consistent with their availability requirements and the availability of information resources at the alternate processing site.<ins> Related Controls: None.</ins>

CP-7 (4):supplement:Site preparation includes, for example, establishing configuration settings for <del>information </del>system components at the alternate processing site consistent with the requirements for such settings at the primary site and ensuring that essential supplies and other logistical considerations are in place. CP-8:title:TELECOMMUNICATIONS SERVICES
CP-8:text:<del>The organization e</del><ins>E</ins>stablish<del>es</del> alternate telecommunications services including necessary agreements to permit the resumption of [Assignment: organization-defined <del>information </del>system operations] for essential missions and business functions within [Assignment: organization-defined time<del> </del><ins>-</ins>period] when the primary telecommunications capabilities are unavailable at either the primary or alternate processing or storage sites.
CP-8:supplement:This control applies to telecommunications services (data and voice) for primary and alternate processing and storage sites. Alternate telecommunications services reflect the continuity requirements in contingency plans to maintain essential missions<del>/</del><ins> and </ins>business functions despite the loss of primary telecommunications services. Organizations may specify different time<del> </del><ins>-</ins>periods for primary/alternate sites. Alternate telecommunications services include, for example, additional organizational or commercial ground-based circuits/lines or satellites in lieu of ground-based communications. Organizations consider factors such as availability, quality of service, and access when entering <del>into </del>alternate telecommunications agreements. Related <del>c</del><ins>C</ins>ontrols: CP-2, CP-6, CP<ins>-7, CP-11, SC</ins>-7.
CP-8 (1):title:TELECOMMUNICATIONS SERVICES | PRIORITY OF SERVICE PROVISIONS
CP-8 (1):text:<del>The organization:</del>
CP-8 (1) (a):text:<del>The organization: </del>Develop<del>s</del> primary and alternate telecommunications service agreements that contain priority-of-service provisions in accordance with organizational availability requirements (including recovery time objectives); and
CP-8 (1) (b):text:<del>The organization: </del>Request<del>s</del> Telecommunications Service Priority for all telecommunications services used for national security emergency preparedness i<del>n the event that</del><ins>f</ins> the primary and/or alternate telecommunications services are provided by a common carrier.
CP-8 (1):supplement:Organizations consider the potential mission/business impact in situations where telecommunications service providers are servicing other organizations with similar priority-of-service provisions.<ins> Related Controls: None.</ins>
CP-8 (2):title:TELECOMMUNICATIONS SERVICES | SINGLE POINTS OF FAILURE
CP-8 (2):text:<del>The organization o</del><ins>O</ins>btain<del>s</del> alternate telecommunications services to reduce the likelihood of sharing a single point of failure with primary telecommunications services.
CP-8 (2):supplement:<ins>None. Related Controls: None.</ins>
CP-8 (3):title:TELECOMMUNICATIONS SERVICES | SEPARATION OF PRIMARY <del>/</del><ins>AND</ins> ALTERNATE PROVIDERS
CP-8 (3):text:<del>The organization o</del><ins>O</ins>btain<del>s</del> alternate telecommunications services from providers that are separated from primary service providers to reduce susceptibility to the same threats.
CP-8 (3):supplement:Threats that affect telecommunications services are typically defined in organizational assessments of risk and include, for example, natural disasters, structural failures, hostile cyber/physical attacks, and errors of omission/commission. Organizations seek to reduce common susceptibilities by, for example, minimizing shared infrastructure among telecommunications service providers and achieving sufficient geographic separation between services. Organizations may consider using a single service provider in situations where the service provider can provide alternate telecommunications services meeting the separation needs addressed in the risk assessment.<ins> Related Controls: None.</ins>
CP-8 (4):title:TELECOMMUNICATIONS SERVICES | PROVIDER CONTINGENCY PLAN
CP-8 (4):text:<del>The organization:</del>
CP-8 (4) (a):text:<del>The organization: </del>Require<del>s</del> primary and alternate telecommunications service providers to have contingency plans;
CP-8 (4) (b):text:<del>The organization: </del>Review<del>s</del> provider contingency plans to ensure that the plans meet organizational contingency requirements; and
CP-8 (4) (c):text:<del>The organization: </del>Obtain<del>s</del> evidence of contingency testing<del>/</del><ins> and </ins>training by providers [Assignment: organization-defined frequency].
CP-8 (4):supplement:Reviews of provider contingency plans consider the proprietary nature of such plans. In some situations, a summary of provider contingency plans may be sufficient evidence for organizations to satisfy the review requirement. Telecommunications service providers may also participate in ongoing disaster recovery exercises in coordination with the Department of Homeland Security, state, and local governments. Organizations may use these types of activities to satisfy evidentiary requirements related to service provider contingency plan reviews, testing, and training.<ins> Related Controls: CP-3, CP-4.</ins>

CP-8 (5):text:T<del>h</del>e<del> organization te</del>st<del>s</del> alternate telecommunication services [Assignment: organization-defined frequency].
CP-8 (5):supplement:<ins>CP-3. Related Controls: None.</ins>

CP-9 c:text:<del>The organization: </del>Conduct<del>s</del> backups of<del> information</del> system documentation including security-related documentation [Assignment: organization-defined frequency consistent with recovery time and recovery point objectives]; and
CP-9 d:text:<del>The organization: </del>Protect<del>s</del> the confidentiality, integrity, and availability of backup information at storage locations.
CP-9:supplement:System-level information includes, for example, system-state information, operating system <ins>softw</ins>a<del>nd</del><ins>re,</ins> application software, and licenses. User-level information includes any information other than system-level information. Mechanisms employed <del>by organiza</del>t<del>i</del>o<del>ns</del> <del>to </del>protect the integrity of <del>information </del>system backups include, for example, digital signatures and cryptographic hashes. Protection of <del>system </del>backup information while in transit is beyond the scope of this control. <del>Information s</del><ins>S</ins>ystem backups reflect the requirements in contingency plans as well as other organizational requirements for backing up information. Related <del>c</del><ins>C</ins>ontrols: CP-2, CP-6, <ins>CP-10, </ins>MP-4, MP-5, SC<ins>-13, SI-4, SI</ins>-13.

CP-9 (3):title:<del>INFORMATION </del>SYSTEM BACKUP | SEPARATE STORAGE FOR CRITICAL INFORMATION
CP-9 (3):text:<del>The organiza</del><ins>S</ins>t<del>i</del>o<del>n sto</del>re<del>s</del> backup copies of [Assignment: organization-defined critical<del> information</del> system software and other security-related information] in a separate facility or in a fire-rated container that is not collocated with the operational system.

CP-9 (7):title:<del>INFORMATION </del>SYSTEM BACKUP | DUAL AUTHORIZATION
CP-9 (7):text:<del>The orga</del><ins>E</ins>n<del>ization en</del>force<del>s</del> dual authorization for the deletion or destruction of [Assignment: organization-defined backup information].
CP-9 (7):supplement:Dual authorization ensures that the deletion or destruction of backup information cannot occur unless two qualified individuals carry out the task. Individuals deleting/destroying backup information possess sufficient skills/expertise to determine if the proposed deletion/destruction of backup information reflects organizational policies and procedures. Dual authorization may also be known as two-person control. Related <del>c</del><ins>C</ins>ontrols: AC-3<ins>, AC-5</ins>, MP-2.
CP-9 (8):title:<ins>SYSTEM BACKUP | CRYPTOGRAPHIC PROTECTION</ins>
CP-9 (8):text:<ins>Implement cryptographic mechanisms to prevent unauthorized disclosure and modification of [Assignment: organization-defined backup information].</ins>
CP-9 (8):supplement:<ins>The selection of cryptographic mechanisms is based on the need to protect the confidentiality and integrity of backup information. The strength of mechanism is commensurate with the security category and/or classification of the information. This control enhancement applies to system backup information in storage at primary and alternate locations. Organizations implementing cryptographic mechanisms to protect information at rest also consider cryptographic key management solutions. Related Controls: SC-12, SC-13, SC-28.</ins>

CP-10:title:<del>INFORMATION </del>SYSTEM RECOVERY AND RECONSTITUTION
CP-10:text:<del>The o</del><ins>P</ins>r<del>ganizati</del>o<del>n pro</del>vide<del>s</del> for the recovery and reconstitution of the <del>information </del>system to a known state after a disruption, compromise, or failure<ins> within [Assignment: organization-defined time-period consistent with recovery time and recovery point objectives]</ins>.
CP-10:supplement:Recovery is executing <del>information system </del>contingency plan activities to restore organizational missions<del>/</del><ins> and </ins>business functions. Reconstitution takes place following recovery and includes activities for returning <del>organizational information </del>systems to fully operational states. Recovery and reconstitution operations reflect mission and business priorities, recovery point<del>/</del><ins>, </ins>time<ins>,</ins> and reconstitution objectives, and established organizational metrics consistent with contingency plan requirements. Reconstitution includes the deactivation of any interim <del>information </del>system capabilities that may have been needed during recovery operations. Reconstitution also includes assessments of fully restored <del>information </del>system capabilities, reestablishment of continuous monitoring activities, <del>potential information </del>system reauthorizations<ins> (if required)</ins>, and activities to prepare the systems against future disruptions, compromises, or failures. Recovery<del>/</del><ins> and </ins>reconstitution capabilities employed by organizations can include both automated mechanisms and manual procedures. Related <del>c</del><ins>C</ins>ontrols: C<del>A</del><ins>P</ins>-2, C<del>A-6, CA-7, C</del>P-<del>2</del><ins>4</ins>, CP-6, CP-7, CP-9, <ins>IR-4, </ins>SC-24<ins>, SI-13</ins>.

CP-12:title:SAFE MODE

CP-12:supplement:For <del>information </del>systems supporting critical missions<del>/</del><ins> and </ins>business functions including, for example, military operations and weapons systems, civilian space operations, nuclear power plant operations, and air traffic control operations (especially real-time operational environments), organizations <del>m</del><ins>c</ins>a<del>y</del><ins>n</ins> <del>choose to </del>identify certain conditions under which those systems revert to a predefined safe mode of operation. CP-13:title:ALTERNATIVE SECURITY MECHANISMS
CP-13:text:<del>The organization e</del><ins>E</ins>mploy<del>s</del> [Assignment: organization-defined alternative or supplemental security mechanisms] for satisfying [Assignment: organization-defined security functions] when the primary means of implementing the security function is unavailable or compromised.
CP-13:supplement:This control supports <del>information </del>system resiliency<ins>,</ins> <del>and </del>contingency planning<del>/</del><ins>, and </ins>continuity of operations. To ensure mission<del>/</del><ins> and </ins>business continuity, organizations can implement alternative or supplemental security mechanisms. These mechanisms may be less effective than the primary mechanisms<del> (e</del>.<del>g.,</del> <del>not as easy to use, not as scalable, or not as secure). </del>However, having the capability to readily employ these alternative<del>/</del><ins> or </ins>supplemental mechanisms<ins>,</ins> enhances <del>overall </del>mission<del>/</del><ins> and </ins>business continuity that might otherwise be adversely impacted if o<del>rganizational o</del>perations had to be curtailed until the primary means of implementing the functions was restored. Given the cost and level of effort required to provide such alternative capabilities, this control <del>would</del><ins>is</ins> typically <del>be </del>applied only to critical security capabilities provided by <del>information </del>systems, system components, or <del>information </del>system services. For example, an organization may issue to senior executives and system administrators one-time pads i<del>n</del><ins>f</ins> <del>case </del>multifactor tokens, the <del>organization'</del>s<del> s</del>tandard means for secure remote authentication, is compromised. Related <del>c</del><ins>C</ins>ontrol<ins>s</ins>: CP-2<ins> CP-11, SI-13</ins>.

DI-1:title:<del>DATA QUALITY</del>
DI-1:text:<del>The organization:</del>
DI-1 a:text:<del>The organization: Confirms to the greatest extent practicable upon collection or creation of personally identifiable information (PII), the accuracy, relevance, timeliness, and completeness of that information;</del>
DI-1 b:text:<del>The organization: Collects PII directly from the individual to the greatest extent practicable;</del>
DI-1 c:text:<del>The organization: Checks for, and corrects as necessary, any inaccurate or outdated PII used by its programs or systems [Assignment: organization-defined frequency]; and</del>
DI-1 d:text:<del>The organization: Issues guidelines ensuring and maximizing the quality, utility, objectivity, and integrity of disseminated information.</del>
DI-1:supplement:<del>Organizations take reasonable steps to confirm the accuracy and relevance of PII. Such steps may include, for example, editing and validating addresses as they are collected or entered into information systems using automated address verification look-up application programming interfaces (API). The types of measures taken to protect data quality are based on the nature and context of the PII, how it is to be used, and how it was obtained. Measures taken to validate the accuracy of PII that is used to make determinations about the rights, benefits, or privileges of individuals under federal programs may be more comprehensive than those used to validate less sensitive PII. Additional steps may be necessary to validate PII that is obtained from sources other than individuals or the authorized representatives of individuals. When PII is of a sufficiently sensitive nature (e.g., when it is used for annual reconfirmation of a taxpayer's income for a recurring benefit), organizations incorporate mechanisms into information systems and develop corresponding procedures for how frequently, and by what method, the information is to be updated. Related controls: AP-2, DI-2, DM-1, IP-3, SI-10.</del>
DI-1 (1):title:<del>DATA QUALITY | VALIDATE PII</del>
DI-1 (1):text:<del>The organization requests that the individual or individual's authorized representative validate PII during the collection process.</del>
DI-1 (2):title:<del>DATA QUALITY | RE-VALIDATE PII</del>
DI-1 (2):text:<del>The organization requests that the individual or individual's authorized representative revalidate that PII collected is still accurate [Assignment: organization-defined frequency].</del>
DI-1:references:<del>The Privacy Act of 1974, 5 U.S.C. § 552a (c) and (e); Treasury and General Government Appropriations Act for Fiscal Year 2001 (P.L. 106-554), app C § 515, 114 Stat. 2763A-153-4; Paperwork Reduction Act, 44 U.S.C. § 3501; OMB Guidelines for Ensuring and Maximizing the Quality, Objectivity, Utility, and Integrity of Information Disseminated by Federal Agencies (October 2001); OMB Memorandum 07-16</del>
DI-2:title:<del>DATA INTEGRITY AND DATA INTEGRITY BOARD</del>
DI-2:text:<del>The organization:</del>
DI-2 a:text:<del>The organization: Documents processes to ensure the integrity of personally identifiable information (PII) through existing security controls; and</del>
DI-2 b:text:<del>The organization: Establishes a Data Integrity Board when appropriate to oversee organizational Computer Matching Agreements and to ensure that those agreements comply with the computer matching provisions of the Privacy Act.</del>
DI-2:supplement:<del>Organizations conducting or participating in Computer Matching Agreements with other organizations regarding applicants for and recipients of financial assistance or payments under federal benefit programs or regarding certain computerized comparisons involving federal personnel or payroll records establish a Data Integrity Board to oversee and coordinate their implementation of such matching agreements. In many organizations, the Data Integrity Board is led by the Senior Agency Official for Privacy (SAOP)/Chief Privacy Officer (CPO). The Data Integrity Board ensures that controls are in place to maintain both the quality and the integrity of data shared under Computer Matching Agreements. Related controls: AC-1, AC-3, AC-4, AC-6, AC-17, AC-22, AU-2, AU-3, AU-6, AU-10, AU-11, DI-1, SC-8, SC-28, UL-2.</del>
DI-2 (1):title:<del>DATA INTEGRITY AND DATA INTEGRITY BOARD | PUBLISH AGREEMENTS ON WEBSITE</del>
DI-2 (1):text:<del>The organization publishes Computer Matching Agreements on its public website.</del>
DI-2:references:<del>The Privacy Act of 1974, 5 U.S.C. §§ 552a (a)(8)(A), (o), (p), (u); OMB Circular A-130, Appendix I</del>
DM-1:title:<del>MINIMIZATION OF PERSONALLY IDENTIFIABLE INFORMATION</del>
DM-1:text:<del>The organization:</del>
DM-1 a:text:<del>The organization: Identifies the minimum personally identifiable information (PII) elements that are relevant and necessary to accomplish the legally authorized purpose of collection;</del>
DM-1 b:text:<del>The organization: Limits the collection and retention of PII to the minimum elements identified for the purposes described in the notice and for which the individual has provided consent; and</del>
DM-1 c:text:<del>The organization: Conducts an initial evaluation of PII holdings and establishes and follows a schedule for regularly reviewing those holdings [Assignment: organization-defined frequency, at least annually] to ensure that only PII identified in the notice is collected and retained, and that the PII continues to be necessary to accomplish the legally authorized purpose.</del>
DM-1:supplement:<del>Organizations take appropriate steps to ensure that the collection of PII is consistent with a purpose authorized by law or regulation. The minimum set of PII elements required to support a specific organization business process may be a subset of the PII the organization is authorized to collect. Program officials consult with the Senior Agency Official for Privacy (SAOP)/Chief Privacy Officer (CPO) and legal counsel to identify the minimum PII elements required by the information system or activity to accomplish the legally authorized purpose. Organizations can further reduce their privacy and security risks by also reducing their inventory of PII, where appropriate. OMB Memorandum 07-16 requires organizations to conduct both an initial review and subsequent reviews of their holdings of all PII and ensure, to the maximum extent practicable, that such holdings are accurate, relevant, timely, and complete. Organizations are also directed by OMB to reduce their holdings to the minimum necessary for the proper performance of a documented organizational business purpose. OMB Memorandum 07-16 requires organizations to develop and publicize, either through a notice in the Federal Register or on their websites, a schedule for periodic reviews of their holdings to supplement the initial review. Organizations coordinate with their federal records officers to ensure that reductions in organizational holdings of PII are consistent with NARA retention schedules. By performing periodic evaluations, organizations reduce risk, ensure that they are collecting only the data specified in the notice, and ensure that the data collected is still relevant and necessary for the purpose(s) specified in the notice. Related controls: AP-1, AP-2, AR-4, IP-1, SE-1, SI-12, TR-1.</del>
DM-1 (1):title:<del>MINIMIZATION OF PERSONALLY IDENTIFIABLE INFORMATION | LOCATE / REMOVE / REDACT / ANONYMIZE PII</del>
DM-1 (1):text:<del>The organization, where feasible and within the limits of technology, locates and removes/redacts specified PII and/or uses anonymization and de-identification techniques to permit use of the retained information while reducing its sensitivity and reducing the risk resulting from disclosure.</del>
DM-1 (1):supplement:<del>NIST Special Publication 800-122 provides guidance on anonymization.</del>
DM-1:references:<del>The Privacy Act of 1974, 5 U.S.C. §552a (e); Section 208(b), E-Government Act of 2002 (P.L. 107-347); OMB Memoranda 03-22, 07-16</del>
DM-2:title:<del>DATA RETENTION AND DISPOSAL</del>
DM-2:text:<del>The organization:</del>
DM-2 a:text:<del>The organization: Retains each collection of personally identifiable information (PII) for [Assignment: organization-defined time period] to fulfill the purpose(s) identified in the notice or as required by law;</del>
DM-2 b:text:<del>The organization: Disposes of, destroys, erases, and/or anonymizes the PII, regardless of the method of storage, in accordance with a NARA-approved record retention schedule and in a manner that prevents loss, theft, misuse, or unauthorized access; and</del>
DM-2 c:text:<del>The organization: Uses [Assignment: organization-defined techniques or methods] to ensure secure deletion or destruction of PII (including originals, copies, and archived records).</del>
DM-2:supplement:<del>NARA provides retention schedules that govern the disposition of federal records. Program officials coordinate with records officers and with NARA to identify appropriate retention periods and disposal methods. NARA may require organizations to retain PII longer than is operationally needed. In those situations, organizations describe such requirements in the notice. Methods of storage include, for example, electronic, optical media, or paper. Examples of ways organizations may reduce holdings include reducing the types of PII held (e.g., delete Social Security numbers if their use is no longer needed) or shortening the retention period for PII that is maintained if it is no longer necessary to keep PII for long periods of time (this effort is undertaken in consultation with an organization's records officer to receive NARA approval). In both examples, organizations provide notice (e.g., an updated System of Records Notice) to inform the public of any changes in holdings of PII. Certain read-only archiving techniques, such as DVDs, CDs, microfilm, or microfiche, may not permit the removal of individual records without the destruction of the entire database contained on such media. Related controls: AR-4, AU-11, DM-1, MP-1, MP-2, MP-3, MP-4, MP-5, MP-6, MP-7, MP-8, SI-12, TR-1.</del>
DM-2 (1):title:<del>DATA RETENTION AND DISPOSAL | SYSTEM CONFIGURATION</del>
DM-2 (1):text:<del>The organization, where feasible, configures its information systems to record the date PII is collected, created, or updated and when PII is to be deleted or archived under an approved record retention schedule.</del>
DM-2:references:<del>The Privacy Act of 1974, 5 U.S.C. § 552a (e)(1), (c)(2); Section 208 (e), E-Government Act of 2002 (P.L. 107-347); 44 U.S.C. Chapters 29, 31, 33; OMB Memorandum 07-16; OMB Circular A-130; NIST Special Publication 800-88</del>
DM-3:title:<del>MINIMIZATION OF PII USED IN TESTING, TRAINING, AND RESEARCH</del>
DM-3:text:<del>The organization:</del>
DM-3 a:text:<del>The organization: Develops policies and procedures that minimize the use of personally identifiable information (PII) for testing, training, and research; and</del>
DM-3 b:text:<del>The organization: Implements controls to protect PII used for testing, training, and research.</del>
DM-3:supplement:<del>Organizations often use PII for testing new applications or information systems prior to deployment. Organizations also use PII for research purposes and for training. The use of PII in testing, research, and training increases risk of unauthorized disclosure or misuse of the information. If PII must be used, organizations take measures to minimize any associated risks and to authorize the use of and limit the amount of PII for these purposes. Organizations consult with the SAOP/CPO and legal counsel to ensure that the use of PII in testing, training, and research is compatible with the original purpose for which it was collected.</del>
DM-3 (1):title:<del>MINIMIZATION OF PII USED IN TESTING, TRAINING, AND RESEARCH | RISK MINIMIZATION TECHNIQUES</del>
DM-3 (1):text:<del>The organization, where feasible, uses techniques to minimize the risk to privacy of using PII for research, testing, or training.</del>
DM-3 (1):supplement:<del>Organizations can minimize risk to privacy of PII by using techniques such as de-identification.</del>
DM-3:references:<del>NIST Special Publication 800-122</del>

IA-2:title:IDENTIFICATION AND AUTHENTICATION (ORGANIZATIONAL USERS)
IA-2:text:<del>The i</del><ins>U</ins>n<del>format</del>i<del>on system uni</del>quely identif<del>ies</del><ins>y</ins> and authenticate<del>s</del> organizational users <del>(</del>or processes acting on behalf of organizational users<del>)</del>.
IA-2:supplement:Organization<ins>s c</ins>a<ins>n satisfy the identification and authentication requirements in this contro</ins>l <ins>by complying with the req</ins>u<ins>irement</ins>s<ins> in Hom</ins>e<ins>land Secu</ins>r<ins>ity Pre</ins>s<ins>idential</ins> <ins>D</ins>i<ins>rective 12. Orga</ins>n<ins>izational users in</ins>clude employees or individuals that organizations <ins>consi</ins>de<del>em</del><ins>r</ins> <del>to </del>hav<ins>ing th</ins>e equivalent status of employees <del>(e.</del><ins>includin</ins>g<del>.</del>, <ins>for example, </ins>contractors<del>,</del> <ins>and </ins>guest researchers<del>)</del>. This control applies to all accesses other than<del>:</del> <del>(i) </del>accesses that are explicitly identified <del>and documented </del>in AC-14<del>;</del> and <del>(ii) accesses </del>that occur through <ins>the </ins>authorized use of group authenticators without individual authentication. Organizations may require unique identification of individuals in group accounts <del>(e.g., shared privilege acc</del>o<del>unts) o</del>r for detailed accountability of individual activity. Organizations employ passwords, <ins>physical au</ins>t<del>ok</del><ins>h</ins>en<ins>ticator</ins>s, or biometrics to authenticate user identities, or in the case <ins>of </ins>multifactor authentication, <del>or </del>some combination thereof. Access to organizational <del>information </del>systems is defined as either local access or network access. Local access is any access to organizational <del>information </del>systems by users <del>(</del>or processes acting on behalf of users<del>)</del><ins>,</ins> where such access is obtained <del>by</del><ins>through</ins> direct connections without the use of networks. Network access is access to organizational <del>information </del>systems by users (or processes acting on behalf of users) where such access is obtained through network connections (i.e., nonlocal accesses). Remote access is a type of network access that involves communication through external networks<del> (e</del>.<del>g.,</del> <del>the </del>Intern<del>et). Intern</del>al networks include local area networks and wide area networks. <del>In addition, t</del><ins>T</ins>he use of encrypted virtual private networks <del>(VPNs) </del>for network connections between organization-controlled endpoints and non-organization controlled endpoints may be treated as internal networks <del>from </del><ins>wi</ins>th<del>e</del> <del>pe</del>r<ins>e</ins>spect<del>ive</del> <ins>t</ins>o<del>f</del> protecting the confidentiality and integrity of information traversing the network. <del>Organizations can satisfy the i</del><ins>I</ins>dentification and authentication requirements <del>in this control by complying with the requirements in Homeland Security Presidential Directive 12 consistent with the speci</del>f<del>ic </del>or<del>ganizational</del> <del>impleme</del>n<del>tati</del>on<del> plans. Multifactor authentication requires the use of two or more different factors to achieve authentication. The factors are defined as: (i) something you know (e.g., password, personal identification number [PIN]); (ii) something you have (e.g., cryptographic identification device, token); or (iii) something you are (e.g., biometric). Multifactor solutions that require devices separate from information systems gaining access include, for example, hardware tokens providing time</del>-<del>based </del>or<del> challen</del>g<del>e-response </del>a<del>uthe</del>n<del>t</del>i<del>cators and smart cards such as the U.S. Government Personal Identity Verification card and the DoD common access card. In addition to identifying and authenticating users at the information system level (i.e., at logon), organi</del>zation<del>s </del>al<del>so</del> <del>employ identification and a</del>u<del>thentication mechani</del>s<del>ms at th</del>e<del> application level, when necessa</del>r<del>y, to provide increa</del>s<del>ed</del> <del>inform</del>a<del>tion secu</del>r<del>ity. Id</del>e<del>ntification</del> <del>an</del>d<del> auth</del>e<del>ntication requirement</del>s<del> for other than organizational users are des</del>cribed in IA-8. Related <del>c</del><ins>C</ins>ontrols: AC-2, AC-3, AC-<ins>4, AC-</ins>14, AC-17, AC-18, <ins>AU-1, AU-6, </ins>IA-4, IA-5, IA-8<ins>, MA-4, MA-5, PE-2, PL-4, SA-4</ins>.
IA-2 (1):title:IDENTIFICATION AND AUTHENTICATION <del>| </del><ins>(ORGA</ins>N<del>E</del><ins>IZA</ins>T<del>W</del><ins>I</ins>O<ins>NAL USE</ins>R<del>K</del><ins>S)</ins> <ins>| MULTIF</ins>AC<del>C</del><ins>TOR AUTH</ins>E<del>SS</del><ins>NTICATION</ins> TO PRIVILEGED ACCOUNTS
IA-2 (1):text:<del>The infor</del><ins>I</ins>m<del>ation system im</del>plement<del>s</del> multifactor authentication for<del> network</del> access to privileged accounts.
IA-2 (1):supplement:<ins>Multifactor authentication requires the use of two or more different factors to achieve authentication. Factors are defined as follows: something you know, for example, a password or personal identification number (PIN); something you have, for example, a physical authenticator or cryptographic identification device; or something you are, for example, a biometric. Multifactor solutions that feature physical authenticators include, for example, hardware authenticators providing time-based or challenge-response authenticators and smart cards such as the U.S. Government Personal Identity Verification card or the DoD common access card. In addition to authenticating users at the system level (i.e., at logon), organizations may also employ authentication mechanisms at the application level, at their discretion, to provide increased information security. </ins>Re<ins>gard</ins>l<ins>ess of the type of </ins>a<ins>ccess (i.e., local, ne</ins>t<ins>work, or r</ins>e<ins>mote) privilege</ins>d <ins>a</ins>c<ins>c</ins>o<ins>u</ins>nt<ins>s a</ins>r<ins>e always authenticated using multifact</ins>o<ins>r options appropriate for the </ins>l<ins>evel of risk. Organizations can add additional security measures, such as additional or more rigorous authentication mechanisms, for specific types of access. Related Controls</ins>:<ins> AC-5,</ins> AC-6.
IA-2 (2):title:IDENTIFICATION AND AUTHENTICATION <del>| </del><ins>(ORGA</ins>N<del>E</del><ins>IZA</ins>T<del>W</del><ins>I</ins>O<ins>NAL USE</ins>R<del>K</del><ins>S)</ins> <ins>| MULTIF</ins>AC<del>C</del><ins>TOR AUTH</ins>E<del>SS</del><ins>NTICATION</ins> TO NON-PRIVILEGED ACCOUNTS
IA-2 (2):text:<del>The infor</del><ins>I</ins>m<del>ation system im</del>plement<del>s</del> multifactor authentication for<del> network</del> access to non-privileged accounts.
IA-2 (2):supplement:<ins>Multifactor authentication requires the use of two or more different factors to achieve authentication. Factors are defined as follows: something you know, for example, a personal identification number (PIN); something you have, for example, a physical authenticator or cryptographic private key stored in hardware or software; or something you are, for example, a biometric. Multifactor solutions that feature physical authenticators include, for example, hardware authenticators providing time-based or challenge-response authenticators and smart cards such as the U.S. Government Personal Identity Verification card or the DoD common access card. In addition to authenticating users at the system level, organizations may also employ authentication mechanisms at the application level, at their discretion, to provide increased information security. Organizations can also provide additional security measures, such as additional or more rigorous authentication mechanisms, for specific types of access. Related Controls: AC-5.</ins>

IA-2 (11):supplement:<del>For remote access to privileged/non-privileged accounts, the purpose of requiring a device that is separate from the information system gaining access for one of the factors during multifactor authentication is to reduce the likelihood of compromising authentication credentials stored on the system. IA-2 (13):title:IDENTIFICATION AND AUTHENTICATION <ins>(ORGANIZATIONAL USERS) </ins>| OUT-OF-BAND AUTHENTICATION
IA-2 (13):withdrawn:<ins>Incorporated into IA-2(1)(2)</ins>
IA-2 (13):text:<del>The information system implements [Assignment: organization-defined out-of-band authentication] under [Assignment: organization-defined conditions].</del>
IA-2 (13):supplement:<del>Out-of-band authentication (OOBA) refers to the use of two separate communication paths to identify and authenticate users or devices to an information system. The first path (i.e., the in-band path), is used to identify and authenticate users or devices, and generally is the path through which information flows. The second path (i.e., the out-of-band path) is used to independently verify the authentication and/or requested action. For example, a user authenticates via a notebook computer to a remote server to which the user desires access, and requests some action of the server via that communication path. Subsequently, the server contacts the user via the user's cell phone to verify that the requested action originated from the user. The user may either confirm the intended action to an individual on the telephone or provide an authentication code via the telephone. This type of authentication can be employed by organizations to mitigate actual or suspected man-in the-middle attacks. The conditions for activation can include, for example, suspicious activities, new threat indicators or elevated threat levels, or the impact level or classification level of information in requested transactions. Related controls: IA-10, IA-11, SC-37.</del>

IA-3 (4):title:DEVICE IDENTIFICATION AND AUTHENTICATION | DEVICE ATTESTATION

IA-4 (1):title:IDENTIFIER MANAGEMENT | PROHIBIT ACCOUNT IDENTIFIERS AS PUBLIC IDENTIFIERS
IA-4 (1):text:<del>The o</del><ins>P</ins>r<del>ganizati</del>o<del>n pro</del>hibit<del>s</del> the use of<del> information</del> system account identifiers that are the same as public identifiers for individual electronic mail accounts.
IA-4 (1):supplement:Prohibiting the use of <del>information </del>systems account identifiers that are the same as some public identifier such as the individual identifier section of an electronic mail address, makes it more difficult for adversaries to guess user identifiers on organizational <ins>systems. The use of th</ins>i<ins>s co</ins>n<del>f</del><ins>tr</ins>o<ins>l alone only complicates guessing of identifie</ins>r<ins>s and </ins>m<ins>ust be combined with </ins>a<ins>ppropria</ins>t<ins>e protect</ins>ion<ins>s</ins> <ins>for authenticator</ins>s<del>y</del><ins> and attribute</ins>s<ins> </ins>t<ins>o prot</ins>e<del>m</del><ins>ct the account a</ins>s<ins> a whole</ins>. Related <del>c</del><ins>C</ins>ontrol<ins>s</ins>: AT-2.
IA-4 (2):title:IDENTIFIER MANAGEMENT | SUPERVISOR AUTHORIZATION
IA-4 (2):withdrawn:<ins>Incorporated into IA-12(1)</ins>
IA-4 (2):text:<del>The organization requires that the registration process to receive an individual identifier includes supervisor authorization.</del>
IA-4 (3):title:IDENTIFIER MANAGEMENT | MULTIPLE FORMS OF CERTIFICATION
IA-4 (3):withdrawn:<ins>Incorporated into IA-12(2)</ins>
IA-4 (3):text:<del>The organization requires multiple forms of certification of individual identification be presented to the registration authority.</del>
IA-4 (3):supplement:<del>Requiring multiple forms of identification, such as documentary evidence or a combination of documents and biometrics, reduces the likelihood of individuals using fraudulent identification to establish an identity, or at least increases the work factor of potential adversaries.</del>
IA-4 (4):title:IDENTIFIER MANAGEMENT | IDENTIFY USER STATUS
IA-4 (4):text:<del>The org</del><ins>M</ins>an<del>iz</del>a<del>tion mana</del>ge<del>s</del> individual identifiers by uniquely identifying each individual as [Assignment: organization-defined characteristic identifying individual status].
IA-4 (4):supplement:Characteristics identifying the status of individuals include, for example, contractors and foreign nationals. Identifying the status of individuals by specific characteristics provides additional information about the people with whom organizational personnel are communicating. For example, it might be useful for a government employee to know that one of the individuals on an email message is a contractor. Related <del>c</del><ins>C</ins>ontrol<ins>s</ins>: <del>AT-2</del><ins>None</ins>.
IA-4 (5):title:IDENTIFIER MANAGEMENT | DYNAMIC MANAGEMENT
IA-4 (5):text:<del>Th</del><ins>Manag</ins>e in<del>form</del><ins>dividu</ins>a<del>t</del><ins>l </ins>i<del>o</del><ins>de</ins>n<del> sys</del>t<ins>ifi</ins>e<del>m</del><ins>rs</ins> dynamically<del> manages identifiers</del>.
IA-4 (5):supplement:In contrast to conventional approaches to identification which presume static accounts for preregistered users, many distributed <del>information </del>systems <del>including, for </del>e<del>xample, </del>s<del>ervice-orien</del>t<del>ed </del>a<del>rchitectures, rely on esta</del>blish<del>ing</del> identifiers at run time for entities that were previously unknown. In these situations, organizations anticipate and provision for the dynamic establishment of identifiers. Pre<ins>-</ins>established trust relationships and mechanisms with appropriate authorities to validate identities and related credentials are essential. Related <del>c</del><ins>C</ins>ontrol<ins>s</ins>: AC-16.
IA-4 (6):title:IDENTIFIER MANAGEMENT | CROSS-ORGANIZATION MANAGEMENT
IA-4 (6):text:<del>The </del><ins>C</ins>o<del>rganizati</del>o<del>n coo</del>rdinate<del>s</del> with [Assignment: organization-defined external organizations] for cross-organization management of identifiers.
IA-4 (6):supplement:Cross-organization identifier management provides the capability for organizations to appropriately identify individuals, groups, roles, or devices when conducting cross-organization activities involving the processing, storage, or transmission of information.<ins> Related Controls: AU-16, IA-2, IA-5.</ins>
IA-4 (7):title:IDENTIFIER MANAGEMENT | IN-PERSON REGISTRATION
IA-4 (7):withdrawn:<ins>Incorporated into IA-12(4)</ins>
IA-4 (7):text:<del>The organization requires that the registration process to receive an individual identifier be conducted in person before a designated registration authority.</del>
IA-4 (7):supplement:<del>In-person registration reduces the likelihood of fraudulent identifiers being issued because it requires the physical presence of individuals and actual face-to-face interactions with designated registration authorities.</del>
IA-4 (8):title:<ins>IDENTIFIER MANAGEMENT | PAIRWISE PSEUDONYMOUS IDENTIFIERS</ins>
IA-4 (8):text:<ins>Generate pairwise pseudonymous identifiers.</ins>
IA-4 (8):supplement:<ins>Generating distinct pairwise pseudonymous identifiers, with no identifying information about a subscriber, discourages subscriber activity tracking and profiling beyond the operational requirements established by an organization. The pairwise pseudonymous identifiers are unique to each relying party, except in situations where relying parties show a demonstrable relationship justifying an operational need for correlation, or all parties consent to being correlated in such a manner. Related Controls: IA-5.</ins>

IA-5 (5):title:AUTHENTICATOR MANAGEMENT | CHANGE AUTHENTICATORS PRIOR TO DELIVERY
IA-5 (5):text:<del>Th</del><ins>R</ins>e<del> organization re</del>quire<del>s</del> developers<del>/</del><ins> and </ins>installers of <del>information </del>system components to provide unique authenticators or change default authenticators prior to delivery<del>/</del><ins> and </ins>installation.
IA-5 (5):supplement:This control enhancement extends the requirement for organizations to change default authenticators upon <del>information </del>system installation, by requiring developers and/or installers to provide unique authenticators or change default authenticators for system components prior to delivery and/or installation. However, it typically does not apply to the developers of commercial off-the-shel<del>ve</del><ins>f</ins> information technology products. Requirements for unique authenticators can be included in acquisition documents prepared by organizations when procuring <del>information </del>systems or system components<ins>. Related Controls: None</ins>.
IA-5 (6):title:AUTHENTICATOR MANAGEMENT | PROTECTION OF AUTHENTICATORS
IA-5 (6):text:<del>The o</del><ins>P</ins>r<del>ganizati</del>o<del>n pro</del>tect<del>s</del> authenticators commensurate with the security category of the information to which use of the authenticator permits access.
IA-5 (6):supplement:For <del>information </del>systems containing multiple security categories of information without reliable physical or logical separation between categories, authenticators used to grant access to the systems are protected commensurate with the highest security category of information on the systems<ins>. Security categories of information are determined as part of the security categorization process. Related Controls: RA-2</ins>.
IA-5 (7):title:AUTHENTICATOR MANAGEMENT | NO EMBEDDED UNENCRYPTED STATIC AUTHENTICATORS
IA-5 (7):text:<del>The orga</del><ins>E</ins>n<del>ization en</del>sure<del>s</del> that unencrypted static authenticators are not embedded in applications or access scripts or stored on function keys.
IA-5 (7):supplement:Organizations exercise caution in determining whether embedded or stored authenticators are in encrypted or unencrypted form. If authenticators are used in the manner stored, then those representations are considered unencrypted authenticators. This is irrespective of whether that representation is perhaps an encrypted version of something else<del> (e</del>.<del>g.,</del> <ins>Rel</ins>a<ins>ted</ins> <del>passw</del><ins>C</ins>o<ins>nt</ins>r<del>d)</del><ins>ols: None</ins>.
IA-5 (8):title:AUTHENTICATOR MANAGEMENT | MULTIPLE <del>INFORMATION </del>SYSTEM ACCOUNTS
IA-5 (8):text:<del>The organization i</del><ins>I</ins>mplement<del>s</del> [Assignment: organization-defined security safeguards] to manage the risk of compromise due to individuals having accounts on multiple<del> information</del> systems.
IA-5 (8):supplement:When individuals have accounts on multiple <del>information </del>systems, there is the risk that <del>the</del><ins>a</ins> compromise of one account may lead to the compromise of other accounts if individuals use the same authenticators. Possible alternatives include<del>, for example</del>: <del>(i) </del>having different authenticators on all systems; <del>(ii) </del>employing some form of single sign-on mechanism; or <del>(iii) incl</del>u<del>d</del><ins>s</ins>ing some form of one-time passwords on all systems<ins>. Related Controls: None</ins>.
IA-5 (9):title:AUTHENTICATOR MANAGEMENT | <del>C</del><ins>FEDE</ins>R<del>OSS-ORG</del>A<del>NIZA</del>T<del>ION</del><ins>ED</ins> CREDENTIAL MANAGEMENT
IA-5 (9):text:<del>Th</del><ins>Us</ins>e <del>organization coordinates with </del>[Assignment: organization-defined external organizations] <del>f</del><ins>t</ins>o<del>r</del> <del>c</del><ins>fede</ins>r<del>oss-org</del>a<del>niza</del>t<del>ion</del><ins>e</ins> <del>m</del>a<del>nagemen</del><ins>u</ins>t<del> of cr</del><ins>h</ins>e<del>de</del>nti<ins>c</ins>a<del>l</del><ins>tor</ins>s.
IA-5 (9):supplement:<del>C</del><ins>Fede</ins>r<del>oss-org</del>a<del>niza</del>tion <del>management of credentials </del>provides the capability for organizations to appropriately authenticate individuals<del>,</del> <del>groups,</del><ins>and</ins> <del>roles, or </del>devices when conducting cross-organization activities involving the processing, storage, or transmission of information<ins>. IA-5 (10):title:AUTHENTICATOR MANAGEMENT | DYNAMIC CREDENTIAL <del>ASSOC</del><ins>B</ins>I<del>AT</del><ins>ND</ins>I<del>O</del>N<ins>G</ins>
IA-5 (10):text:<del>The</del><ins>Bind</ins> i<ins>de</ins>n<del>forma</del>ti<del>o</del><ins>ties a</ins>n<ins>d</ins> <del>sys</del><ins>au</ins>t<ins>h</ins>e<del>m</del><ins>nticators</ins> dynamically<del> provisions identities</del>.
IA-5 (10):supplement:Authentication requires some form of binding between an identity and the authenticator used to confirm the identity. In conventional approaches, this binding is established by pre-provisioning both the identity and the authenticator to the <del>information </del>system. For example, the binding between a username (i.e., identity) and a password (i.e., authenticator) is accomplished by provisioning the identity and authenticator as a pair in the <del>information </del>system. New authentication techniques allow the binding between the identity and the authenticator to be implemented outside a<del>n</del> <del>information </del>system. For example, with smartcard credentials, the identity and the authenticator are bound together on the <ins>smart</ins>card. Using these credentials, <del>information </del>systems can authenticate identities that have not been pre-provisioned, dynamically provisioning the identity after authentication. In these situations, organizations can anticipate the dynamic provisioning of identities. Pre<ins>-</ins>established trust relationships and mechanisms with appropriate authorities to validate identities and related credentials are essential<ins>. Related Controls: AU-16, IA-5</ins>.
IA-5 (11):title:AUTHENTICATOR MANAGEMENT | HARDWARE TOKEN-BASED AUTHENTICATION
IA-5 (11):withdrawn:<ins>Incorporated into IA-2(1)(2)</ins>
IA-5 (11):text:<del>The information system, for hardware token-based authentication, employs mechanisms that satisfy [Assignment: organization-defined token quality requirements].</del>
IA-5 (11):supplement:<del>Hardware token-based authentication typically refers to the use of PKI-based tokens, such as the U.S. Government Personal Identity Verification (PIV) card. Organizations define specific requirements for tokens, such as working with a particular PKI.</del>
IA-5 (12):title:AUTHENTICATOR MANAGEMENT | BIOMETRIC<del>-BASED</del> AUTHENTICATION<ins> PERFORMANCE</ins>
IA-5 (12):text:<del>The inf</del><ins>F</ins>or<del>mation</del> <del>system, for </del>biometric-based authentication, employ<del>s</del> mechanisms that satisfy [Assignment: organization-defined biometric quality requirements].
IA-5 (12):supplement:Unlike password-based authentication which provides exact matches of user-input passwords to stored passwords, biometric authentication does not provide such exact matches. Depending upon the type of biometric and the type of collection mechanism, there is likely to be some divergence from the presented biometric and stored biometric which serves as the basis of comparison. IA-5 (17):title:<ins>AUTHENTICATOR MANAGEMENT | PRESENTATION ATTACK DETECTION FOR BIOMETRIC AUTHENTICATORS</ins>
IA-5 (17):text:<ins>Employ presentation attack detection mechanisms for biometric-based authentication.</ins>
IA-5 (17):supplement:<ins>Biometric characteristics do not constitute secrets. Such characteristics can be obtained by online web accesses; taking a picture of someone with a camera phone to obtain facial images with or without their knowledge; lifting from objects that someone has touched, for example, a latent fingerprint; or capturing a high-resolution image, for example, an iris pattern. Presentation attack detection technologies including, for example, liveness detection, can mitigate the risk of these types of attacks by making it more difficult to produce artifacts intended to defeat the biometric sensor. Related Controls: AC-7.</ins>

IA-6:title:AUTHENTICATOR FEEDBACK

IA-6:supplement:The feedback from <del>information </del>systems does not provide information that would allow unauthorized individuals to compromise authentication mechanisms. For some types of <del>information </del>systems or system components, for example, desktops/notebooks with relatively large monitors, the threat (<del>often </del>referred to as shoulder surfing) may be significant. For other types of systems or components, for example, mobile devices with <del>2-4</del><ins>small</ins> <ins>d</ins>i<del>nch </del>s<del>creen</del><ins>play</ins>s, this threat may be less significant, and <del>may</del><ins>is</ins> <del>need to </del>b<del>e b</del>alanced against the increased likelihood of typographic input errors due to the small keyboards. Therefore, the means for obscuring <del>the </del>authenticator feedback is selected accordingly. Obscuring <del>the feedb</del>a<del>ck of a</del>uthenticat<del>i</del>o<del>n</del><ins>r</ins> <del>in</del>f<del>orm</del><ins>eedb</ins>a<del>tion</del><ins>ck</ins> includes, for example, displaying asterisks when users type passwords into input devices, or displaying feedback for a very limited time before fully obscuring it. IA-10:supplement:Adversaries may compromise individual authentication mechanisms and subsequently attempt to impersonate legitimate users. In <del>the</del>s<del>e s</del>ituations when <del>certain </del>pre<ins>-</ins>established conditions or triggers occur, organizations can require <del>selected </del>individuals to provide additional authentication information. Another potential use for adaptive <del>identific</del>a<del>tion and a</del>uthentication is to increase the strength of mechanism based on the number and/or types of records being accessed. <del>R</del><ins>Adaptiv</ins>e<ins> authentication does not rep</ins>la<ins>ce and is no</ins>t<ins> us</ins>ed <ins>to avoid multifa</ins>c<ins>t</ins>o<ins>r mecha</ins>n<ins>isms, bu</ins>t<ins> can augment implementations of these cont</ins>rols<ins>. Related Controls</ins>: <ins>I</ins>A<del>U</del>-<del>6</del><ins>2</ins>, <del>S</del>I<ins>A</ins>-<del>4</del><ins>8</ins>.

IA-12:title:<ins>IDENTITY PROOFING</ins>
IA-12 a:text:<ins>Identity proof users that require accounts for logical access to systems based on appropriate identity assurance level requirements as specified in applicable standards and guidelines;</ins>
IA-12 b:text:<ins>Resolve user identities to a unique individual; and</ins>
IA-12 c:text:<ins>Collect, validate, and verify identity evidence.</ins>
IA-12:supplement:<ins>Identity proofing is the process of collecting, validating, and verifying user’s identity information for the purposes of issuing credentials for accessing a system. This control is intended to mitigate threats to the registration of users and the establishment of their accounts. Standards and guidelines specifying identity assurance levels for identity proofing include NIST Special Publications 800-63 and 800-63A. Related Controls: IA-1, IA-2, IA-3, IA-4, IA-5, IA-6, IA-8. (1) IDENTITY PROOFING | SUPERVISOR AUTHORIZATION Require that the registration process to receive an account for logical access includes supervisor or sponsor authorization. Supplemental Guidance: None. Related Controls: None. (2) IDENTITY PROOFING | IDENTITY EVIDENCE Require evidence of individual identification be presented to the registration authority. Supplemental Guidance: Requiring identity evidence, such as documentary evidence or a combination of documents and biometrics, reduces the likelihood of individuals using fraudulent identification to establish an identity, or at least increases the work factor of potential adversaries. Acceptable forms of evidence are consistent with the risk to the systems, roles, and privileges associated with the user’s account. Related Controls: None. (3) IDENTITY PROOFING | IDENTITY EVIDENCE VALIDATION AND VERIFICATION Require that the presented identity evidence be validated and verified through [Assignment: organizational defined methods of validation and verification]. Supplemental Guidance: Validating and verifying identity evidence increases the assurance that that accounts, identifiers, and authenticators are being issued to the correct user. Validation refers to the process of confirming that the evidence is genuine and authentic and that the data contained in the evidence is correct, current, and related to an actual person or individual. Verification confirms and establishes a linkage between the claimed identity and the actual existence of the user presenting the evidence. Acceptable methods for validating and verifying identity evidence are consistent with the risk to the systems, roles, and privileges associated with the users account Related Controls: None. (4) IDENTITY PROOFING | IN-PERSON VALIDATION AND VERIFICATION Require that the validation and verification of identity evidence be conducted in person before a designated registration authority. Supplemental Guidance: In-person proofing reduces the likelihood of fraudulent credentials being issued because it requires the physical presence of individuals, the presentation of physical identity documents, and actual face-to-face interactions with designated registration authorities. Related Controls: None. (5) IDENTITY PROOFING | ADDRESS CONFIRMATION Require that a [Selection: registration code; notice of proofing] be delivered through an out-of-band channel to verify the users address (physical or digital) of record. Supplemental Guidance: To make it more difficult for adversaries to pose as legitimate users during the identity proofing process, organizations can use out-of-band methods to increase assurance that the individual associated with an address of record was the same person that participated in the registration. Confirmation can take the form of a temporary enrollment code or a notice of proofing. The delivery address for these artifacts are obtained from records and not self-asserted by the user. The address can include a physical or a digital address. A home address is an example of a physical address. Email addresses and telephone numbers are examples of digital addresses. Related Controls: IA-12. (6) IDENTITY PROOFING | ACCEPT EXTERNALLY-PROOFED IDENTITIES Accept externally-proofed identities at [Assignment: organization-defined identity assurance level]. Supplemental Guidance: To limit unnecessary re-proofing of identities, particularly of non-PIV users, organizations accept proofing conducted at a commensurate level of assurance by other agencies or organizations. Proofing is consistent with organizational security policy and with the identity assurance level appropriate for the system, application, or information accessed. This is a core component of managing federated identities across agencies and organizations. Related Controls: IA-3, IA-4, IA-5, IA-8.</ins>
IA-12:references:<ins>FIPS Publication 201 ; NIST Special Publications 800-63 , 800-63A</ins>

IP-1 (1):title:<del>CONSENT | MECHANISMS SUPPORTING ITEMIZED OR TIERED CONSENT</del>
IP-1 (1):text:<del>The organization implements mechanisms to support itemized or tiered consent for specific uses of data.</del>
IP-1 (1):supplement:<del>Organizations can provide, for example, individuals' itemized choices as to whether they wish to be contacted for any of a variety of purposes. In this situation, organizations construct consent mechanisms to ensure that organizational operations comply with individual choices.</del>

IP-2 (1):title:<ins>CONSENT | ATTRIBUTE MANAGEMENT</ins>
IP-2 (1):text:<ins>Allow data subjects to tailor use permissions to selected attributes.</ins>
IP-2 (1):supplement:<ins>Allowing individuals to select how specific data attributes may be further used or disclosed beyond the original use may help reduce privacy risk arising from the most sensitive of the data attributes while maintaining utility of the data. Related Controls: None.</ins>
IP-2 (2):title:<ins>CONSENT | JUST-IN-TIME NOTICE OF CONSENT</ins>
IP-2 (2):text:<ins>Present authorizations to process personally identifiable information in conjunction with the data action or [Assignment: organization-defined frequency].</ins>
IP-2 (2):supplement:<ins>If the circumstances under which an individual gave consent have changed or a significant amount of time has passed since an individual gave consent for the processing of his or her personally identifiable information, the data subject’s assumption about how the information is being processed might no longer be accurate or reliable. Just-in-time notice can help maintain individual satisfaction with how the personally identifiable information is being processed. Related Controls: None.</ins>

IP-3:title:REDRESS
IP-3:text:<del>The organization:</del>
IP-3 a:text:<del>T</del><ins>Establis</ins>h<del>e</del> <del>org</del>an<del>ization:</del><ins>d</ins> <del>Prov</del>i<del>d</del><ins>mpl</ins>e<del>s</del><ins>ment</ins> a process for individuals to have inaccurate personally identifiable information <del>(PII) </del>maintained by the organization corrected or amended<del>, as appropriate</del>; and
IP-3 b:text:<del>The organization: </del>Establish<ins> and impl</ins>e<del>s</del><ins>ment</ins> a process for disseminating corrections or amendments of <ins>personally iden</ins>t<del>h</del><ins>ifiabl</ins>e <del>PII</del><ins>information</ins> to other authorized users of the <del>PII, such as external information-sharing </del>p<del>artn</del>ers<del> a</del><ins>o</ins>n<del>d, where fe</del>a<del>sib</del>l<del>e</del><ins>ly</ins> <del>and appropr</del>i<del>at</del><ins>d</ins>e<del>, </del>n<del>o</del>tifi<del>es </del>a<del>ffected individua</del><ins>b</ins>l<del>s that th</del>e<del>ir</del> information<del> has been corrected or amended</del>.
IP-3:supplement:Redress supports the ability of individuals to ensure the accuracy of <del>PII</del><ins>their</ins> <ins>personally identifiable information </ins>held by organizations. Effective redress processes demonstrate organizational commitment to data quality especially in those business functions where inaccurate data may result in inappropriate decisions or <ins>the </ins>denial of benefits and services to individuals. Organizations use discretion in determining if records are to be corrected or amended, based on the scope of redress requests, the changes sought, and the impact of the changes. <del>Ind</del><ins>Other author</ins>i<del>vi</del><ins>ze</ins>d<ins> </ins>u<del>al</del>s<ins>ers</ins> <del>may</del><ins>of</ins> <del>a</del>p<del>p</del>e<ins>rson</ins>al<ins>ly</ins> <del>a</del><ins>ide</ins>n<del> </del><ins>tifi</ins>a<del>dv</del><ins>bl</ins>e<del>rse</del> <del>dec</del>i<del>s</del><ins>nformat</ins>ion <del>a</del><ins>i</ins>n<ins>clu</ins>d<del> hav</del>e<ins>,</ins> <del>inc</del><ins>f</ins>or<del>r</del><ins> </ins>e<del>c</del><ins>xample, ex</ins>t<ins>ernal</ins> information<del> amended, w</del><ins>-s</ins>h<del>ere </del>a<del>pp</del>r<del>opr</del>i<ins>ng p</ins>a<ins>r</ins>t<ins>n</ins>e<ins>rs</ins>. <del>To</del><ins>An</ins> <del>provid</del>e<del> e</del>ffective redress<del>,</del> <del>o</del><ins>p</ins>r<del>ganizati</del>o<ins>cess i</ins>n<ins>clude</ins>s: <del>(i) </del>provid<del>e</del><ins>ing</ins> effective notice of the existence of a <del>PII</del><ins>personally</ins> <ins>identifiable information </ins>collection; <del>(ii) </del>provid<del>e</del><ins>ing</ins> plain language explanations of the processes and mechanisms for requesting access to records; <del>(iii) </del>establish<ins>ing</ins> <ins>the </ins>criteria for submitting requests for correction or amendment<ins> of records</ins>; <del>(</del>i<del>v) i</del>mplement<ins>ing</ins> resources to analyze and adjudicate requests; <del>(v) </del>implement<ins>ing</ins> means of correcting or amending data collections; and <del>(vi) </del>review<ins>ing</ins> any decisions that may have been the result of inaccurate information. <del>Organizational redress processes provide responses to individuals of decisions to deny requests for correction or amendment, including the reasons for those decisions, a means to record individual objections to the organizational decisions, and a means of requesting organizational reviews of the initial determinations. Where PII is corrected or amended, organizations take steps to ensure that all authorized recipients of that PII are informed of the corrected or amended information. In instances where redress involves information obtained from other organizations, redress processes include coordination with organizations that originally collected the information. </del>Related <del>c</del><ins>C</ins>ontrols: IP-<del>2</del><ins>4</ins>, <del>TR</del><ins>IP</ins>-<del>1</del><ins>6</ins>, <del>T</del><ins>I</ins>R-<del>2</del><ins>7</ins>, <del>UL</del><ins>PM</ins>-2<ins>8</ins>.
IP-3 (1):title:<ins>REDRESS | NOTICE OF CORRECTION OR AMENDMENT</ins>
IP-3 (1):text:<ins>Notify affected individuals if their personally identifiable information has been corrected or amended.</ins>
IP-3 (1):supplement:<ins>Where personally identifiable information is corrected or amended, organizations take steps to ensure that all authorized recipients of such information and the individual with which the information is associated, are informed of the corrected or amended information. Related Controls: None.</ins>
IP-3 (2):title:<ins>REDRESS | APPEAL</ins>
IP-3 (2):text:<ins>Provide [Assignment: organization-defined process] for individuals to appeal an adverse decision and have incorrect information amended.</ins>
IP-3 (2):supplement:<ins>The Senior Agency Official for Privacy ensures that practical means and mechanisms exist and are accessible for individuals to seek the correction or amendment of their personally identifiable information. Redress processes are clearly defined and publicly available. Additionally, redress processes include the provision of responses to individuals of decisions to deny requests for correction or amendment. The responses include the reasons for the decisions, a means to record individual objections to the decisions, and finally, a means of requesting reviews of the initial determinations. Related Controls: None.</ins>
