SA-20:title:CUSTOMIZED DEVELOPMENT OF CRITICAL COMPONENTS
SA-20:text:<del>Th</del><ins>R</ins>e<del> organization re</del>-implement<del>s</del> or custom develops [Assignment: organization-defined critical<del> information</del> system components].
SA-20:supplement:Organizations determine that certain <del>information </del>system components likely cannot be trusted due to specific threats to and vulnerabilities in those components, and for which there are no viable security controls to adequately mitigate the resulting risk. Re-implementation or custom development of such components helps to satisfy requirements for higher assurance. This is accomplished by initiating changes to system components (including hardware, software, and firmware) such that the standard attacks by adversaries are less likely to succeed. In situations where no alternative sourcing is available and organizations choose not to re-implement or custom develop critical <del>information </del>system components, additional safeguards can be employed<ins>.</ins> <del>(</del><ins>Th</ins>e<del>.g.</del><ins>se include</ins>, <ins>for </ins>e<ins>xample, e</ins>nhanced auditing<del>,</del><ins>;</ins> restrictions on source code and system utility access<del>,</del><ins>;</ins> and protection from deletion of system and application files. Related <del>c</del><ins>C</ins>ontrols: CP-2, <del>S</del><ins>R</ins>A-<del>8</del><ins>9</ins>, SA-<del>14</del><ins>8</ins>.

SC-2:supplement:<del>Information s</del><ins>S</ins>ystem management functionality includes, for example, functions <ins>that are </ins>necessary to administer databases, network components, workstations, or servers<del>,</del><ins>.</ins> <del>a</del><ins>These fu</ins>n<del>d</del><ins>ctions</ins> typically require<del>s</del> privileged user access. Organizations implement separation of system management<del>-related</del> function<del>ality</del><ins>s</ins> from user function<ins>s, for ex</ins>a<ins>mp</ins>l<del>ity</del><ins>e,</ins> by using different computers, <del>d</del>i<del>ffere</del>n<del>t central proce</del>s<del>sing uni</del>t<del>s, different inst</del>ances of operating systems, <del>diff</del><ins>c</ins>e<ins>nt</ins>r<ins>al proc</ins>e<ins>ssi</ins>n<ins>g uni</ins>t<ins>s,</ins> <ins>or </ins>network addresses<del>,</del><ins>;</ins> <ins>by employing </ins>virtualization techniques<del>,</del><ins>;</ins> or <ins>some </ins>combination<del>s</del> of these or other methods<del>, as appropriate</del>. SC-3:title:SECURITY FUNCTION ISOLATION
SC-3:text:<del>The information </del><ins>I</ins>s<del>ystem is</del>olate<del>s</del> security functions from nonsecurity functions.
SC-3:supplement:The <del>information </del>system isolates security functions from nonsecurity functions by means of an isolation boundary <del>(</del>implemented via partitions and domains<del>)</del>. Such isolation controls access to and protects the integrity of the hardware, software, and firmware that perform those security functions. <del>Information s</del><ins>S</ins>ystems implement code separation <del>(</del>i<del>.e., separatio</del>n <del>of security functions fro</del>m<del> </del><ins>a</ins>n<del>onsecurit</del>y <del>functions) in a number of </del>ways, <del>including, </del>for example, through the provision of security kernels via processor rings or processor modes. For non-kernel code, security function isolation is often achieved through file system protections that <del>serve to </del>protect the code on disk<del>,</del> and address space protections that protect executing code. <del>Information s</del><ins>S</ins>ystems <ins>can </ins>restrict access to security functions <del>thro</del>u<ins>sin</ins>g<del>h</del> <del>the use of </del>access control mechanisms and by implementing least privilege capabilities. While the ideal is for all <del>of the </del>code within the <ins>defined </ins>security function isolation boundary to only contain security-relevant code, it is sometimes necessary to include nonsecurity functions within the isolation boundary as an exception. Related <del>c</del><ins>C</ins>ontrols: AC-3, AC-6, <ins>AC-25, CM-2, CM-4, </ins>SA-4, SA-5, SA-8, SA-1<del>3</del><ins>5</ins>, S<ins>A-17, S</ins>C-2, SC-7, SC-3<ins>2, SC-3</ins>9<ins>, SI-16</ins>.
SC-3 (1):title:SECURITY FUNCTION ISOLATION | HARDWARE SEPARATION
SC-3 (1):text:<del>The information </del><ins>U</ins>s<del>yst</del>e<del>m utilizes underlying</del> hardware separation mechanisms to implement security function isolation.
SC-3 (1):supplement:<del>Underlying h</del><ins>H</ins>ardware separation mechanisms include, for example, hardware ring architectures<del>,</del> <ins>that are </ins>commonly implemented within microprocessors, and hardware-enforced address segmentation used to support logically distinct storage objects with separate attributes (i.e., readable, writeable)<ins>. Related Controls: None</ins>.
SC-3 (2):title:SECURITY FUNCTION ISOLATION | ACCESS <del>/</del><ins>AND</ins> FLOW CONTROL FUNCTIONS
SC-3 (2):text:<del>The information </del><ins>I</ins>s<del>ystem is</del>olate<del>s</del> security functions enforcing access and information flow control from nonsecurity functions and from other security functions.
SC-3 (2):supplement:Security function isolation occurs <ins>bec</ins>a<ins>u</ins>s<del> a r</del>e<del>sult</del> of implementation<del>;</del><ins>.</ins> <del>t</del><ins>T</ins>he functions can still be scanned and monitored. SC-3 (3):title:SECURITY FUNCTION ISOLATION | MINIMIZE NONSECURITY FUNCTIONALITY
SC-3 (3):text:<del>The organ</del><ins>M</ins>i<del>zatio</del>n<del> m</del>i<del>ni</del>mize<del>s</del> the number of nonsecurity functions included within the isolation boundary containing security functions.
SC-3 (3):supplement:In those instances where it is not feasible to achieve strict isolation of nonsecurity functions from security functions, it is necessary to take actions to minimize the nonsecurity-relevant functions within the security function boundary. Nonsecurity functions contained within the isolation boundary are considered security-relevant because errors or <ins>the </ins>maliciousness in such software, <del>by</del><ins>can</ins> <del>v</del><ins>d</ins>ir<del>tu</del>e<del> of being wi</del><ins>c</ins>t<del>hin the boundar</del><ins>l</ins>y<del>,</del> <del>can </del>impact the security functions of <del>organizational information </del>systems. The <ins>fun</ins>d<ins>am</ins>e<ins>ntal de</ins>sign objective is that the specific portions of <del>information </del>systems providing information security are of minimal size<del>/</del><ins> and </ins>complexity. Minimizing the number of nonsecurity functions in the security-relevant <ins>system </ins>components <del>of inform</del>a<del>tion systems a</del>llows designers and implementers to focus only on those functions which are necessary to provide the desired security capability (typically access enforcement). By minimizing nonsecurity functions within the isolation boundaries, the amount of code that must be trusted to enforce security policies is <ins>significantly </ins>reduced, thus contributing to understandability<ins>. Related Controls: None</ins>.
SC-3 (4):title:SECURITY FUNCTION ISOLATION | MODULE COUPLING AND COHESIVENESS
SC-3 (4):text:<del>The organization i</del><ins>I</ins>mplement<del>s</del> security functions as largely independent modules that maximize internal cohesiveness within modules and minimize coupling between modules.
SC-3 (4):supplement:The reduction in inter-module interactions helps to constrain security functions and to manage complexity. The concepts of coupling and cohesion are important with respect to modularity in software design. Coupling refers to the dependencies that one module has on other modules. Cohesion refers to the relationship between <del>the </del>different functions within a <del>particular </del>module. <del>Good</del><ins>Best</ins> <ins>practice</ins>s<ins> in s</ins>oftware engineering <del>p</del>r<del>actic</del>e<del>s re</del>ly on <del>modu</del>la<ins>ye</ins>r<ins>ing,</ins> <del>deco</del>m<del>pos</del>i<ins>nimiza</ins>tion, <del>l</del>a<del>yeri</del>n<del>g,</del><ins>d</ins> <del>an</del><ins>mo</ins>d<ins>ular</ins> <ins>deco</ins>m<ins>pos</ins>i<del>nimiza</del>tion to reduce and manage complexity<del>,</del><ins>.</ins> <del>t</del><ins>T</ins>h<del>u</del><ins>i</ins>s produc<del>ing</del><ins>es</ins> software modules that are highly cohesive and loosely coupled<ins>. Related Controls: None</ins>.
SC-3 (5):title:SECURITY FUNCTION ISOLATION | LAYERED STRUCTURES
SC-3 (5):text:<del>The organization i</del><ins>I</ins>mplement<del>s</del> security functions as a layered structure minimizing interactions between layers of the design and avoiding any dependence by lower layers on the functionality or correctness of higher layers.
SC-3 (5):supplement:The implementation of layered structures with minimized interactions among security functions and non-looping layers (i.e., lower-layer functions do not depend on higher-layer functions) further enables the isolation of security functions and management of complexity.<ins> Related Controls: None.</ins>

SC-5 (1):supplement:Restricting the ability of individuals to launch denial of service attacks requires that the mechanisms <ins>commonly </ins>used for such attacks are unavailable. Related Controls: None</ins>.

SC-7 (7):title:BOUNDARY PROTECTION | PREVENT SPLIT TUNNELING FOR REMOTE DEVICES
SC-7 (7):text:<del>The info</del><ins>P</ins>r<del>mation syst</del>e<del>m, i</del><ins>ve</ins>n<del> conjunc</del>t<del>ion</del> <del>with </del>a remot<del>e device, prevents th</del>e device from simultaneously establishing non-remote connections with the system and communicating via some other connection to resources in external networks.
SC-7 (7):supplement:This control enhancement is implemented <del>w</del>i<del>thi</del>n remote devices <del>(e.</del><ins>includin</ins>g<del>.</del>, <ins>for example, </ins>notebook computers<del>)</del><ins>,</ins> through configuration settings to disable split tunneling in those devices, and by preventing those configuration settings from being readily configurable by users. This control enhancement is implemented within the <del>information </del>system by the detection of split tunneling (or of configuration settings that allow split tunneling) in the remote device, and by prohibiting the connection if the remote device is using split tunneling. Split tunneling might be desirable by remote users to communicate with local <del>information </del>system resources such as printers<del>/</del><ins> or </ins>file servers. However, split tunneling <del>would i</del><ins>ca</ins>n <del>effect </del>allow unauthorized external connections, making the system more vulnerable to attack and to exfiltration of organizational information. The use of VPNs for remote connections, when adequately provisioned with <ins>the </ins>appropriate security controls, may provide the organization with sufficient assurance that it can effectively treat such connections as non-remote connections <del>f</del><ins>with </ins>r<ins>espect t</ins>o<del>m</del> the <ins>obje</ins>c<ins>tives </ins>o<ins>f co</ins>nfidentiality and integrity<del> perspective</del>. VPNs <del>thus </del>provide a means for allowing non-remote communications paths from remote devices. The use of an adequately provisioned VPN does not eliminate the need for preventing split tunneling<ins>. Related Controls: None</ins>.
SC-7 (8):title:BOUNDARY PROTECTION | ROUTE TRAFFIC TO AUTHENTICATED PROXY SERVERS
SC-7 (8):text:<del>The inf</del><ins>R</ins>o<del>rmation system ro</del>ute<del>s</del> [Assignment: organization-defined internal communications traffic] to [Assignment: organization-defined external networks] through authenticated proxy servers at managed interfaces.
SC-7 (8):supplement:External networks are networks outside of organizational control. A proxy server is a server (i.e., <del>information </del>system or application) that acts as an intermediary for clients requesting <ins>system resources from non-organ</ins>i<ins>zatio</ins>n<del>f</del><ins>al </ins>or<del>m</del><ins> other org</ins>a<ins>niza</ins>tion<ins>al</ins> s<ins>ervers. These s</ins>ystem resources <del>(</del><ins>can includ</ins>e<del>.g.</del>, f<ins>or example, f</ins>iles, connections, web pages, or services<del>) from other organizational servers</del>. Client requests established through an initial connection to the proxy server are evaluated to manage complexity and to provide additional protection by limiting direct connectivity. Web content filtering devices are one of the most common proxy servers providing access to the Internet. Proxy servers <ins>can </ins>support logging <ins>of </ins>individual Transmission Control Protocol <del>(TCP) </del>sessions and blocking specific Uniform Resource Locators<del> (URLs)</del>, <del>domain names, and </del>Internet Protocol <del>(IP) </del>addresses<ins>, and domain names</ins>. Web proxies can be configured with organization-defined lists of authorized and unauthorized websites. Related <del>c</del><ins>C</ins>ontrols: AC-3<del>, AU-2</del>.

SC-7 (14):supplement:<del>Information s</del><ins>S</ins>ystems operating at different security categories or classification levels may share common physical and environmental controls, since the systems may share space within <del>organiza</del>t<del>ion</del><ins>he s</ins>a<del>l</del><ins>me</ins> facilities. SC-7 (21):title:BOUNDARY PROTECTION | ISOLATION OF <del>INFORMATION </del>SYSTEM COMPONENTS
SC-7 (21):text:<del>The organization e</del><ins>E</ins>mploy<del>s</del> boundary protection mechanisms to separate [Assignment: organization-defined<del> information</del> system components] supporting [Assignment: organization-defined missions and/or business functions].
SC-7 (21):supplement:Organizations can isolate <del>information </del>system components performing different missions <del>and/</del>or business functions. Such isolation limits unauthorized information flows among system components and <del>also </del>provides the opportunity to deploy greater levels of protection for selected <ins>system </ins>components. Separating system components with boundary protection mechanisms provides the capability for increased protection of individual components and to more effectively control information flows between those components. This type of enhanced protection limits the potential harm from <del>cyb</del><ins>hostil</ins>e<del>r</del> attacks and errors. The degree of separation provided varies depending upon the mechanisms chosen. Boundary protection mechanisms include, for example, routers, gateways, and firewalls separating system components into physically separate networks or subnetworks<del>,</del><ins>;</ins> cross-domain devices separating subnetworks<del>,</del><ins>;</ins> virtualization techniques<del>,</del><ins>;</ins> and encrypting information flows among system components using distinct encryption keys. Related <del>c</del><ins>C</ins>ontrols: CA-9, SC-3.

SC-8 (1):title:TRANSMISSION CONFIDENTIALITY AND INTEGRITY | CRYPTOGRAPHIC <del>OR ALTERNATE PHYSICAL </del>PROTECTION
SC-8 (1):text:<del>The infor</del><ins>I</ins>m<del>ation system im</del>plement<del>s</del> cryptographic mechanisms to [Selection (one or more): prevent unauthorized disclosure of information; detect changes to information] during transmission<del> unless otherwise protected by [Assignment: organization-defined alternative physical safeguards]</del>.
SC-8 (1):supplement:Encrypting information for transmission protects information from unauthorized disclosure and modification. Cryptographic mechanisms implemented to protect information integrity include, for example, cryptographic hash functions which have common application in digital signatures, checksums, and message authentication codes. <del>Alternative physical security safeguards include, for example, protected distribution systems. </del>Related <del>c</del><ins>C</ins>ontrol<ins>s</ins>: SC-13.
SC-8 (2):title:TRANSMISSION CONFIDENTIALITY AND INTEGRITY | PRE<ins>-</ins> <del>/</del><ins>AND</ins> POST<del> </del><ins>-</ins>TRANSMISSION HANDLING
SC-8 (2):text:<del>The inform</del><ins>M</ins>a<del>t</del>i<del>o</del>n<del> sys</del>t<del>em m</del>ain<del>tains</del> the [Selection (one or more): confidentiality; integrity] of information during preparation for transmission and during reception.
SC-8 (2):supplement:Information can be either unintentionally or maliciously disclosed or modified during preparation for transmission or during reception including, for example, during aggregation, at protocol transformation points, and during packing<del>/</del><ins> and </ins>unpacking. These unauthorized disclosures or modifications compromise the confidentiality or integrity of the information. Related <del>c</del><ins>C</ins>ontrol<ins>s</ins>: AU-10.
SC-8 (3):title:TRANSMISSION CONFIDENTIALITY AND INTEGRITY | CRYPTOGRAPHIC PROTECTION FOR MESSAGE EXTERNALS
SC-8 (3):text:<del>The infor</del><ins>I</ins>m<del>ation system im</del>plement<del>s</del> cryptographic mechanisms to protect message externals unless otherwise protected by [Assignment: organization-defined alternative physical safeguards].
SC-8 (3):supplement:This control enhancement addresses protection against unauthorized disclosure of information. Message externals include, for example, message headers<del>/</del><ins> and </ins>routing information. This control enhancement prevents the exploitation of message externals and applies to <del>both </del>internal and external networks or links that may be visible to individuals who are not authorized users. Header<del>/</del><ins> and </ins>routing information is sometimes transmitted <ins>in the clear (i.e., </ins>unencrypted<ins>)</ins> because the information is not properly identified by organizations as having significant value or because encrypting the information can result in lower network performance <del>and/</del>or higher costs. Alternative physical safeguards include, for example, protected distribution systems. Related <del>c</del><ins>C</ins>ontrols: SC-12, SC-13.
SC-8 (4):title:TRANSMISSION CONFIDENTIALITY AND INTEGRITY | CONCEAL <del>/</del><ins>OR</ins> RANDOMIZE COMMUNICATIONS
SC-8 (4):text:<del>The infor</del><ins>I</ins>m<del>ation system im</del>plement<del>s</del> cryptographic mechanisms to conceal or randomize communication patterns unless otherwise protected by [Assignment: organization-defined alternative physical safeguards].
SC-8 (4):supplement:This control enhancement addresses protection against unauthorized disclosure of information. Communication patterns include, for example, frequency, periods, amount, and predictability. Changes to communications patterns can reveal information having intelligence value especially when combined with other available information related to <ins>the </ins>missions<del>/</del><ins> and </ins>business functions supported by organizational <del>information </del>systems. This control enhancement prevents the derivation of intelligence based on communications patterns and applies to <del>both </del>internal and external networks or links that may be visible to individuals who are not authorized users. Encrypting the links and transmitting in continuous, fixed<del>/</del><ins> o</ins>r<ins> r</ins>andom patterns prevents the derivation of intelligence from the system communications patterns. Alternative physical safeguards include, for example, protected distribution systems. Related <del>c</del><ins>C</ins>ontrols: SC-12, SC-13.

SC-11:title:TRUSTED PATH
SC-11:text:<del>The information system establishes a trusted communications path between the user and the following security functions of the system: [Assignment: organization-defined security functions to include at a minimum, information system authentication and re-authentication].</del>
SC-11 a:text:<ins>Provide a [Selection: physically; logically] isolated trusted communications path for communications between the user and the trusted components of the system; and</ins>
SC-11 b:text:<ins>Permit users to invoke the trusted communications path for communications between the user and the following security functions of the system, including at a minimum, authentication and re-authentication: [Assignment: organization-defined security functions].</ins>
SC-11:supplement:Trusted paths are mechanisms by which users (through input devices) can communicate directly with security functions of <del>information </del>systems with the requisite assurance to support <del>information </del>security policies. The<ins>se</ins> mechanisms can be activated only by users or the security functions of organizational <del>information </del>systems. User responses via trusted paths are protected from modifications by or disclosure to untrusted applications. Organizations employ trusted paths for <ins>trustwort</ins>h<ins>y, h</ins>igh-assurance connections between security functions of <ins>systems and users </ins>in<ins>cluding, </ins>for<del>m</del><ins> ex</ins>a<del>t</del><ins>mple, dur</ins>i<del>o</del>n<ins>g</ins> system<ins> logon</ins>s<ins>.</ins> <ins>The origin</ins>a<ins>l impleme</ins>n<ins>tations of truste</ins>d <ins>path </ins>use<ins>d an out-of-band signal to initiate the path, fo</ins>r<ins> example u</ins>s<ins>ing</ins> <del>(</del><ins>th</ins>e<del>.</del><ins> &lt;BREAK&</ins>g<del>.</del><ins>t; key</ins>, <ins>which </ins>d<del>u</del><ins>oes not t</ins>r<ins>ansm</ins>i<ins>t characters that ca</ins>n<del>g</del> <ins>be </ins>s<ins>poofed. In later implementations, a ke</ins>y<ins> combination that could not be hijacked wa</ins>s<ins> used, for example, </ins>t<ins>h</ins>e<ins> &lt;CTRL&gt; + &lt;ALT&gt; + &lt;DEL&gt; keys. Note, however, that any such key co</ins>m<ins>binations</ins> <ins>are p</ins>l<ins>atf</ins>o<del>g</del><ins>rm-specific and may n</ins>o<ins>t provide a trusted path impleme</ins>n<ins>tation in every ca</ins>s<del>)</del><ins>e</ins>. Enforcement of trusted communications paths is typically provided <del>via</del><ins>by</ins> a<del>n</del> <ins>spec</ins>i<ins>fic i</ins>mplementation that meets the reference monitor concept. Related <del>c</del><ins>C</ins>ontrols: AC-16, AC-25<ins>, SC-12, SC-23</ins>.
SC-11 (1):title:TRUSTED PATH <del> </del>| LOGICAL ISOLATION
SC-11 (1):text:<del>The information system provides a trusted communications path that is logically isolated and distinguishable from other paths.</del>
SC-11 (1) (a):text:<ins>Provide a trusted communications path that is irrefutably distinguishable from other communications paths; and</ins>
SC-11 (1) (b):text:<ins>Initiate the trusted communications path for communications between the following security functions of the system and the user [Assignment: organization-defined security functions].</ins>
SC-11 (1):supplement:<ins>This enhancement permits the system to initiate a trusted path which necessitates that the user can unmistakably recognize the source of the communication as a trusted system component. For example, the trusted path may appear in an area of the display that other applications cannot access, or be based on the presence of an identifier that cannot be spoofed. Related Controls: None.</ins>

SC-18:supplement:Decisions regarding the <ins>us</ins>e<del>mployment</del> of mobile code within organizational <del>information </del>systems are based on the potential for the code to cause damage to the systems if used maliciously. Mobile code technologies include, for example, Java, JavaScript, ActiveX, Postscript, PDF, Shockwave movies, Flash animations, and VBScript. Usage restrictions and implementation guid<del>a</del><ins>eli</ins>n<del>c</del>e<ins>s</ins> apply to both the selection and use of mobile code installed on servers and mobile code downloaded and executed on individual workstations and devices <del>(e.</del><ins>includin</ins>g<del>.</del>, <ins>for example, notebook computer</ins>s<ins> and s</ins>mart phones<del>)</del>. Related <del>c</del><ins>C</ins>ontrols: AU-2, AU-12, CM-2, CM-6, SI-3.

SC-20:supplement:This control enables external clients including, for example, remote Internet clients, to obtain origin authentication and integrity verification assurances for the host/service name to network address resolution information obtained through the service. <del>Information s</del><ins>S</ins>ystems that provide name and address resolution services include, for example, domain name system (DNS) servers. SC-22:title:ARCHITECTURE AND PROVISIONING FOR NAME<del> </del>/<del> </del>ADDRESS RESOLUTION SERVICE
SC-22:text:<del>The i</del><ins>E</ins>n<del>fo</del><ins>su</ins>r<del>ma</del><ins>e </ins>t<del>ion</del><ins>he</ins> systems that collectively provide name/address resolution service for an organization are fault-tolerant and implement internal<del>/</del><ins> and </ins>external role separation.
SC-22:supplement:<del>Information s</del><ins>S</ins>ystems that provide name and address resolution services include, for example, domain name system (DNS) servers. To eliminate single points of failure and to enhance redundancy, organizations employ at least two authoritative domain name system servers<del>,</del><ins>;</ins> one configured as the primary server and the other configured as the secondary server. Additionally, organizations typically deploy the servers in two geographically separated network subnetworks (i.e., not located in the same physical facility). For role separation, DNS servers with internal roles only process name and address resolution requests from within organizations (i.e., from internal clients). DNS servers with external roles only process name and address resolution information requests from clients external to organizations (i.e., on external networks including the Internet). Organizations specify clients that can access authoritative DNS servers in <del>pa</del><ins>ce</ins>rt<del>icul</del>a<del>r</del><ins>in</ins> roles<ins>,</ins> <del>(</del><ins>for </ins>e<del>.g.</del><ins>xample</ins>, by address ranges<del>,</del> <ins>and </ins>explicit lists<del>)</del>. Related <del>c</del><ins>C</ins>ontrols: SC-2, SC-20, SC-21, SC-24.

SC-28:supplement:This control addresses the confidentiality and integrity of information at rest and covers user information and system information. Information at rest refers to the state of information when it is <ins>not in process or in transit and is </ins>located on storage devices as specific components of <ins>systems. Organizations may employ different mechanisms to achieve confidentiality and integrity protections, including the use of cryptographic mechanisms and file share scanning. Integrity protection can be achieved, for example, by implementing Write-Once-Read-Many (WORM) technologies. <del>O</del><ins>When adequate p</ins>r<ins>otection of information at rest cannot otherwise be achieved, or</ins>ganizations may <del>also </del>employ other security controls including, for example, <del>s</del><ins>fr</ins>e<del>c</del><ins>q</ins>u<del>r</del>e<del> off-li</del>n<del>e</del><ins>t</ins> s<del>tor</del><ins>c</ins>a<del>ge i</del>n<del> lieu of o</del>n<del>l</del>in<del>e</del><ins>g</ins> <del>s</del>to<del>rage</del> <del>when a</del><ins>i</ins>de<del>qua</del><ins>n</ins>t<del>e protect</del>i<del>on o</del>f<ins>y</ins> <del>infor</del>ma<del>t</del><ins>l</ins>i<ins>ci</ins>o<del>n</del><ins>us</ins> <ins>code </ins>at rest <del>c</del>an<del>not</del><ins>d</ins> <del>otherwi</del>se<del> be a</del>c<del>hi</del><ins>ur</ins>e<del>ved</del> <del>and/</del>o<del>r cont</del><ins>ff-l</ins>in<del>uous</del><ins>e</ins> <del>moni</del><ins>s</ins>tor<del>in</del><ins>a</ins>g<ins>e</ins> <del>to </del>i<del>de</del>n<del>tify</del> <del>ma</del>li<del>cio</del><ins>e</ins>u<del>s</del> <del>c</del>o<del>d</del><ins>f onlin</ins>e <del>a</del><ins>s</ins>t<del> </del><ins>o</ins>r<ins>ag</ins>e<del>st</del>. SC-29:title:HETEROGENEITY
SC-29:text:<del>The organization e</del><ins>E</ins>mploy<del>s</del> a diverse set of information technologies for [Assignment: organization-defined <del>information </del>system components] in the implementation of the<del> information</del> system.
SC-29:supplement:Increasing the diversity of information technologies within organizational <del>information </del>systems reduces the impact of potential exploitations o<ins>r compromises o</ins>f specific technologies<ins>.</ins> <del>and</del><ins>Such</ins> <del>al</del><ins>diver</ins>s<del>o</del><ins>ity</ins> <del>d</del><ins>prot</ins>e<del>fend</del><ins>ct</ins>s against common mode failures, including those failures induced by supply chain attacks. Diversity in information technologies also reduces the likelihood that the means adversaries use to compromise one <del>information </del>system component will be equally effective against other system components, thus further increasing the adversary work factor to successfully complete planned <del>cyber </del>attacks. An increase in diversity may add complexity and management overhead which could ultimately lead to mistakes and unauthorized configurations. Related <del>c</del><ins>C</ins>ontrols: <del>S</del>A<ins>U</ins>-<del>12</del><ins>9</ins>, <ins>PL-8, </ins>SA-1<del>4</del><ins>2</ins>, SC-27<ins>, SC-30</ins>.

SC-29 (1):supplement:While frequent changes to operating systems and applications pose configuration management challenges, the changes can result in an increased work factor for adversaries <del>in order </del>to c<del>arry </del>o<ins>nd</ins>u<ins>c</ins>t successful <del>cyber </del>attacks. Changing virtual operating systems or applications, as opposed to changing actual operating systems<del>/</del><ins> or </ins>applications, provide<ins>s</ins> virtual changes that impede attacker success while reducing configuration management efforts. <del>In add</del><ins>V</ins>i<del>tion, vi</del>rtualization techniques can assist <del>organ</del>i<del>zatio</del>n<del>s</del> i<del>n i</del>solating untrustworthy software <del>and/</del>or software of dubious provenance into confined execution environments<ins>. SC-30:title:CONCEALMENT AND MISDIRECTION
SC-30:text:<del>The organization e</del><ins>E</ins>mploy<del>s</del> [Assignment: organization-defined concealment and misdirection techniques] for [Assignment: organization-defined <del>information </del>systems] at [Assignment: organization-defined time<del> </del><ins>-</ins>periods] to confuse and mislead adversaries.
SC-30:supplement:Concealment and misdirection techniques can significantly reduce the targeting capability of adversaries (i.e., window of opportunity and available attack surface) to initiate and complete <del>cyber </del>attacks. For example, virtualization techniques provide organizations with the ability to disguise <del>information </del>systems, potentially reducing the likelihood of successful attacks without the cost of having multiple platforms. Increased use of concealment<del>/</del><ins> and </ins>misdirection techniques <ins>and methods </ins>including, for example, randomness, uncertainty, and virtualization, may sufficiently confuse and mislead adversaries and subsequently increase the risk of discovery and/or exposing tradecraft. Concealment<del>/</del><ins> and </ins>misdirection techniques may also provide organizations additional time to successfully perform core missions and business functions. Because of the time and effort required to support concealment<del>/</del><ins> and </ins>misdirection techniques, it is anticipated that such techniques would be used by organizations on a very limited basis. Related <del>c</del><ins>C</ins>ontrols: <ins>AC-6, </ins>SC-2<ins>5, SC-2</ins>6, SC-29<ins>, SC-44</ins>, SI-14.

SC-30 (2):title:CONCEALMENT AND MISDIRECTION | RANDOMNESS
SC-30 (2):text:<del>The organization e</del><ins>E</ins>mploy<del>s</del> [Assignment: organization-defined techniques] to introduce randomness into organizational operations and assets.
SC-30 (2):supplement:Randomness introduces increased levels of uncertainty for adversaries regarding the actions organizations take in defending <ins>their systems </ins>against <del>cyber </del>attacks. Such actions may impede the ability of adversaries to correctly target information resources of organizations supporting critical missions<del>/</del><ins> or </ins>business functions. Uncertainty may also cause adversaries to hesitate before initiating or continuing <ins>their </ins>attacks. Misdirection techniques involving randomness include, for example, performing certain routine actions at different times of day, employing different information technologies<del> (e.g.</del>, <del>browsers, search engines), </del>using different suppliers, and rotating roles and responsibilities of organizational personnel<ins>. Related Controls: None</ins>.
SC-30 (3):title:CONCEALMENT AND MISDIRECTION | CHANGE PROCESSING <del>/</del><ins>AND</ins> STORAGE LOCATIONS
SC-30 (3):text:<del>T</del><ins>C</ins>h<del>e org</del>an<del>ization chan</del>ge<del>s</del> the location of [Assignment: organization-defined processing and/or storage] [Selection: [Assignment: organization-defined time frequency]; at random time intervals]].
SC-30 (3):supplement:Adversaries target critical <del>organizational </del>missions<del>/</del><ins> and </ins>business functions and the <del>informa</del><ins>sys</ins>t<del>ion r</del>e<ins>m</ins>s<del>ources</del> supporting those missions and functions while at the same time, trying to minimize exposure of their existence and tradecraft. Changing <del>organizational </del>processing and storage locations (sometimes referred to as moving target defense) addresses the advanced persistent threat (APT) using techniques such as virtualization, distributed processing, and replication. This enables organizations to relocate the <del>inf</del><ins>system c</ins>o<del>r</del>m<del>ati</del><ins>p</ins>on<del> r</del>e<ins>nt</ins>s<del>ources</del> (i.e., processing and/or storage) supporting critical missions and business functions. SC-38:title:OPERATIONS SECURITY
SC-38:text:<del>The organization e</del><ins>E</ins>mploy<del>s</del> [Assignment: organization-defined operations security safeguards] to protect key organizational information throughout the system development life cycle.
SC-38:supplement:Operations security (OPSEC) is a systematic process by which potential adversaries can be denied information about the capabilities and intentions of organizations by identifying, controlling, and protecting generally unclassified information that specifically relates to the planning and execution of sensitive organizational activities. The OPSEC process involves five steps: <del>(</del>i<del>) i</del>dentification of critical information<del> (e.g., the security categorization process)</del>; <del>(ii) </del>analysis of threats; <del>(iii) </del>analysis of vulnerabilities; <del>(iv) </del>assessment of risks; and <del>(v) </del>the application of appropriate countermeasures. OPSEC safeguards are applied to <del>b</del>o<del>th o</del>rganizational <del>information </del>systems and the environments in which those systems operate. OPSEC safeguards <del>hel</del>p<del> to p</del>rotect the confidentiality of key information including, for example, limiting the sharing of information with suppliers and potential suppliers of <del>information </del>system components<del>,</del> <del>inform</del>a<del>tio</del>n<del> technology pro</del>d<del>ucts</del> <del>and </del>services, and with other non-organizational elements and individuals. Information critical to <ins>organizational </ins>mission<del>/</del><ins> and </ins>business success includes, for example, user identities, element uses, suppliers, supply chain processes, functional and security requirements, system design specifications, testing <ins>and evaluation </ins>protocols, and security control implementation details. Related <del>c</del><ins>C</ins>ontrols: <ins>CA-2, CA-7, PL-1, PM-9, PM-12, </ins>RA-2, RA-<ins>3, RA-</ins>5, SA-12<ins>, SC-7</ins>.

SC-39:title:PROCESS ISOLATION
SC-39:text:<del>The inform</del><ins>M</ins>a<del>t</del>i<del>o</del>n<del> sys</del>t<del>em m</del>ain<del>tains</del> a separate execution domain for each executing process<ins> with the system</ins>.
SC-39:supplement:<del>Information s</del><ins>S</ins>ystems can maintain separate execution domains for each executing process by assigning each process a separate address space. Each <del>information </del>system process has a distinct address space so that communication between processes is performed in a manner controlled through the security functions, and one process cannot modify the executing code of another process. Maintaining separate execution domains for executing processes can be achieved, for example, by implementing separate address spaces. This capability is <ins>re</ins>a<ins>dily a</ins>vailable in most commercial operating systems that employ multi-state processor technologies. Related <del>c</del><ins>C</ins>ontrols: AC-3, AC-4, AC-6, <del>S</del>A<ins>C</ins>-<del>4, SA-</del><ins>2</ins>5, SA-8, SC-2, SC-3.
SC-39 (1):title:PROCESS ISOLATION | HARDWARE SEPARATION
SC-39 (1):text:<del>The infor</del><ins>I</ins>m<del>ation system im</del>plement<del>s underlying</del> hardware separation mechanisms to facilitate process separation.
SC-39 (1):supplement:Hardware-based separation of <del>information </del>system processes is generally less susceptible to compromise than software-based separation, thus providing greater assurance that the separation will be enforced. <del>Underlying h</del><ins>H</ins>ardware separation mechanisms include, for example, hardware memory management<ins>. Related Controls: None</ins>.

SC-40:title:WIRELESS LINK PROTECTION
SC-40:text:<del>The info</del><ins>P</ins>r<del>mati</del>o<del>n sys</del>te<del>m prote</del>ct<del>s</del> external and internal [Assignment: organization-defined wireless links] from [Assignment: organization-defined types of signal parameter attacks or references to sources for such attacks].
SC-40:supplement:This control applies to internal and external wireless communication links that may be visible to individuals who are not authorized <del>information </del>system users. Adversaries can exploit the signal parameters of wireless links if such links are not adequately protected. There are many ways to exploit the signal parameters of wireless links to gain intelligence, deny service, or <del>to </del>spoof users of organizational <del>information </del>systems. This control reduces the impact of attacks that are unique to wireless systems. If organizations rely on commercial service providers for transmission services as commodity items rather than as fully dedicated services, it may not be possible to implement this control. Related <del>c</del><ins>C</ins>ontrols: AC-18, SC-5.
SC-40 (1):title:WIRELESS LINK PROTECTION | ELECTROMAGNETIC INTERFERENCE
SC-40 (1):text:<del>The infor</del><ins>I</ins>m<del>ation system im</del>plement<del>s</del> cryptographic mechanisms that achieve [Assignment: organization-defined level of protection] against the effects of intentional electromagnetic interference.
SC-40 (1):supplement:This control enhancement protects against intentional jamming that might deny or impair communications by ensuring that wireless spread spectrum waveforms used to provide anti-jam protection are not predictable by unauthorized individuals. The control enhancement may also coincidentally help to mitigate the effects of unintentional jamming due to interference from legitimate transmitters sharing the same spectrum. Mission requirements, projected threats, concept of operations, and applicable legislation, directives, regulations, policies, standards, and guidelines determine levels of wireless link availability and performance/cryptography needed. Related <del>c</del><ins>C</ins>ontrols: SC-12, SC-13.
SC-40 (2):title:WIRELESS LINK PROTECTION | REDUCE DETECTION POTENTIAL
SC-40 (2):text:<del>The infor</del><ins>I</ins>m<del>ation system im</del>plement<del>s</del> cryptographic mechanisms to reduce the detection potential of wireless links to [Assignment: organization-defined level of reduction].
SC-40 (2):supplement:This control enhancement is needed for covert communications and protecting wireless transmitters from being geo-located by their transmissions. The control enhancement ensures that spread spectrum waveforms used to achieve low probability of detection are not predictable by unauthorized individuals. Mission requirements, projected threats, concept of operations, and applicable legislation, directives, regulations, policies, standards, and guidelines determine the levels to which wireless links should be undetectable. Related <del>c</del><ins>C</ins>ontrols: SC-12, SC-13.
SC-40 (3):title:WIRELESS LINK PROTECTION | IMITATIVE OR MANIPULATIVE COMMUNICATIONS DECEPTION
SC-40 (3):text:<del>The infor</del><ins>I</ins>m<del>ation system im</del>plement<del>s</del> cryptographic mechanisms to identify and reject wireless transmissions that are deliberate attempts to achieve imitative or manipulative communications deception based on signal parameters.
SC-40 (3):supplement:This control enhancement ensures that the signal parameters of wireless transmissions are not predictable by unauthorized individuals. Such unpredictability reduces the probability of imitative or manipulative communications deception based upon signal parameters alone. Related <del>c</del><ins>C</ins>ontrols: SC-12, SC-13<ins>, SI-4</ins>.
SC-40 (4):title:WIRELESS LINK PROTECTION | SIGNAL PARAMETER IDENTIFICATION
SC-40 (4):text:<del>The infor</del><ins>I</ins>m<del>ation system im</del>plement<del>s</del> cryptographic mechanisms to prevent the identification of [Assignment: organization-defined wireless transmitters] by using the transmitter signal parameters.
SC-40 (4):supplement:Radio fingerprinting techniques identify the unique signal parameters of transmitters to fingerprint such transmitters for purposes of tracking and mission/user identification. This control enhancement protects against the unique identification of wireless transmitters for purposes of intelligence exploitation by ensuring that anti-fingerprinting alterations to signal parameters are not predictable by unauthorized individuals. This control enhancement helps assure mission success when anonymity is required. Related <del>c</del><ins>C</ins>ontrols: SC-12, SC-13.
SC-40:references:None

SC-41:title:PORT AND I/O DEVICE ACCESS
SC-41:text:<del>Th</del><ins>[S</ins>e<del> organiza</del><ins>lec</ins>tion<ins>:</ins> <del>p</del><ins>P</ins>hysically <ins>or Logically] </ins>disable<del>s</del> or remove<del>s</del> [Assignment: organization-defined connection ports or input/output devices] on [Assignment: organization-defined <del>information </del>systems or<del> information</del> system components].
SC-41:supplement:Connection ports include, for example, Universal Serial Bus (USB) and Firewire (IEEE 1394). Input/output (I/O) devices include, for example, Compact Disk (CD) and Digital Video Disk (DVD) drives. <del>Phys</del><ins>D</ins>i<del>cally di</del>sabling or removing such connection ports and I/O devices helps prevent exfiltration of information from <del>information </del>systems and the introduction of malicious code into systems from those ports<ins> or devices. Physically disabling or removing ports and</ins>/<ins>or </ins>devices<ins> is the stronger action. Related Controls: AC-20, MP-7</ins>.

SC-42:title:SENSOR CAPABILITY AND DATA
SC-42:text:<del>The information system:</del>
SC-42 a:text:<del>The information system: </del>Prohibit<del>s</del> the remote activation of environmental sensing capabilitie<ins>s on organizational systems or system component</ins>s with the following exceptions: [Assignment: organization-defined exceptions where remote activation of sensors is allowed]; and
SC-42 b:text:<del>The information system: </del>Provide<del>s</del> an explicit indication of sensor use to [Assignment: organization-defined class of users].
SC-42:supplement:This control often applies to types of <del>information </del>systems or system components characterized as mobile devices, for example, smart phones, tablets, and E-readers. These systems often include sensors that can collect and record data regarding the environment where the system is in use. Sensors that are embedded within mobile devices include, for example, cameras, microphones, Global Positioning System (GPS) mechanisms, and accelerometers. While the sensors on mobiles devices provide an important function, if activated covertly, such devices can potentially provide a means for adversaries to learn valuable information about individuals and organizations. For example, remotely activating the GPS function on a mobile device could provide an adversary with the ability to track the specific movements of an individual<ins>. Related Controls: None</ins>.
SC-42 (1):title:SENSOR CAPABILITY AND DATA | REPORTING TO AUTHORIZED INDIVIDUALS OR ROLES
SC-42 (1):text:<del>Th</del><ins>V</ins>e<del> o</del>r<del>gan</del>i<del>zation</del><ins>fy</ins> <del>ensures </del>that the<del> information</del> system is configured so that data or information collected by the [Assignment: organization-defined sensors] is only reported to authorized individuals or roles.
SC-42 (1):supplement:In situations where sensors are activated by authorized individuals<del> (e.g.</del>, <del>end users), </del>it is still possible that the data<del>/</del><ins> or </ins>information collected by the sensors will be sent to unauthorized entities<ins>. Related Controls: None</ins>.
SC-42 (2):title:SENSOR CAPABILITY AND DATA | AUTHORIZED USE
SC-42 (2):text:<del>The organization e</del><ins>E</ins>mploy<del>s</del> <del>the following measures: </del>[Assignment: organization-defined measures]<del>,</del> so that data or information collected by [Assignment: organization-defined sensors] is only used for authorized purposes.
SC-42 (2):supplement:Information collected by sensors for a specific authorized purpose <del>potentially </del>could be misused for some unauthorized purpose. For example, GPS sensors that are used to support traffic navigation could be misused to track movements of individuals. Measures to mitigate such activities include, for example, additional training to ensure that authorized <del>part</del>i<del>e</del><ins>ndividual</ins>s do not abuse their authority<del>,</del><ins>;</ins> <del>or</del><ins>and</ins> <del>(</del>in the case where sensor data<del>/</del><ins> or </ins>information is maintained by external parties<del>)</del><ins>,</ins> contractual restrictions on the use of <del>t</del><ins>suc</ins>h<del>e</del> data/information<ins>. Related Controls: PA-2</ins>.
SC-42 (3):title:SENSOR CAPABILITY AND DATA | PROHIBIT USE OF DEVICES
SC-42 (3):text:<del>The o</del><ins>P</ins>r<del>ganizati</del>o<del>n pro</del>hibit<del>s</del> the use of devices possessing [Assignment: organization-defined environmental sensing capabilities] in [Assignment: organization-defined facilities, areas, or systems].
SC-42 (3):supplement:For example, organizations may prohibit individuals from bringing cell phones or digital cameras into certain <ins>designated </ins>facilities or <del>spe</del>c<del>ific c</del>ontrolled areas within facilities where classified information is stored or sensitive conversations are taking plac<ins>e. Related Controls: Non</ins>e.
SC-42 (4):title:<ins>SENSOR CAPABILITY AND DATA | NOTICE OF COLLECTION</ins>
SC-42 (4):text:<ins>Employ the following measures to facilitate an individual’s awareness that personally identifiable information is being collected by [Assignment: organization-defined sensors]: [Assignment: organization-defined measures].</ins>
SC-42 (4):supplement:<ins>Awareness that organizational sensors are collecting data enable individuals to more effectively engage in managing their privacy. Measures can include, for example, conventional written notices and sensor configurations that make individuals aware directly or indirectly through other devices that the sensor is collecting information. Usability and efficacy of the notice are important considerations. Related Controls: IP-1, IP-2, IP-4.</ins>
SC-42 (5):title:<ins>SENSOR CAPABILITY AND DATA | COLLECTION MINIMIZATION</ins>
SC-42 (5):text:<ins>Employ [Assignment: organization-defined sensors] that are configured to minimize the collection of information about individuals that is not needed.</ins>
SC-42 (5):supplement:<ins>Although policies to control for authorized use can be applied to information once it is collected, minimizing the collection of information that is not needed mitigates privacy-related risk at the system entry point and mitigates the risk of policy control failures. Sensor configurations include, for example, the obscuring of human features such as blurring or pixelating flesh tones. Related Controls: None.</ins>

SC-44:title:DETONATION CHAMBERS
SC-44:text:<del>The organization e</del><ins>E</ins>mploy<del>s</del> a detonation chamber capability within [Assignment: organization-defined<del> information</del> system, system component, or location].
SC-44:supplement:Detonation chambers, also known as dynamic execution environments, allow organizations to open email attachments, execute untrusted or suspicious applications, and execute Universal Resource Locator <del>(URL) </del>requests in the safety of an isolated environment or <ins>a </ins>virtualized sandbox. These protected and isolated execution environments provide a means of determining whether the associated attachments<del>/</del><ins> or </ins>applications contain malicious code. While related to the concept of deception nets, th<del>e</del><ins>is</ins> control is not intended to maintain a long-term environment in which adversaries can operate and their actions can be observed. Rather, it is intended to quickly identify malicious code and reduce the likelihood that the code is propagated to user environments of operation <del>(</del>or prevent such propagation completely<del>)</del>. Related <del>c</del><ins>C</ins>ontrols: SC-7, SC-25, SC-26, SC-30<ins>, SC-35, SI-3, SI-7</ins>.

SE-1:title:<del>INVENTORY OF PERSONALLY IDENTIFIABLE INFORMATION</del>
SE-1:text:<del>The organization:</del>
SE-1 a:text:<del>The organization: Establishes, maintains, and updates [Assignment: organization-defined frequency] an inventory that contains a listing of all programs and information systems identified as collecting, using, maintaining, or sharing personally identifiable information (PII); and</del>
SE-1 b:text:<del>The organization: Provides each update of the PII inventory to the CIO or information security official [Assignment: organization-defined frequency] to support the establishment of information security requirements for all new or modified information systems containing PII.</del>
SE-1:supplement:<del>The PII inventory enables organizations to implement effective administrative, technical, and physical security policies and procedures to protect PII consistent with Appendix F, and to mitigate risks of PII exposure. As one method of gathering information for their PII inventories, organizations may extract the following information elements from Privacy Impact Assessments (PIA) for information systems containing PII: (i) the name and acronym for each system identified; (ii) the types of PII contained in that system; (iii) classification of level of sensitivity of all types of PII, as combined in that information system; and (iv) classification of level of potential risk of substantial harm, embarrassment, inconvenience, or unfairness to affected individuals, as well as the financial or reputational risks to organizations, if PII is exposed. Organizations take due care in updating the inventories by identifying linkable data that could create PII. Related controls: AR-1, AR-4, AR-5, AT-1, DM-1, PM-5.</del>
SE-1:references:<del>The Privacy Act of 1974, 5 U.S.C. § 552a (e) (10); Section 208(b)(2), E-Government Act of 2002 (P.L. 107-347); OMB Memorandum 03-22; OMB Circular A-130, Appendix I; FIPS Publication 199; NIST Special Publications 800-37, 800-122</del>
SE-2:title:<del>PRIVACY INCIDENT RESPONSE</del>
SE-2:text:<del>The organization:</del>
SE-2 a:text:<del>The organization: Develops and implements a Privacy Incident Response Plan; and</del>
SE-2 b:text:<del>The organization: Provides an organized and effective response to privacy incidents in accordance with the organizational Privacy Incident Response Plan.</del>
SE-2:supplement:<del>In contrast to the Incident Response (IR) family in Appendix F, which concerns a broader range of incidents affecting information security, this control uses the term Privacy Incident to describe only those incidents that relate to personally identifiable information (PII). The organization Privacy Incident Response Plan is developed under the leadership of the SAOP/CPO. The plan includes: (i) the establishment of a cross-functional Privacy Incident Response Team that reviews, approves, and participates in the execution of the Privacy Incident Response Plan; (ii) a process to determine whether notice to oversight organizations or affected individuals is appropriate and to provide that notice accordingly; (iii) a privacy risk assessment process to determine the extent of harm, embarrassment, inconvenience, or unfairness to affected individuals and, where appropriate, to take steps to mitigate any such risks; (iv) internal procedures to ensure prompt reporting by employees and contractors of any privacy incident to information security officials and the Senior Agency Official for Privacy (SAOP)/Chief Privacy Officer (CPO), consistent with organizational incident management structures; and (v) internal procedures for reporting noncompliance with organizational privacy policy by employees or contractors to appropriate management or oversight officials. Some organizations may be required by law or policy to provide notice to oversight organizations in the event of a breach. Organizations may also choose to integrate Privacy Incident Response Plans with Security Incident Response Plans, or keep the plans separate. Related controls: AR-1, AR-4, AR-5, AR-6, AU-1 through 14, IR-1 through IR-8, RA-1.</del>
SE-2:references:<del>The Privacy Act of 1974, 5 U.S.C. § 552a (e), (i)(1), and (m); Federal Information Security Management Act (FISMA) of 2002, 44 U.S.C. § 3541; OMB Memoranda 06-19, 07-16; NIST Special Publication 800-37</del>

SI-2:title:FLAW REMEDIATION
SI-2:text:<del>The organization:</del>
SI-2 a:text:<del>The organization: </del>Identif<del>ies</del><ins>y</ins>, report<del>s</del>, and correct<del>s information</del> system flaws;
SI-2 b:text:T<del>h</del>e<del> organization: Te</del>st<del>s</del> software and firmware updates related to flaw remediation for effectiveness and potential side effects before installation;
SI-2 c:text:<del>The organization: </del>Install<del>s</del> security-relevant software and firmware updates within [Assignment: organization-defined time<del> </del><ins>-</ins>period] of the release of the updates; and
SI-2 d:text:<del>The organization: </del>Incorporate<del>s</del> flaw remediation into the organizational configuration management process.
SI-2:supplement:Organizations identify <del>information </del>systems affected by <del>announced </del>software flaws including potential vulnerabilities resulting from those flaws, and report this information to designated organizational personnel with information security <ins>and p</ins>r<ins>ivacy r</ins>esponsibilities. Security-relevant software updates include, for example, patches, service packs, hot fixes, and anti-virus signatures. Organizations also address flaws discovered during <del>security </del>assessments, continuous monitoring, incident response activities, and system error handling. <del>Organizations take advantage of available resources such as the Common Weakness Enumeration (CWE) or Common Vulnerabilities and Exposures (CVE) databases in remediating flaws discovered in organizational information systems. </del>By incorporating flaw remediation into ongoing configuration management processes, required<del>/anticipated</del> remediation actions can be tracked and verified. <del>Flaw remediation actions that can be tracked and verified include, for example, determining whether organizations follow US-CERT guidance and Information Assurance Vulnerability Alerts. </del>Organization-defined time<del> </del><ins>-</ins>periods for updating security-relevant software and firmware may vary based on a variety of factors including, for example, the security category of the <del>information </del>system or the criticality of the update (i.e., severity of the vulnerability related to the discovered flaw). Some types of flaw remediation may require more testing than other types. Organizations determine the <del>degree and </del>type of testing needed for the specific type of flaw remediation activity under consideration and <del>also </del>the types of changes that are to be configuration-managed. In some situations, organizations may determine that t<del>h</del>e<del> te</del>sting of software <del>and/</del>or firmware updates is not necessary or practical, for example, when implementing simple anti-virus signature updates. Organizations <del>m</del>a<del>y a</del>lso consider in testing decisions, whether security-relevant software or firmware updates are obtained from authorized sources with appropriate digital signatures. Related <del>c</del><ins>C</ins>ontrols: CA-<del>2</del><ins>4</ins>, C<del>A</del><ins>M</ins>-<del>7</del><ins>3</ins>, CM-<del>3</del><ins>4</ins>, CM-5, CM-<ins>6, CM-</ins>8, MA-2, <del>I</del>R<del>-4, R</del>A-5, SA-10, SA-11<ins>, SI-3, SI-5, SI-7</ins>, SI-11.

This includes polymorphic malicious code (i.e., code that changes signatures when it replicates). This control enhancement does not preclude the use of signature-based detection mechanisms.</del>
SI-3 (8):title:MALICIOUS CODE PROTECTION | DETECT UNAUTHORIZED COMMANDS
SI-3 (8):text:<del>Th</del><ins>D</ins>e<del> informa</del>t<del>ion syst</del>e<del>m dete</del>ct<del>s</del> [Assignment: organization-defined unauthorized operating system commands] through the kernel application programming interface at [Assignment: organization-defined <del>information </del>system hardware components] and [Selection (one or more): issue<del>s</del> a warning; audit<del>s</del> the command execution; prevent<del>s</del> the execution of the command].
SI-3 (8):supplement:This control enhancement can also be applied to critical interfaces other than kernel-based interfaces, including for example, interfaces with virtual machines and privileged applications. Unauthorized operating system commands include, for example, commands for kernel functions from <del>information </del>system processes that are not trusted to initiate such commands, or commands for kernel functions that are suspicious even though commands of that type are reasonable for processes to initiate. Organizations can define the malicious commands to be detected by a combination of command types, command classes, or specific instances of commands. Organizations can define hardware components by <del>s</del><ins>com</ins>p<ins>on</ins>e<del>cific</del><ins>nt</ins> <ins>type, </ins>component, component <del>type, </del>location in the network, or combination therein. Organizations may select different actions for different types<del>/</del><ins>, </ins>classes<del>/specific</del><ins>,</ins> <ins>or </ins>instances of <del>potentially </del>malicious commands. Related <del>c</del><ins>C</ins>ontrol<ins>s</ins>: AU-<ins>2, AU-</ins>6<ins>, AU-12</ins>.
SI-3 (9):title:MALICIOUS CODE PROTECTION | AUTHENTICATE REMOTE COMMANDS
SI-3 (9):text:<del>The infor</del><ins>I</ins>m<del>ation system im</del>plement<del>s</del> [Assignment: organization-defined security safeguards] to authenticate [Assignment: organization-defined remote commands].
SI-3 (9):supplement:This control enhancement protects against unauthorized commands and replay of authorized commands. This capability is important for those remote <del>information </del>systems whose loss, malfunction, misdirection, or exploitation would have immediate and/or serious consequences<ins>,</ins> <del>(e.</del><ins>includin</ins>g<del>.</del>, <ins>for example, </ins>injury or death, property damage, loss of high-value<del>d</del> assets<ins>,</ins> <ins>c</ins>o<ins>mp</ins>r<ins>omise</ins> <ins>of cla</ins>s<ins>sifi</ins>e<ins>d or co</ins>n<ins>trolled uncla</ins>s<ins>s</ins>i<del>t</del><ins>f</ins>i<del>v</del>e<ins>d</ins> information, or failure of <del>i</del>m<del>portant m</del>issions<del>/</del><ins> or </ins>business functions<del>)</del>. Authentication safeguards for remote commands <del>h</del>e<del>lp to e</del>nsure that <del>information </del>systems accept and execute <ins>commands </ins>in the order intended, <ins>execute </ins>only authorized commands, and <ins>rejec</ins>t<del>hat</del> unauthorized commands<del> are rejected</del>. Cryptographic mechanisms can be employed, for example, to authenticate remote commands. Related <del>c</del><ins>C</ins>ontrols: SC-12, SC-13, SC-23.
SI-3 (10):title:MALICIOUS CODE PROTECTION | MALICIOUS CODE ANALYSIS
SI-3 (10):text:<del>The organization:</del>
SI-3 (10) (a):text:<del>The organization: </del>Employ<del>s</del> [Assignment: organization-defined tools and techniques] to analyze the characteristics and behavior of malicious code; and
SI-3 (10) (b):text:<del>The organization: </del>Incorporate<del>s</del> the results from malicious code analysis into organizational incident response and flaw remediation processes.
SI-3 (10):supplement:The <del>application</del><ins>use</ins> of <del>selected </del>malicious code analysis tools <del>and techniques </del>provides organizations with a more in-depth understanding of adversary tradecraft (i.e., tactics, techniques, and procedures) and the functionality and purpose of specific instances of malicious code. Understanding the characteristics of malicious code facilitates more effective organizational responses to current and future threats. Organizations can <ins>also </ins>conduct malicious code analyses by using reverse engineering techniques or by monitoring the behavior of executing cod<ins>e. Related Controls: Non</ins>e.

SI-4 (17):title:<del>INFORMATION </del>SYSTEM MONITORING | INTEGRATED SITUATIONAL AWARENESS

SI-4 (17):supplement:This control enhancement correlates monitoring information from a more diverse set of information sources to achieve integrated situational awareness. In contrast to SI-4<del> </del>(16) which correlates the various cyber monitoring information, this control enhancement correlates monitoring beyond <del>jus</del>t<del> t</del>he cyber domain. Such monitoring may help reveal attacks on organizations that are operating across multiple attack vectors. Related <del>c</del><ins>C</ins>ontrol<ins>s</ins>:<ins> AU-16, PE-6,</ins> SA-12.

SI-4 (24):title:<del>INFORMATION </del>SYSTEM MONITORING | INDICATORS OF COMPROMISE
SI-4 (24):text:<del>The </del><ins>D</ins>i<del>nformation </del>s<del>ystem dis</del>cover<del>s</del>, collect<del>s</del>, <ins>an</ins>d<ins> d</ins>istribute<ins> to [A</ins>s<del>,</del><ins>signment:</ins> <ins>org</ins>an<ins>ization-</ins>d<ins>efined</ins> <del>u</del><ins>per</ins>s<ins>onn</ins>e<ins>l or role</ins>s<ins>],</ins> indicators of compromise.
SI-4 (24):supplement:Indicators of compromise (IOC) are forensic artifacts from intrusions that are identified on organizational <del>information </del>systems <del>(</del>at the host or network level<del>)</del>. IOCs provide <del>organizations with </del>valuable information on <del>object</del>s<del> or information s</del>ystems that have been compromised. IOCs for the discovery of compromised hosts can include<ins>,</ins> for example, the creation of registry key values. IOCs for network traffic include, for example, Universal Resource Locator <del>(URL) </del>or protocol elements that indicate mal<del>war</del><ins>icious cod</ins>e command and control servers. The rapid distribution and adoption of IOCs can improve information security by reducing the time that <del>information </del>systems and organizations are vulnerable to the same exploit or attack<ins>. Related Controls: AC-18</ins>.
SI-4 (25):title:<ins>SYSTEM MONITORING | PERSONALLY IDENTIFIABLE INFORMATION MONITORING</ins>
SI-4 (25):text:<ins>Employ automated mechanisms to monitor:</ins>
SI-4 (25) (a):text:<ins>Employ automated mechanisms to monitor: For unauthorized access or usage of personally identifiable information; and</ins>
SI-4 (25) (b):text:<ins>Employ automated mechanisms to monitor: The collection, creation, accuracy, relevance, timeliness, impact, and completeness of personally identifiable information.</ins>
SI-4 (25):supplement:<ins>Monitoring the collection, creation, accuracy, relevance, timeliness, impact, and completeness of personally identifiable information helps improve data quality. Automated monitoring techniques can create unintended privacy risks because automated controls may connect to external or otherwise unrelated systems. The matching of records between these systems may create linkages with unintended consequences. Organizations assess and document these risks in their privacy impact assessment and make determinations that are in alignment with their privacy program plan. Related Controls: PM-24, PM-26, SI-19.</ins>

SI-10:title:INFORMATION INPUT VALIDATION
SI-10:text:<del>T</del><ins>C</ins>he<del> information system </del>c<del>hec</del>k<del>s</del> the validity of [Assignment: organization-defined information inputs].
SI-10:supplement:Checking the valid syntax and semantics of <del>information </del>system inputs <del>(e.</del><ins>includin</ins>g<del>.</del>, <ins>for example, </ins>character set, length, numerical range, and acceptable values<del>)</del><ins>,</ins> verifies that inputs match specified definitions for format and content. Software applications typically follow well-defined protocols that use structured messages (i.e., commands or queries) to communicate between software modules or system components. Structured messages can contain raw or unstructured data interspersed with metadata or control information. If software applications use attacker-supplied inputs to construct structured messages without properly encoding such messages, then the attacker could insert malicious commands or special characters that can cause the data to be interpreted as control information or metadata. Consequently, the module or component that receives the <ins>corrup</ins>t<del>aint</del>ed output will perform the wrong operations or otherwise interpret the data incorrectly. Prescreening inputs prior to passing to interpreters prevents the content from being unintentionally interpreted as commands. Input validation <del>h</del>e<del>lps to e</del>nsure<ins>s</ins> accurate and correct inputs and prevent attacks such as cross-site scripting and a variety of injection attacks<ins>. Related Controls: None</ins>.
SI-10 (1):title:INFORMATION INPUT VALIDATION | MANUAL OVERRIDE CAPABILITY
SI-10 (1):text:<del>The information system:</del>
SI-10 (1) (a):text:<del>The information system: </del>Provide<del>s</del> a manual override capability for input validation of [Assignment: organization-defined inputs];
SI-10 (1) (b):text:<del>The information system: </del>Restrict<del>s</del> the use of the manual override capability to only [Assignment: organization-defined authorized individuals]; and
SI-10 (1) (c):text:<del>The information system: </del>Audit<del>s</del> the use of the manual override capability.
SI-10 (1):supplement:<del>R</del><ins>In c</ins>e<ins>rtain situations, for examp</ins>l<ins>e, during events th</ins>at<ins> ar</ins>e<ins> </ins>d<ins>efined</ins> <ins>in organizational </ins>cont<ins>ingency plans, a manual ove</ins>r<ins>ride capability f</ins>o<ins>r input va</ins>l<ins>idation may be needed. Such manual override</ins>s<ins> are used only in limited circumstances and with the inputs defined by the organization. Related Controls</ins>: <ins>A</ins>C<del>M</del>-3, <del>CM</del><ins>AU</ins>-<del>5</del><ins>2, AU-12</ins>.
SI-10 (2):title:INFORMATION INPUT VALIDATION | REVIEW <del>/</del><ins>AND</ins> RESOL<del>UTION OF</del><ins>VE</ins> ERRORS
SI-10 (2):text:<del>Th</del><ins>R</ins>e<ins>view</ins> <del>org</del>an<del>ization</del><ins>d</ins> <del>ensu</del>res<ins>olve</ins> <del>that </del>input validation errors <del>are revie</del>w<del>ed and resolved w</del>ithin [Assignment: organization-defined time<del> </del><ins>-</ins>period].

SI-10 (3):title:INFORMATION INPUT VALIDATION | PREDICTABLE BEHAVIOR
SI-10 (3):text:<del>Th</del><ins>V</ins>e<del> </del><ins>r</ins>i<del>n</del>f<del>orm</del><ins>y th</ins>at<del>ion</del> <ins>the </ins>system behaves in a predictable and documented manner<del> that reflects organizational and system objectives</del> when invalid inputs are received.
SI-10 (3):supplement:A common vulnerability in organizational <del>information </del>systems is unpredictable behavior when invalid inputs are received. This control enhancement ensures that there is predictable behavior in the face of invalid inputs by specifying <del>information </del>system responses that facilitate transitioning the system to known states without adverse, unintended side effects<ins>. The invalid inputs are those inputs related to the information inputs defined by the organization in the base control. Related Controls: None</ins>.
SI-10 (4):title:INFORMATION INPUT VALIDATION | <del>REVIEW / </del>TIMING INTERACTIONS
SI-10 (4):text:<del>The organization a</del><ins>A</ins>ccount<del>s</del> for timing interactions among<del> information</del> system components in determining appropriate responses for invalid inputs.
SI-10 (4):supplement:In addressing invalid <del>information </del>system inputs received across protocol interfaces, timing interactions become relevant, where one protocol needs to consider the impact of the error response on other protocols within the protocol stack. For example, 802.11 standard wireless network protocols do not interact well with Transmission Control Protocols (TCP) when packets are dropped (which could be due to invalid packet input). TCP assumes packet losses are due to congestion, while packets lost over 802.11 links are typically dropped due to collisions or noise on the link. If TCP makes a congestion response, it takes <del>precisely </del>the wrong action in response to a collision event. Adversaries may be able to use <ins>wh</ins>a<ins>t a</ins>pp<ins>e</ins>ar<del>en</del><ins>s </ins>t<del>ly</del><ins>o</ins> <ins>be </ins>acceptable individual behaviors of the protocols in concert to achieve adverse effects through suitable construction of invalid input<ins>. Related Controls: None</ins>.
SI-10 (5):title:INFORMATION INPUT VALIDATION | RESTRICT INPUTS TO TRUSTED SOURCES AND APPROVED FORMATS
SI-10 (5):text:<del>Th</del><ins>R</ins>e<del> organization re</del>strict<del>s</del> the use of information inputs to [Assignment: organization-defined trusted sources] and/or [Assignment: organization-defined formats].
SI-10 (5):supplement:This control enhancement applies the concept of whitelisting to information inputs. Specifying known trusted sources for information inputs and acceptable formats for such inputs can reduce the probability of malicious activity.<ins> Related Controls: AC-3, AC-6.</ins>

SI-13:text:<del>The organization:</del>

SI-13 b:text:<del>The organization: </del>Provide<del>s</del> substitute<del> information</del> system components and a means to exchange active and standby components at [Assignment: organization-defined MTTF substitution criteria].
SI-13:supplement:While MTTF is primarily a reliability issue, this control addresses potential failures of s<del>pecific information s</del>ystem components that provide security capability. Failure rates reflect installation-specific consideration, not industry-average. Organizations define <ins>the </ins>criteria for substitution of <del>information </del>system components based on <ins>the </ins>MTTF value with consideration for resulting potential harm from component failures. Transfer of responsibilities between active and standby components does not compromise safety, operational readiness, or security capability<ins>.</ins> <del>(</del><ins>This includ</ins>e<del>.g.</del><ins>s</ins>, <ins>for exam</ins>p<ins>le, p</ins>reservation of s<ins>ys</ins>t<ins>em st</ins>ate variables<del>)</del>. Standby components remain available at all times except for maintenance issues or recovery failures in progress. Related <del>c</del><ins>C</ins>ontrols: CP-2, CP-10, <ins>CP-13, </ins>MA<ins>-2, MA-6, SC</ins>-6.

SI-14:title:NON-PERSISTENCE
SI-14:text:<del>The organization i</del><ins>I</ins>mplement<del>s</del> non-persistent [Assignment: organization-defined<del> information</del> system components and services] that are initiated in a known state and terminated [Selection (one or more): upon end of session of use; periodically at [Assignment: organization-defined frequency]].
SI-14:supplement:This control mitigates risk from advanced persistent threats (APTs) by significantly reducing the targeting capability of adversaries (i.e., window of opportunity and available attack surface) to initiate and complete <del>cyber </del>attacks. By implementing the concept of non-persistence for selected <del>information </del>system components, organizations can provide a known state computing resource for a specific <ins>time-</ins>period <del>of </del>t<del>ime t</del>hat does not give adversaries sufficient time on target to exploit vulnerabilities in organizational <del>information </del>systems and the environments in which those systems operate. Since the <del>advanced</del><ins>APT</ins> <del>pers</del>is<del>tent</del> <del>thre</del>a<del>t</del> <del>is a </del>high-end<ins>,</ins> <ins>sophis</ins>t<ins>icated t</ins>hreat <del>with </del>regard<ins>ing</ins> <del>to </del>capability, intent, and targeting, organizations assume that over an extended period<del> of time</del>, a percentage of <del>cyber </del>attacks will be successful. Non-persistent <del>information </del>system components and services are activated as required using protected information and terminated periodically or <del>upon</del><ins>at</ins> the end of sessions. Non-persistence increases the work factor of adversaries in attempting to compromise or breach organizational <del>information </del>systems. Non-persisten<del>t</del><ins>ce</ins> <ins>can be achieved by refre</ins>s<ins>hing s</ins>ystem components<del> can be implemented</del>, for example, by periodically re-imaging components or by using a variety of common virtualization techniques. Non-persistent services can be implemented using virtualization techniques as part of virtual machines or as new instances of processes on physical machines (either persistent or non-persistent).<ins> </ins>The benefit of periodic refreshes of <del>information </del>system components<del>/</del><ins> and </ins>services is that it does not require organizations to first determine whether compromises of components or services have occurred (something that may often be difficult <del>for organiza</del>t<del>i</del>o<del>ns</del> <del>to </del>determine). The refresh of selected <del>information </del>system components and services occurs with sufficient frequency to prevent the spread or intended impact of attacks, but not with such frequency that it makes the <del>information </del>system unstable. <del>In som</del><ins>R</ins>e<del> instances, re</del>freshes of critical components and services may be done periodically <del>in order </del>to hinder the ability of adversaries to exploit optimum windows of vulnerabilities. Related <del>c</del><ins>C</ins>ontrols: SC-30, SC-34.
SI-14 (1):title:NON-PERSISTENCE | REFRESH FROM TRUSTED SOURCES
SI-14 (1):text:<del>The org</del><ins>Obt</ins>a<del>n</del>i<del>zatio</del>n <del>en</del>s<del>ures that s</del>oftware and data employed during <del>information </del>system component and service refreshes<del> are obtained</del> from [Assignment: organization-defined trusted sources].
SI-14 (1):supplement:Trusted sources include, for example, software<del>/</del><ins> an</ins>d<ins> d</ins>ata from write-once, read-only media or from selected off-line secure storage facilities<ins>. Related Controls: None</ins>.

SI-15:title:INFORMATION OUTPUT FILTERING
SI-15:text:<del>The inform</del><ins>V</ins>a<del>tion system va</del>lidate<del>s</del> information output from [Assignment: organization-defined software programs and/or applications] to ensure that the information is consistent with the expected content.
SI-15:supplement:Certain types of <del>cyber </del>attacks<ins>,</ins> <del>(e.</del><ins>includin</ins>g<del>.</del><ins> for example</ins>, SQL injections<del>)</del><ins>,</ins> produce output results that are unexpected or inconsistent with the output results that would normally be expected from software programs or applications. This control enhancement focuses on detecting extraneous content, preventing such extraneous content from being displayed, and <ins>then </ins>alerting monitoring tools that anomalous behavior has been discovered. Related <del>c</del><ins>C</ins>ontrols: SI-3, SI-4.
SI-15 (1):title:<ins>INFORMATION OUTPUT FILTERING | LIMIT PERSONALLY IDENTIFIABLE INFORMATION DISSEMINATION</ins>
SI-15 (1):text:<ins>Limit the dissemination of personally identifiable information to [Assignment: organization-defined elements] identified in the privacy risk assessment and consistent with authorized purposes.</ins>
SI-15 (1):supplement:<ins>Preventing the sharing of personally identifiable information outside of explicitly determined elements helps mitigate privacy risks that may arise from using such information to detect anomalous system behavior. Organizations weigh the risks created by using personally identifiable information for information output filtering (as either signature or heuristic information) against the security risks they help mitigate and the established privacy posture in the privacy program plan. Related Controls: PA-2, PA-3, PM-18.</ins>

SI-16:title:MEMORY PROTECTION
SI-16:text:<del>The infor</del><ins>I</ins>m<del>ation system im</del>plement<del>s</del> [Assignment: organization-defined security safeguards] to protect <del>i</del>t<ins>he </ins>s<ins>ystem</ins> memory from unauthorized code execution.
SI-16:supplement:Some adversaries launch attacks with the intent of executing code in non-executable regions of memory or in memory locations that are prohibited. Security safeguards employed to protect memory include, for example, data execution prevention and address space layout randomization. Data execution prevention safeguards can either be hardware-enforced or software-enforced with hardware <ins>enforcement </ins>providing the greater strength of mechanism. Related <del>c</del><ins>C</ins>ontrols: AC-25, SC-3.
